headline: Trump’s Tax Avoidance Is a Tax on the Rest of Us
abstract: The majority of taxpayers can’t afford the expensive professional advice on which successful tax-avoidance strategies depend.
lead_paragraph: We don’t know if Donald Trump’s recent federal income tax returns indicate illegal activity. But even if the $750 income tax bills he paid in each of the first two years of his presidency turn out to have been calculated in compliance with the U.S. Internal Revenue Code, he has enjoyed the benefits of the society we all contribute to build, then skipped out on his share of the bill — a sort of dine-and-dash on his fellow Americans.

headline: Tokyo Stock Market Halts Trading for a Day, Citing Glitch

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Tokyo Stock Exchange shut down for the day on Thursday as its operator raced to solve a technical glitch that halted equities trading throughout the world’s third- largest economy.

headline: N.F.L. Week 4 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: Tom Brady and the Buccaneers are building momentum and the Bears hope to continue an improbable start. Two games — Chiefs-Patriots and Titans-Steelers — have been postponed.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L.’s nearly perfect record in containing the coronavirus took a major hit when multiple members of the Tennessee Titans tested positive following last week’s win over Minnesota. Now, a huge matchup between Tennessee and Pittsburgh — both of which are 3-0 — has been delayed until Week 7. Things got worse on Saturday, when positive tests forced the week’s other top game, between Kansas City and New England, to be postponed until Monday or Tuesday. Thus far the impact on the league has been manageable, but things could quickly get out of control without major precautions.

lead_paragraph: The model and cookbook author Chrissy Teigen said late Wednesday that she and her husband, the singer John Legend, had lost their third child, a son, days after she posted on social media about suffering pregnancy complications.

headline: ‘I feel like crying’: In Rio, the pandemic has stopped an unstoppable parade.
abstract: Wars, disease and political turmoil have never prevented Rio de Janeiro from putting on its famous carnival. Now, the pandemic has forced a suspension of the annual parade for the first time since 1932.
lead_paragraph: Wars, disease and political turmoil have never prevented Rio de Janeiro from putting on its famous carnival. Now, the pandemic has forced a suspension of the annual parade for the first time since 1932.

keywords: ['Television', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A new AMC show dramatizes the 2018 poisoning of a former Russian spy in Britain. Even for a reporter who covered the real events, the four episodes contain revelations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After a former Russian spy was found convulsing on a park bench in the English city of Salisbury, the British prime minister at the time, Theresa May, stood before Parliament and the world and accused the Kremlin of “a brazen act to murder innocent civilians on our soil.”

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Annoying Birthday Requests
abstract: What should you get your boyfriend who incessantly asks for a tiger?
lead_paragraph: Kate writes: Every time I ask my boyfriend, Joel, what he wants for his birthday, he says, “A tiger.” He won’t stop. He is clearly joking, but it’s exasperating. I want an injunction against the joke. Also, what would be a good gift for him?

headline: Are You Having a Tough Time Maintaining Friendships These Days?
abstract: Has the pandemic brought you closer together with friends? Or moved you farther apart?
lead_paragraph: Do you find it difficult to keep up with your friendships in a time of social distancing? Do you find it hard to make new friends in the era of remote schooling, and when people are spending so much time more at home? Has the pandemic brought you closer together, or moved you farther apart, from friends?

headline: Distance Learning, With Shades of Big Brother
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: A video on digital classroom etiquette makes it very clear: Your home is no longer your own, and your kids must pretend to learn in it.
lead_paragraph: There’s an adorable video being sent to parents in at least one public school I know of, aimed at teaching children some Covid-era etiquette. It also reminds me of prison. Titled “Rules of the Digital Classroom,” it was made by an edutainment outfit called Manic Turtle, and it’s as peppy and upbeat as the name of the company implies. Organized in a basic dos-and-don’ts format, it features an adorable little girl, maybe 5 or so, demonstrating correct and incorrect strategies for attending school while staying home.

headline: A Renter Wanted to Return to Her Childhood Neighborhood. Could She Still Afford It?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: With her Bronx lease expiring, a single mother decided to take her family back home — or as close as they could get. Which of these options did she choose?
lead_paragraph: With her Bronx lease expiring, a single mother decided to take her family back home — or as close as they could get. Which of these options did she choose?

headline: Shout Out to the Bodega Boys, From the Bronx to the Best-Seller List
abstract: In “God-Level Knowledge Darts,” Desus Nice & the Kid Mero deliver a “fat sack of truth nuggets.”
lead_paragraph: BOYS TO MEN When Daniel Baker, a.k.a. Desus Nice, got a call from his agent, reps and lawyer out of nowhere in late September, he panicked. “I was like, oh wow, the show must’ve gotten canceled,” he said in a three-way phone interview with Joel Martinez, a.k.a. the Kid Mero, his co-host on their late-night TV series, “Desus & Mero.” “It scared the hell out of me.”

headline: Why ‘Biodegradable’ Isn’t What You Think

lead_paragraph: It sounds positive, but there are a few ways the label ‘biodegradable’ may cause more problems than it solves.

headline: Finding Help to Take Their Next Steps
abstract: Moving beyond challenges at home, these New Yorkers sought assistance to reach their goals.
lead_paragraph: When Denisha Smith left her Brooklyn home at 14, she had nowhere to go.

headline: Alexander Vindman Knew Trump Would End His Career
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: He spoke out anyway. A key witness in the impeachment investigation speaks to Kara Swisher about what that decision cost him.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Vindman — war hero, European affairs expert, lieutenant colonel in the Army — had lofty dreams of serving the United States. But a call he heard between President Trump and Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, gave him pause. Little more than a year after taking a job at the White House, Colonel Vindman testified before Congress regarding the Ukraine scandal, and was a key witness in the impeachment inquiry into Mr. Trump.

headline: Poem: On Taking the Measure of Your Book
abstract: A poem that allows one to feel the fresh exhilaration of a beach, wind and air.
lead_paragraph: In this deeply appealing poem by the Californian Fran Claggett-Holland, from her new book, “The Consciousness of Stone” (RiskPress Foundation), reading is experienced as a supple activity, an actual posture as one moves to engage with textual experience. It’s a physical revelation as well as a landscape — not just a passive stare. I could feel the fresh exhilaration of a beach, wind and air inside my own body after reading this, without having been to any beach for a long time. Sometimes when people ask how to read a poem, one might simply say, “Go inside it.” Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: For the Sake of Democracy, Cancel the Trump-Biden Debates
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The president is maneuvering to steal the election. Why help him?
lead_paragraph: Little more than 12 hours after the conclusion of the most chaotic, counterproductive and outright offensive American presidential debate in my lifetime, the Commission on Presidential Debates promised unspecified format changes in the two remaining faceoffs between Donald Trump and Joe Biden so that the events would be more orderly, which is to say watchable at all.

headline: Tenants Facing Eviction Over Covid-19 Look to a 1970s Solution | Retro Report
abstract: As a housing crisis set off by the Covid-19 pandemic has put low-income tenants at risk of eviction, a counterintuitive proposal to help renters buy their apartments has emerged. It’s an idea that originated during a 1970s eviction battle in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: As a housing crisis set off by the Covid-19 pandemic has put low-income tenants at risk of eviction, a counterintuitive proposal to help renters buy their apartments has emerged. It’s an idea that originated during a 1970s eviction battle in San Francisco.

abstract: A lot of families are going to need restructuring by the time this is over. They probably needed it before.
lead_paragraph: One of the few good things about a deadly pandemic is that if you are a person who enjoys talking on the phone, as I am, you will now have lots of time to do this, far more time than you did during regular life.

headline: She Was Resting With Her Sons. Then a Shot Was Fired.
abstract: Bertha Arriaga heard a noise and went to the window of her Queens home, where a stray bullet killed her.  An arrest was made on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Bertha Arriaga was resting in a bedroom with her three sleeping sons when she heard a commotion outside and went to the window. It was after midnight.

headline: How Trump Voters View His Position on Pre-existing Conditions
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: He has pursued policies to weaken insurance protections, but that’s not reflected in polling of Republicans.
lead_paragraph: When Pamela Jean Locke votes in November, one issue she’ll be thinking about is protections for Americans with pre-existing health problems.

headline: When Latinos Saw Themselves Onscreen: ‘It Was Exhilarating’
abstract: For some it was “Selena”; for another, Bruce Lee. Latino actors and filmmakers share the surprising moments when they felt seen onscreen.
lead_paragraph: The experiences of American-born or -raised Latinos remain largely overlooked in entertainment — or conflated with border-crossing stories, and those set in Latin America. So we assembled a list of 20 essential films released since the year 2000 that focus on characters with an American identity and Latino heritage. Here, some of the Latino actors and filmmakers whose work appears on the list share when they first felt seen onscreen.

headline: New York Becomes First Big City in U.S. to Reopen All Its Schools
abstract: It’s a significant moment for the recovery in a city hit hard by the pandemic in the spring. The system, the nation’s largest, is welcoming back 500,000 students.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on NYC school closings due to Covid-19]

headline: The 51st State America Needs
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Electoral College', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Yes, statehood for Washington, D.C., is good for Democrats. It is also good for democracy.
lead_paragraph: As Election Day nears, conservative lawmakers like Senator John Barrasso of Wyoming have warned that Democrats plan to “stack the Senate” by admitting new states to the union if they win control of the presidency and Congress. We certainly hope so. Democrats should make District of Columbia statehood a top priority if they win in November. Adding a star to the American flag for the district would be good for the Democratic Party and good for democracy.

headline: Why This Artist Is Paying Bodegas With 120,000 Pennies
abstract: A message about the pandemic, inscribed on $1,200 worth of coins, is trickling into New York’s shops, and possibly your pocket.
lead_paragraph: A conceptual artist walked into a bodega during a pandemic carrying a box full of pennies.

headline: A Brief History of the Taxpayer in Chief
keywords: ['Trump Tax Returns', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Evasion']
abstract: From Lincoln to Trump, the president’s attitude toward his taxes has shaped the public’s attitude toward theirs.
lead_paragraph: This week’s investigation by The Times into President Trump’s long-hidden tax returns uncovered staggering business losses and such vigorous exploitation of loopholes that the president paid only $750 in federal income taxes in 2016 and 2017. When asked during Tuesday’s presidential debate about the revelations, Mr. Trump was unrepentant. “It was the tax laws,” he declared. His tax avoidance was “like every other private person, unless they’re stupid.”

headline: With His New Mystery Novel, John Banville Kills Off a Pen Name
abstract: “Snow” would normally have been published under the pseudonym Benjamin Black, but Banville says he doesn’t need that “rascal” anymore.
lead_paragraph: The Irish novelist John Banville is a famous perfectionist — the kind of writer who can spend a day on a single sentence. His books, most written in the first person, are lapidary, intricate, Nabokovian. Or just difficult, some readers have complained, more interested in style than in storytelling. They invariably come laden with words that seem meant to prove his vocabulary is bigger than yours: flocculent, crapulent, caducous, anaglypta, mephitic, velutinous.

headline: With Evictions Looming, Cities Revisit a Housing Experiment From the ’70s
abstract: Proposals giving tenants the right to purchase their building are being revived as the coronavirus puts renters at risk.
lead_paragraph: Even before the coronavirus pandemic rang down the curtain on much of the U.S. economy, times could be tough for the roughly 110 million Americans living in rental housing. For many of them, paying the landlord was a tattered hope and staving off the sheriff’s deputies an endless worry. Nearly four million eviction petitions were filed each year. On any given night as many as 200,000 people were without a home.

headline: Laughter May Be Effective Medicine for These Trying Times
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Laughter', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Hospitals', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Doctors', 'Heart', 'Pain']
abstract: Doctors, nurses and therapists have a prescription for helping all of us to get through these difficult times: Try a little laughter.
lead_paragraph: Some enlightened doctors, nurses and therapists have a prescription for helping all of us to get through this seemingly never-ending pandemic: Try a little laughter.

headline: When Your Job Is to Make Sure Nov. 3 Isn’t a Disaster
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Absentee Voting', 'Elections', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As the top elections officials in many states, secretaries of state are managing a level of chaos they never expected.
lead_paragraph: A flood of mail-in ballots that will need processing. Foreign disinformation campaigns. A shortage of poll workers. And voters afraid of catching a potentially fatal disease at the ballot box.

headline: The Army Rolls Out a New Weapon: Strategic Napping
abstract: Because fatigue can corrode mission performance, a new physical training manual tells soldiers to grab 40 winks when they can, part of a new holistic approach to health in the ranks.
lead_paragraph: Turns out Beetle Bailey had it right all along.

headline: Jim Murray, a Top Whiskey Critic, Faces Accusations of Sexism
abstract: Several distillers and retailers have severed ties to the British writer, after complaints surfaced about the treatment of women in his books and at events.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, the British spirits writer Jim Murray has held sway as the world’s most influential whiskey critic, thanks largely to his “Whisky Bible,” an annual compendium of thousands of reviews, including his prestigious World Whisky of the Year award. His words can make or break a brand, his books have sold more than a million copies, and his tasting events, which take him from Kentucky to India to points in between, attract thousands of fans.

headline: In U.S.-China Tech Feud, Taiwan Feels Heat From Both Sides
keywords: ['5G (Wireless Communications)', 'United States International Relations', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Chips', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The island’s biggest chip maker has been a coveted partner to both battling giants. But rising nationalism is making it harder to keep the middle ground.
lead_paragraph: TAINAN, Taiwan — The United States and China are wrestling to lead the world in artificial intelligence, 5G wireless and other cutting-edge technologies. But the real wizardry that makes those advancements possible is being performed on a yam-shaped island that sits between them, geographically and politically.

headline: Roland Mouret on How to Create a Vacation Bag for the Summer That Wasn’t
abstract: As part of our Designer D.I.Y. series, Mr. Mouret shows how to make a denim handbag inspired by a town on the French Riviera.
lead_paragraph: Here, Roland Mouret, known for his feminine silhouettes and famous bodycon Galaxy dress, has chosen to create a knotted handbag out of a simple square of denim and an inexpensive metal chain. He calls it the Nimes.

headline: The American Latino Experience: 20 Essential Films Since 2000
abstract: In Hollywood, Hispanic stories usually mean ones from other countries. The features and documentaries on this list explore U.S. lives that deserve the spotlight, too.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood still doesn’t get it.

headline: ‘A Battle for the Souls of Black Girls’
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Education (K-12)', 'School Discipline (Students)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Discipline disparities between Black and white boys have driven reform efforts for years. But Black girls are arguably the most at-risk student group in the United States.
lead_paragraph: BINGHAMTON, N.Y. — Zulayka McKinstry’s once silly, sociable daughter has stopped seeing friends, talking to siblings and trusting anyone — changes Ms. McKinstry dates to the day in January 2019 when her daughter’s school principal decided that “hyper and giddy” were suspicious behaviors in a 12-year-old girl.

headline: Russian Opposition Leader Navalny Says Putin Is Behind His Poisoning
abstract: In an interview with Der Spiegel, Aleksei Navalny said the use of a military-grade nerve agent was proof that Russia’s president was involved.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, who was poisoned in August in Siberia, says he has no doubt that President Vladimir V. Putin was behind the attack.

headline: In Germany, New Plays Consider Autonomy in the Age of Corona
abstract: In a country in which cultural life is returning to an enviable version of normal, the fall theater season opens with reflections on the meaning and limits of freedom.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Late last month, I shared a picture on Twitter of the audience at the Thalia Theater shortly before a performance.

headline: 40 More Intriguing Photos to Make Students Think
abstract: A new slide show of some of our favorite “What’s Going On in This Picture?” posts, culled from the last four years of images.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago we published a collection of 40 intriguing photographs from the first four years of our popular weekly feature “What’s Going On in This Picture?” The slide show quickly became a go-to resource for teachers around the world, and it remains one of our most utilized teaching resources — ever.

headline: Jacinda Ardern Admits Past Cannabis Use. New Zealanders Shrug: ‘Us, Too.’
abstract: As a former marijuana smoker, the prime minister has plenty of company in New Zealand. But she stopped short of backing legalization in a referendum this month.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The question from the debate moderator in New Zealand was simple and to the point: “Jacinda Ardern, have you ever used cannabis?”

headline: Fans celebrate the Stanley Cup champions, well outside the N.H.L.’s pandemic bubble.
abstract: The Tampa Bay Lightning won the National Hockey League’s top trophy on Monday from within the confines of a 24/7 pandemic bubble in western Canada, and without any fans in the arena to watch.
lead_paragraph: The Tampa Bay Lightning won the National Hockey League’s top trophy on Monday from within the confines of a 24/7 pandemic bubble in western Canada, and without any fans in the arena to watch.

headline: A YouTuber Hangs His Own Shingle With an Auction Website
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Auctions', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Entrepreneurship']
abstract: Doug DeMuro has a strong following for his giddy videos about exotic and quirky cars. Cars & Bids, his new site, got off to a roaring start.
lead_paragraph: Making the most important pitch of his career, Doug DeMuro stood in cargo shorts in front of a camera, unwavering in his giddy demeanor. He was about to unveil his new car auction website to his 3.7 million YouTube subscribers. The site would feature cars “that I like most,” he said.

headline: A User’s Guide to Mail-In Voting
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: How do you secure an absentee ballot? When will Americans know who has won the presidency? Take a walk through the rules, realities and rancor of the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic will mean that many more Americans vote by mail this year.

headline: Trump’s Fear of Biden
abstract: And what else you need to know today.

headline: E.U. Brings Suit Against U.K. on Eve of Crucial Trade Talks
abstract: The move came after Britain refused to withdraw legislation that it admits could break international law by potentially overriding commitments on Northern Ireland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A decision by the European Commission on Thursday to press ahead with legal action against Britain over its plans to override parts of an agreement on withdrawal from the bloc raises the stakes at a critical moment in talks that will determine whether the two sides can avert an economically ruinous rupture.

headline: The Trump Debate Fallout
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Absentee Voting']
abstract: The president reluctantly walks back his nod to a far-right group: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans do the old dance around Trump and racism, while Biden presses his case in Ohio and Pennsylvania. Plus, a Q. and A. with Jim Rutenberg about his explosive voter-suppression investigation. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: ‘12 Hour Shift’ Review: When a Bedside Manner Includes Murder
abstract: The exploitation comedy about nurses who are secretly harvesting patients’ organs has about two good jokes for every bad one.
lead_paragraph: How quickly we pivot from honoring our frontline workers. In the exploitation splatter comedy “12 Hour Shift,” two nurses manage an organ-trafficking network out of their Arkansas hospital. The drug-addled Mandy (Angela Bettis), who takes her orders from Karen (Nikea Gamby-Turner), brings fresh harvests to the soda machine just outside the building’s doors. From there, Regina (Chloe Farnworth), who harbors a misapprehension that she’s Mandy’s cousin, is supposed to shuttle organs in a picnic cooler to their destination.

headline: ‘Eternal Beauty’ Review: Sally Hawkins, in Another Transformation
abstract: Hawkins, a two-time Oscar nominee, explores a character with mental illness in this comedy-drama from Craig Roberts.
lead_paragraph: The Welsh actor Craig Roberts dedicates his second directorial feature to “the real Calamity Jane,” making clear that “Eternal Beauty” is based on actual people in his life. (He’s also said so in interviews.) The Jane he presents in this movie — he’s also the writer — is played by Sally Hawkins, and her performance is another startling transformation in her filmography. (She’s a two-time Oscar nominee, for her work in “The Shape of Water” and “Happy Go Lucky,” playing two very different characters.)

headline: ‘A Call to Spy’ Review: A Resistance Led by Women
abstract: Some tough agents help Winston Churchill take on the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: “A Call to Spy” is a welcome, albeit imperfect, addition to the existing slate of movies about World War II. The propulsive historical drama, which was written by Sarah Megan Thomas (she also plays Virginia Hall, one of the three leads) and directed by Lydia Dean Pilcher, explores the lives of three remarkable women who served as spies for the Allied nations.

headline: ‘Save Yourselves!’ Review: Alien Invasion in the Smartphone Generation
abstract: The writer-directors Alex Huston Fischer and Eleanor Wilson lovingly poke fun at the doomed generation in this apocalyptic comedy.
lead_paragraph: Imagine surviving an alien invasion when you’re a staunchly anti-gun Brooklyn millennial with no survival skills beyond making a sourdough starter. That amusing premise sets the stage for this apocalyptic comedy from the writer-directors Alex Huston Fischer and Eleanor Wilson, which should belong in a subgenre sillier than “mumblegore,” the horror offshoot of the low-budget, dialogue-heavy mumblecore.

headline: ‘Possessor’ Review: It’s by a Cronenberg, but Not the One You Think
abstract: The assassin in this film by Brandon Cronenberg weaponizes the human mind and body of an unsuspecting stranger who has access to her target.
lead_paragraph: “Possessor,” about an assassin who works by taking over the mind and body of someone who can get close to the victim without suspicion, could have sprung from the imagination of David Cronenberg and, like his early films, “Possessor” is equal parts cerebral and visceral. But this film is the work of the writer-director Brandon Cronenberg, his son. It depicts horrific murders in appalling detail as it relentlessly interrogates the experience of inhabiting a foreign body.

headline: ‘The Great American Lie’ Review: Another Interpretation of the Dream
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Income Inequality', 'Women and Girls', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Scholars, activists, politicians and real people illustrate the national economic abyss.
lead_paragraph: The run-of-the-mill documentary “The Great American Lie” fires shots at the American Dream, criticizing a country that has failed its promise.

headline: Take It or Leave It
abstract: Palantir’s C.E.O. defended the founders’ tight control over the company, citing defense of its corporate mission.
lead_paragraph: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.

headline: ‘Dick Johnson Is Dead’ Review: A Father’s Painful, Funny Goodbye
abstract: With the help of her father, the documentary filmmaker Kirsten Johnson made a surprising, endearing movie about his death.
lead_paragraph: Critics like to pigeonhole movies using familiar categories — fiction, nonfiction, happy, sad — but one of the charms of “Dick Johnson Is Dead” is how slippery it is. Pitched artfully between the celebratory and the elegiac, it is an inarguably serious documentary with light, surrealistic flourishes that, at times, veer into exuberant goofiness. Even at its silliest, the movie retains an undertow of melancholia because (as the title announces) it’s a death notice. It is also a love letter from a daughter to a father who, for the viewer, becomes fully human even as he fades away.

headline: Editors’ Note
abstract: This article was published in error.
lead_paragraph: This article was published in error.

headline: China’s ‘Golden Week’ Kicks Off in Boost to Battered Tourism Industry
abstract: Chinese travelers are expected to fan out across the country in droves, even as anxiety about the virus and the economy lingers.
lead_paragraph: Along the Great Wall, extra security guards have been deployed to deter rowdy tourists. Hotel bookings in Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, have risen 600 percent from the same period last year. In Wuhan, where the coronavirus outbreak began late last year, visitor demand for the city’s Yellow Crane Tower has been so high that the landmark sits atop a major travel agency’s list of the “Country’s Hottest Scenic Spots.”

headline: Is It Time to Rethink Milton Friedman?
abstract: Leo Strine, the former Delaware chief justice, and Joey Zwillinger of the shoe brand Allbirds discuss whether the economist’s influential essay ignored social inequality.
lead_paragraph: To commemorate the 50th anniversary of Milton Friedman’s influential essay, “The Social Responsibility of Business Is to Increase Its Profits,” DealBook teamed up with The New York Times Magazine to collect thoughts from executives, political leaders and Nobel Prize winners on its legacy.

headline: Breaking Impasse, E.U. Imposes Sanctions on Belarus
abstract: The delay in punishing Belarus for the crackdown that followed its flawed elections had been a huge embarrassment for the bloc.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders early Friday finally broke a longstanding impasse to impose sanctions against Belarus as they tackled a raft of interconnected issues — from Turkey to the coronavirus recovery fund to the rule of law — that would have been complicated even if taken one by one.

headline: Corporate America’s Role in the Fight for Racial Justice
abstract: A conversation with The Times’s Nikole Hannah-Jones on how businesses can help whittle away social inequities — and why they should.
lead_paragraph: Corporate leaders have been pledging support for civil rights initiatives and re-examining their records on racial inequality, but critics contend that well-intentioned promises have had little effect. On this DealBook Debrief call, Nikole Hannah-Jones, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter for The Times Magazine and creator of the 1619 Project, said that “corporate America has a much, much larger role to play.”

headline: Amid a surge in cases, India plans to reopen cinemas, entertainment parks and some schools.
abstract: Despite a fast-growing number of coronavirus cases, India will allow cinemas and entertainment parks to open with limited capacity beginning Oct. 15, in an effort to revive an economy that has been battered by the pandemic. Swimming pools will be open for athletes in training, and states could be allowed to open schools.
lead_paragraph: Despite a fast-growing number of coronavirus cases, India will allow cinemas and entertainment parks to open with limited capacity beginning Oct. 15, in an effort to revive an economy that has been battered by the pandemic. Swimming pools will be open for athletes in training, and states could be allowed to open schools.

headline: If MAGA Hats Are Business Casual, Why Isn’t My Biden Shirt?
abstract: A reader is bothered by his employer’s insistence that his political merch is inappropriate when others are free to wear theirs.
lead_paragraph: I am a Democrat in a very red state. I work at a small service business where I interact with customers in person. Several of my co-workers wear bright red “Make America Great Again” caps. So, I bought a Joe Biden T-shirt to express my views. Recently, though, my boss, the owner of the company, issued a rule that “customer-facing employees” are not allowed to wear political garb. I can’t wear my shirt, but the accounting guys in the back office can still wear their MAGA hats. I don’t think this is fair. Do you? What about my First Amendment rights?

headline: A Countercultural Dreamland From Tokyo Flickers at MoMA
abstract: In 1969, Shuzo Azuchi Gulliver created a moving-image environment with 18 projectors. Now his and other expanded cinema works from Japanese pioneers are in New York.
lead_paragraph: Norma Desmond was right, the pictures got small. Once cinema filled your field of vision, but in this century, as ever cheaper digital displays have replaced projection technologies, we have grown accustomed to smaller and smaller movies. The old movie palaces, with their 50-foot silver screens, have mostly shut down. The multiplexes are in trouble. You probably watched your last movie on a 55-inch TV set, a 21-inch computer monitor, or, feel free to admit, a 6-inch cameraphone screen.

headline: T’s Design & Luxury Issue: Safe Havens
abstract: In praise of homes that are worlds unto themselves, reflecting their owners’ unique tastes while offering shelter from all manner of storms.
lead_paragraph: Before a home is a place of beauty, or a stage for its inhabitant’s personality, it’s something that provides that most essential of needs: shelter, whether from weather or, as we all now well know, disease.

headline: Long Island’s Enduring Black Beachfront Community
abstract: A brief history of how New York’s Sag Harbor became a refuge for African-American families, with testimonials from some of the residents who’ve summered there for much of their lives.
lead_paragraph: A brief history of how New York’s Sag Harbor became a refuge for African-American families, with testimonials from some of the residents who’ve summered there for much of their lives.

headline: On Long Island, a Beachfront Haven for Black Families
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Families and Family Life', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: In the 1930s, a group of trailblazing African-Americans bought plots for themselves in Sag Harbor, establishing a close-knit community that’s spanned multiple generations.
lead_paragraph: WHILE VACATIONING ONE summer in the late 1930s, Maude Terry decided to go fishing. On her way to Gardiners Bay in eastern Long Island, she came across a secluded, underdeveloped, marshy, wooded area that faced a beach. Immediately, she felt a sense of tranquillity in the sylvan space, surrounded by tall old oak and walnut trees. Green shrubbery and weeds grew amid the sand at her feet, and her skin turned sticky in the salt air. It was heaven.

headline: Facebook bans ads that aim to undermine the election.
abstract: Facebook on Wednesday said it would prohibit the purchase of ads that seek to delegitimize the outcome of the election, as the social network prepares for a turbulent next few weeks.
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Wednesday said it would prohibit the purchase of ads that seek to delegitimize the outcome of the election, as the social network prepares for a turbulent next few weeks.

headline: A far-right group that trades in political violence has gotten a boost from Trump.
abstract: During this week’s presidential debate, President Trump said an extremist organization should “stand back and stand by.” Some saw it as an endorsement of a group known for street brawls.
lead_paragraph: When hundreds of supporters of President Trump gathered for a Labor Day rally in Oregon, a man in the signature black-and-gold shirt of the Proud Boys approached the crowd with a welcoming smile.

headline: For undecided voters, one thing is clear: The debate didn’t help.
abstract: A small but crucial segment of likely voters say they remain uncommitted — to a candidate or to voting at all — and nothing they heard on Tuesday clinched things for them.
lead_paragraph: “Useless.” “Ridiculous.” “Horrible.”

headline: Trump renews fears of voter intimidation as G.O.P. poll watchers mobilize.
abstract: Republicans are putting together what they call an army of Trump supporters to monitor election procedures.
lead_paragraph: The group of Trump campaign officials came carrying cellphone cameras and a determination to help the president’s re-election efforts in Philadelphia. But they were asked to leave the city’s newly opened satellite election offices on Tuesday after being told local election laws did not permit them to monitor voters coming to request and complete absentee ballots.

headline: A study found the ‘single largest driver’ of coronavirus misinformation. It was the president.
abstract: Cornell University researchers analyzing 38 million English-language articles about the pandemic found that President Trump was the largest driver of the “infodemic.”
lead_paragraph: Of the flood of misinformation, conspiracy theories and falsehoods seeding the internet on the coronavirus, one common thread stands out: President Trump.

headline: Will Trump participate in the next two debates? The White House won’t commit.
abstract: Democrats and Republicans alike have speculated that after Tuesday’s debacle, the presidential candidates might not debate again. Both have decent incentives to give it another shot.
lead_paragraph: There are two more presidential debates left before Election Day, but now, after the debacle of the first debate — 90 minutes dominated by insults, attacks and interruptions by President Trump — everything seems up in the air.

headline: Where Does America Sit in a Pandemic World?
abstract: A conversation with The Times’s Tom Friedman about how Covid-19 has changed the United States’ position in global affairs.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic has disrupted life as we knew it, and the Trump administration has upended American policies along with it. The Times foreign affairs columnist Tom Friedman joined us for a DealBook Debrief call to make sense of it all.

headline: The Calculus Behind Trump’s Covid Response
abstract: A conversation with The Times’s Maggie Haberman about how President Trump has managed the federal response to the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Haberman, White House correspondent for The Times, joined us for a DealBook Debrief call to assess how the Trump administration was managing its pandemic response, re-election campaign and more.

headline: Inside the New Tech Cold War
abstract: A conversation with The Times’s David Sanger on how Washington and Beijing are battling over the future of technology.
lead_paragraph: Tensions between China and the U.S. have climbed ever higher in recent months, with clashes over Chinese tech companies becoming a huge flash point. David Sanger, The Times’s national security correspondent, joined us for a DealBook Debrief call with readers to discuss the battle between Washington and Beijing over tech companies like Huawei and TikTok.

headline: Turkey admits not including asymptomatic people in its count.
abstract: Turkey has acknowledged that it was not making all confirmed coronavirus cases public in its daily announced tally, but counting only those patients showing symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Turkey has acknowledged that it was not making all confirmed coronavirus cases public in its daily announced tally, but counting only those patients showing symptoms.

headline: Pence heads to Iowa, as Biden and Trump catch their breath and host fund-raisers.
abstract: Here are the daily schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Thursday, Oct. 1. All times are Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Here are the daily schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Thursday, Oct. 1. All times are Eastern time.

headline: The battle over restrictions in Madrid moves to the courtroom.
abstract: The debate over how and whether to lock down Madrid, the epicenter of Spain’s second wave of the virus, is moving to the courtroom as the region challenges a national decree that would lock down the capital and prevent Madrid-area residents from traveling to other parts of the country.
lead_paragraph: The debate over how and whether to lock down Madrid, the epicenter of Spain’s second wave of the virus, is moving to the courtroom as the region challenges a national decree that would lock down the capital and prevent Madrid-area residents from traveling to other parts of the country.

headline: An Interview With the Pac-12 Commissioner
abstract: The conference announced last week that it would try to play football beginning Nov. 6.
lead_paragraph: Pac-12 football is coming back, or so the league hopes.

headline: Unemployment claims in the U.S. show little relief from pandemic layoffs.
abstract: American employers continue to cut jobs at rates that dwarf the pace of layoffs in past decades, even as the economy crawls forward from the coronavirus-induced recession that began last spring.
lead_paragraph: American employers continue to cut jobs at rates that dwarf the pace of layoffs in past decades, even as the economy crawls forward from the coronavirus-induced recession that began last spring.

headline: Fauci pushes back against Trump for misrepresenting his stance on masks.
abstract: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the leading U.S. official on infectious diseases, hit back at President Trump on Wednesday for what he called the misrepresentation of his stance on using masks to curb the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the leading U.S. official on infectious diseases, hit back at President Trump on Wednesday for what he called the misrepresentation of his stance on using masks to curb the coronavirus.

headline: A High-Tech Twin for a Renaissance Masterpiece
abstract: A copy of Michelangelo’s David printed in 3-D will be the centerpiece of the Italy Pavilion at the next world fair.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — For the past five centuries, Michelangelo’s David has been celebrated for its sculptural perfection and its embodiment of youthful beauty and strength.

headline: Three charts about the markets in the third quarter.
abstract: It’s a new month, and a new quarter. Today’s DealBook newsletter ran the numbers …
lead_paragraph: It’s a new month, and a new quarter. Today’s DealBook newsletter ran the numbers …

headline: Plenty of work for homebuilders, but few commercial construction jobs.
abstract: Home construction workers, whose livelihoods were on the line as the economy collapsed in the spring, are benefiting from a newly resurgent housing market, while builders of commercial and retail properties struggle.
lead_paragraph: Home construction workers, whose livelihoods were on the line as the economy collapsed in the spring, are benefiting from a newly resurgent housing market, while builders of commercial and retail properties struggle.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: JW Anderson x Moncler, perfume for the home — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Which Cities Are Converting the Most Factories Into Homes?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Conversions of commercial and institutional buildings to residences has accelerated to an all-time high in the past decade.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic stretches on, office buildings sit empty as their tenants work from home, and brick and-mortar stores continue to lose ground to online shopping. Witness the bankruptcies of major retail giants J.C. Penney and Neiman Marcus, and the pile of Amazon deliveries in your building lobby, as clear evidence.

headline: 5 Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
abstract: Pandemic posters, “impossible exhibitions,” pictures of fungi and lockdown protests: These art accounts are a creative coping mechanism for staying engaged during a trying time.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic continues to devastate countries around the world, natural disasters bear down and Election Day draws nearer, I find myself struggling with opposite impulses: I want to keep up with the news, and I want to escape into pleasure and imagination. Instagram offers both. Some accounts help me process current events, others provide aesthetic wonder, and still others manage the two at once. This list covers all the points on that spectrum. Consider it a creative coping mechanism for staying engaged during a trying time.

headline: The Astros Are Moving On, Even if the Rest of You Aren’t
abstract: A cheating scandal still shadows Houston, but in empty stadiums its players are tuning it out. “The more we win, the closer it brings us together.”
lead_paragraph: The Houston Astros hear you. Even with no crowds to heckle them from the stands, they know what you think of them. You want them to go away.

headline: Her hours cut to almost nothing, she spent the time trying to launch a new career.
abstract: Joann Taylor, a catering coordinator at a McAlister’s Deli franchise in Houston, used to work about 30 hours per week. But when the pandemic hit, her boss put her in an on-call position for deliveries only.
lead_paragraph: Joann Taylor, a catering coordinator at a McAlister’s Deli franchise in Houston, used to work about 30 hours per week. But when the pandemic hit, her boss put her in an on-call position for deliveries only.

headline: These people’s job is making sure Nov. 3 isn’t a disaster.
abstract: As the top elections officials in many states, secretaries of state are managing a level of chaos they never expected.
lead_paragraph: A flood of mail-in ballots that will need processing. Foreign disinformation campaigns. A shortage of poll workers. And voters afraid of catching a potentially fatal disease at the ballot box.

headline: Subsidized furlough programs keep a lid on eurozone unemployment.
abstract: The unemployment rate in the eurozone edged up to 8.1 percent in August from 8 percent in July, the European Union said Thursday, as government support cushioned much of the economic impact of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate in the eurozone edged up to 8.1 percent in August from 8 percent in July, the European Union said Thursday, as government support cushioned much of the economic impact of the pandemic.

headline: Where You Carry Body Fat May Affect How Long You Live
abstract: Extra weight in some places may lower your risk of dying prematurely.
lead_paragraph: Being overweight is linked to an increased risk for premature death, but which part of the body carries the added fat could make a big difference. Extra weight in some places may actually lower the risk.

headline: After a layoff, a couple struggles to get by on one salary and jobless benefits.
abstract: Until June, MacKenzie Nicholson worked for the American Cancer Society, lobbying state and federal legislators to increase funding for cancer research. She lost her job after the pandemic forced the organization to cancel events across the country, eroding its revenue.
lead_paragraph: Until June, MacKenzie Nicholson worked for the American Cancer Society, lobbying state and federal legislators to increase funding for cancer research. She lost her job after the pandemic forced the organization to cancel events across the country, eroding its revenue.

headline: Google commits $1 billion to license content from news publishers.
abstract: Google said on Thursday that it would spend more than $1 billion to license content from international news organizations, after years of criticism that it was not providing fair compensation for articles and other content linked to by its internet search products.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Thursday that it would spend more than $1 billion to license content from international news organizations, after years of criticism that it was not providing fair compensation for articles and other content linked to by its internet search products.

headline: Yankees Will Face the Tough Rays After a Record-Setting Playoff Win
abstract: When Aroldis Chapman struck out Austin Hedges at 1:14 a.m., the Yankees had defeated the Indians to cap the longest nine-inning game in major league history.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — At one point in the eighth inning of the epic Game 2 of the wild-card series between the Yankees and the Indians, Yankees third baseman Gio Urshela looked back at the giant scoreboard at Progressive Field and saw that the clock was approaching 1 a.m. Thursday.

headline: On China’s National Day, Hong Kong Police Quash Protests
abstract: One year ago, an important political anniversary in China was met with chaotic demonstrations in Hong Kong. This year, police quickly silenced expressions of dissent.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — One year ago, China’s National Day on Oct. 1 was a day of protest and turmoil in Hong Kong. Demonstrators set fires and blockaded streets. The police responded with tear gas and pepper spray. One officer shot a young demonstrator with a live bullet.

headline: Mellon Foundation to Provide $5 Million to Aid Black Theaters
abstract: The Billie Holiday Theater in Brooklyn will spearhead The Black Seed, a strategic plan that will offer grants to up to 50 theaters across the country.
lead_paragraph: Black theaters across the country will receive a significant financial boost thanks to a multimillion-dollar program announced today by the Billie Holiday Theater, a Black-led artistic institution in Brooklyn.

headline: Galleries and an Auction House Follow Collectors to Florida
abstract: Pace, Acquavella and Sotheby’s are opening seasonal spaces in Palm Beach.
lead_paragraph: As the birds fly south for the winter, some of the art world will undertake a similar migration: Pace Gallery, Acquavella Galleries and Sotheby’s are opening seasonal gallery spaces in Palm Beach, Fla., a hub for wealthy vacationers.

headline: The Special Place Where Ella Fitzgerald Comes Alive
abstract: The singer’s concert recordings have always had a power that her studio outings could only imply. “Ella: The Lost Berlin Tapes,” a newly unearthed 1962 performance, magnifies her legacy.
lead_paragraph: Ella Fitzgerald hardly ever crooned the blues, and her vocals rarely overflowed with pathos or fury. Listening to her nail a ballad, you may not feel invited to leap into her own world and feel her pain, like you would with Billie Holiday or Little Jimmy Scott.

headline: 7 Podcasts for Music Lovers
abstract: These shows will keep you up-to-date on new releases, deepen your appreciation of your existing playlists and help to broaden your musical horizons.
lead_paragraph: No corner of culture has been untouched by the pandemic, with institutions shuttered, most movie and TV production in limbo, and most live performances indefinitely postponed. But music has weathered the storm better than many art forms, as artists turn to virtual concerts during lockdown or produce records inspired directly by the quarantine, like Charli XCX’s “How I’m Feeling Now” and Taylor Swift’s “Folklore.”

headline: The Artists Giving New Life to Fake Flowers
abstract: Common in Victorian London, handmade paper blooms have sprouted once again.
lead_paragraph: IN EARLY REGENCY-ERA England, neo-Classicism defined design: Walls were painted the pale hues of a summer morning. Greek motifs abounded. But such subtlety was too tame for the Victorians who followed, who preferred resplendent fakery: papier-mâché molded into heavy-looking armoires, giltwood chairs carved to resemble bamboo, lace crocheted to mimic snowflakes.

headline: The Pandemic’s Pressure on Military Spouses
abstract: ‘We are no strangers to separation.’
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of the pandemic, military wives across the country were circulating a smug meme: Some of you have never had the government ruin your plans and it shows.

headline: After 2 Years of Paralysis, Belgium Forms a (Very Fragile) Government
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: A coalition, cobbled together from seven political parties, will try to keep a growing far-right movement at bay and look to finally pass a budget and a pandemic recovery package.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — For nearly two years, Belgium has been without a formal government, leaving a country that was already divided by language and politics to endure a pandemic with lame-duck caretakers wielding emergency powers.

headline: Italy’s daily new cases topped 2,000 for the first time since April.
abstract: Italy registered a number of infections exceeding 2,000 for the first time since April on Thursday, when 2,548 residents tested positive for coronavirus in one day.
lead_paragraph: Italy registered a number of infections exceeding 2,000 for the first time since April on Thursday, when 2,548 residents tested positive for coronavirus in one day.

headline: Trump Launches Xenophobic Attack Against Omar in Minnesota Speech
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Chants of ‘‘lock her up” broke out during a campaign rally for President Trump after he accused Representative Ilhan Omar of telling “us” how “to run our country.”
lead_paragraph: Chants of ‘‘lock her up” broke out during a campaign rally for President Trump after he accused Representative Ilhan Omar of telling “us” how “to run our country.”

headline: Facing 200 Abuse Claims, Diocese Becomes U.S.’s Largest to Seek Bankruptcy
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Bankruptcies', 'New York Child Victims Act (2019)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The move by the Diocese of Rockville Centre on Long Island came after numerous lawsuits were filed under the Child Victims Act.
lead_paragraph: Facing more than 200 lawsuits over sexual abuse allegations, the Diocese of Rockville Centre on Long Island said on Thursday that it filed for bankruptcy, the largest Roman Catholic diocese in the United States to do so.

headline: Fraud Schemes Exploit Weak Spots in Unemployment Claims System
keywords: ['Unemployment Insurance', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Identity Theft', 'States (US)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Pandemic programs have lowered the barriers to collecting benefits, and the usual security methods haven’t kept up.
lead_paragraph: The for-sale ad appeared last week in an underground internet bazaar that specializes in selling stolen accounts and data. It was for access to a filched unemployment insurance claim in California that had been approved and offered benefits worth $17,550.

headline: Brennan Rebuffed Requests to Lower Confidence in Key Russia Finding
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'National Intelligence Estimates', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The revelation that the former C.I.A. director sided with analysts over senior officers, contained in his new book, has been a focus of the Justice Department review of the Russia inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The former C.I.A. director John O. Brennan disagreed with the recommendation of two senior officers in early 2017 who wanted to override intelligence analysts’ determination that the agency had high confidence in one of its major judgments in the assessment of Russia’s 2016 election interference: that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia tried to help Donald J. Trump by discrediting Hillary Clinton.

headline: Overlooked No More: Lucy Diggs Slowe, Scholar Who Persisted Against Racism and Sexism
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Biographical Information', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Impelled by her vision of the modern Black woman, Slowe nurtured a post-World War I generation at Howard University to be empowered, self-aware and globally conscious.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. It is also part of The Times’s continuing coverage of the centennial of the 19th Amendment, which gave women the vote.

headline: A day after refusing to condemn white supremacists, Trump aims a xenophobic attack at Ilhan Omar.
abstract: President Trump aimed a xenophobic attack at Representative Ilhan Omar at a rally, one day after he refused to denounce white supremacists.
lead_paragraph: A day after he refused to condemn white supremacists at the first presidential debate, President Trump unleashed a xenophobic attack on Representative Ilhan Omar at a rally in Minnesota Wednesday night, accusing her of telling “us” — meaning his overwhelmingly white audience — “how to run our country.”

headline: H&M will close stores and ramp up digital efforts as online sales rise.
abstract: Shares in the Swedish retailer H&M rose more than 7 percent after the company said online sales were growing strongly and the company had already returned to profit in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: Shares in the Swedish retailer H&M rose more than 7 percent after the company said online sales were growing strongly and the company had already returned to profit in the third quarter.

headline: ‘Good for the Psyche of This City:’ Indoor Dining Resumes in N.Y.C.
abstract: Indoor dining resumed in New York City at 25 percent capacity. However, some diners remained wary as coronavirus cases grew throughout the city.
lead_paragraph: Indoor dining resumed in New York City at 25 percent capacity. However, some diners remained wary as coronavirus cases grew throughout the city.

headline: The Postal Service Needs Fixing. Here’s How It Could Happen.
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Even as it becomes a focus of debate in a sharply partisan election year, the agency is crippled by economic forces outside its control. But a number of proposals, new and old, could chart a path forward.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On at least one issue, most of Washington agrees: The Postal Service needs an intervention.

headline: The Feats and Failures of Jimmy Carter
abstract: In a new biography, “His Very Best,” Jonathan Alter offers an authoritative introduction to a president who has been largely neglected by biographers.

headline: ‘Kingdom of Silence’ Review: A Spotlight on Jamal Khashoggi
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Rick Rowley’s documentary looks back at the journalist’s career in all its contours and contradictions against a backdrop of changing geopolitics.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Kingdom of Silence” is debuting on Showtime two years to the day after Saudi agents killed and dismembered the Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul. Its aim is not simply to serve as a memorial, or as muckraking, but to capture Khashoggi’s career in all its contours and contradictions against a backdrop of changing geopolitics.

headline: How Bob Dylan Turned David Remnick on to Serious Reading
abstract: “He’d mention Allen Ginsberg and I’d discover ‘Howl’ for a nickel at a secondhand sale. He’d mention T.S. Eliot and I’d discover ‘The Waste Land.’”
lead_paragraph: [The Best Books of 2020: View our full list.]

headline: The White House press secretary declines to explicitly denounce white supremacy, saying the president has already done so.
abstract: Trump’s press secretary would not explicitly denounce white supremacists, saying that the president had already done so.
lead_paragraph: Kayleigh McEnany, the White House press secretary, repeatedly refused to denounce white supremacy on Thursday, insisting that President Trump had already done so and angrily accusing the media of refusing to accept his answer.

headline: In Supreme Court Fight, McSally Sees a Chance to Reboot Her Senate Campaign
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Martha McSally, the Arizona Republican, spent months trailing her opponent. By embracing Trump’s strategy to replace Ginsburg, can she close the gap?
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, people close to Senator Martha McSally, the imperiled Arizona Republican, began calling in to offer their advice.

headline: ‘On the Rocks’ Review: Daddy Dearest and His Late Bloomer
abstract: In Sofia Coppola’s latest, Rashida Jones plays a woman worried about her marriage. Who’s she gonna call? Bill Murray, a.k.a. Dad.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t surprising how effortlessly Bill Murray takes possession of Sofia Coppola’s gently comic “On the Rocks” — though this hijacking may be more of a sly directorial surrender. Casting Murray is a surefire way to win over an audience. It also means yielding at least part of the movie to him, which is what happens here. He plays a bigger-than-life sybarite whose daughter enlists him to help with her marital woes. If that sounds like a dubious idea for a grown child, it’s also a playful conceptual gambit for a director whose father, Francis Ford Coppola, casts his own long shadow.

headline: Amy Coney Barrett signed an ad in 2006 urging overturning the ‘barbaric legacy’ of Roe v. Wade.
abstract: Judge Amy Coney Barrett, President Trump’s nominee to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s seat on the Supreme Court, signed a newspaper ad in 2006 that supported overturning Roe v. Wade, the landmark decision establishing the right to abortion.
lead_paragraph: Judge Amy Coney Barrett, President Trump’s nominee to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s seat on the Supreme Court, signed a newspaper ad in 2006 that supported overturning Roe v. Wade, the landmark decision establishing the right to abortion.

headline: Verne Edquist, Virtuoso Piano Tuner, Is Dead at 89
abstract: Mr. Edquist ministered to Glenn Gould’s favorite piano, heard on dozens of recordings. The two men’s exacting approaches were well matched.
lead_paragraph: As a piano tuner, Verne Edquist spent his career tweaking the infinitely complicated mechanical actions under the lids of pianos in Toronto, pricking hammers with needles to give the sound different characteristics and adjusting tiny parts with names most pianists do not know — wippens, agraffes, knuckles and backchecks.

headline: An Uber Wage Experiment Worked
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Minimum Wage', 'Smartphones']
abstract: New York shows that Uber drivers can have higher wages without triggering an Armageddon.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: House Democrats pushed through an aid package with little chance of becoming law.
abstract: House Democrats on Thursday pushed through a $2.2 trillion stimulus plan that would provide aid to families, schools, restaurants, businesses and airline workers, advancing a wish list with little chance of becoming law.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats on Thursday pushed through a $2.2 trillion stimulus plan that would provide aid to families, schools, restaurants, businesses and airline workers, advancing a wish list with little chance of becoming law.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | 2020 U.S. Census
abstract: How many residents in each state might be undercounted in the 2020 census? And why does it matter if people remain uncounted?
lead_paragraph: These graphs, showing the projected share of uncounted addresses for the 2020 United States census as of Sept. 30, appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com.

headline: David Hockney: A Life in Drawing
abstract: The British artist’s new show at the Morgan Library & Museum derives its poignant power from its focus on loved ones and the complex nature of relationships.
lead_paragraph: Whether we’re related by blood or not, our loved ones have been very much with us these last several months. Some have been physically with us, at our elbows, sheltering at home, strengthening and sometimes straining the ties that bind. Or they are with us in absentia, in yearning, across great distances, sometimes oceans. Others are no longer among the living; their absences may have been caused by the current pandemic, leaving a fresh painful void and the suspicion that they died in vain.

headline: The Sun Pushed the Limits of Winning, Losing and Playing in Pain
abstract: Connecticut bounced back from a dreadful start to make a deep postseason run, despite injuries and a missing star.
lead_paragraph: The pain of defeat, of a season’s abrupt end, was still raw when Curt Miller emerged from the Connecticut Sun locker room late Tuesday.

headline: ‘The Keeper’ Review: Accepting an Enemy as a Teammate
abstract: A former member of the Hitler Youth who fought for the Nazis in World War II became a soccer star in England.
lead_paragraph: “The Keeper” is inspired by the true story of Bert Trautmann, a German who during World War II served as an ardent member of the Hitler Youth and later of the Luftwaffe. Then after the war he played soccer in England, as a goalkeeper for Manchester City. His presence on the team, which hired him in 1949, inspired protests, although a Manchester rabbi urged against holding the Nazis’ crimes against Trautmann individually, and fans eventually accepted him as a star player (particularly after he continued playing with what turned out to be a broken neck when Manchester City won the Football Association Cup in 1956).

headline: Help for the jobless has also been a bonanza for criminals.
abstract: The unemployment insurance system — the main artery for delivering financial assistance to laid-off workers — has been besieged during the coronavirus crisis by fraud schemes aimed at bilking the government out of hundreds of millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: The unemployment insurance system — the main artery for delivering financial assistance to laid-off workers — has been besieged during the coronavirus crisis by fraud schemes aimed at bilking the government out of hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: Companies Ditch Plans for Rapid Coronavirus Spit Tests at Home
abstract: You won’t be buying a rapid spit test anytime soon. But nose-swab versions might be on the way.
lead_paragraph: For months, public health experts have been eagerly watching the companies developing spit tests for the coronavirus that could be used at home, producing results in a matter of minutes.

headline: ‘The Good Lord Bird’ Review: The Necessity of John Brown
abstract: Ethan Hawke plays the wild-eyed abolitionist in Showtime’s adaptation of the award-winning novel by James McBride.
lead_paragraph: “The Good Lord Bird” has not received what you could call kid-glove treatment from Showtime. It was announced for Feb. 16 but pulled, then rescheduled for Aug. 9 and pulled again. It will finally premiere, without much fanfare, this Sunday. It’s curious treatment for a prestige mini-series based on a National Book Award-winning novel that was spearheaded by and stars one of America’s most accomplished actors.

headline: Membership of Anti-Mask Facebook Groups Jumps Sharply

headline: Fires and Storms Push Demand for Emergency Shelter to a New High
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Wildfires', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: The Red Cross has provided more nights of shelter to Americans this year than at any point on record, a sign of the widening human toll of climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A year already filled with historic wildfires and hurricanes can now claim another dubious distinction: Americans have spent far more time in emergency housing than in any year during the past decade, smashing 2017’s full-year record with three months left to go.

headline: Glass Fire Burns in California as Winds Cause Concern
abstract: Forecasters and fire officials warned that strong, dry gusts, known as Diablo winds, could worsen the Glass Fire. The fire has burned more than 50,000 acres in California’s Napa and Sonoma Counties.
lead_paragraph: Forecasters and fire officials warned that strong, dry gusts, known as Diablo winds, could worsen the Glass Fire. The fire has burned more than 50,000 acres in California’s Napa and Sonoma Counties.

headline: 7 Things to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Music', 'Theater', 'Dancing', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Salzburg Festival', 'Brooklyn Book Festival']
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually or in person in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Live theater has returned to Manhattan, though no seats are available. In “Voyeur: The Windows of Toulouse-Lautrec,” actors from Bated Breath Theater Company will lead eight-person audiences on a walking tour of the West Village. That neighborhood will double for 19th-century Montmartre, the quarter where the artist Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec spent some of his final syphilitic months. The show, conceived and directed by Mara Lieberman with puppet design by James Ortiz, takes place mostly outdoors with one brief foray inside. As audiences wander the Village’s wide and narrow byways, masked performers emerge from sidewalk and stoop, conjuring the cabarets and cafes of Bohemian Paris. Through windows, spectators can peek into Toulouse-Lautrec’s aperitif-fueled dreams.

headline: Gas Tax Spikes in N.J. Because of Pandemic’s Impact
keywords: ['Gasoline Tax (US)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Politics and Government', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Taxes on gasoline and diesel increased by 9.3 cents a gallon on Thursday in a state once known for bargain fuel. The increase came a month after tolls on major roadways also went up.
lead_paragraph: Motorists in New Jersey began reaching deeper into their wallets on Thursday to fill their gas tanks as the state’s fuel tax rose by more than 9 cents a gallon to the nation’s fourth-highest rate — a spike linked to a steep decline in traffic during the pandemic.

lead_paragraph: Loath to be seen profiting from the economic disaster caused by the coronavirus, the nation’s biggest banks were quick to pledge that they would donate to charity any money earned from helping deliver the government’s signature small-business relief plan.

abstract: These male monkeys lived longer if they socialized with females, with or without benefits.
lead_paragraph: In the shadow of Mount Kilimanjaro, baboons live out their daily dramas. They tussle, they mate, they care for their young. Some are loners and others have lots of friends.

Below is our regularly updated guide to the must-see docs currently on Netflix, subdivided by genre. (Note: Netflix sometimes removes titles without notice.)

lead_paragraph: White actors, writers and directors still dominate Broadway stages, according to an annual report released on Wednesday by the Asian American Performers Action Coalition in partnership with the American Theater Wing.

headline: Please Let Me Terrify Some Kids on Halloween
abstract: A socially distanced dad hopes that frightening children isn’t a thing of the past.
lead_paragraph: I have always loved the holidays. All holidays. I’m a quarter Christmas elf on my mother’s side, and Thanksgiving at my house has topped out as high as 70 guests. The Easter Bunny always appears in spring, as do sparklers in July. If it were legal, I’d rent a woodchuck for Groundhog Day.

headline: For French Open Contenders, Serving Is Mental. So Stop Thinking So Much.
abstract: Some of the best players in the world have struggled with one of the most basic shots in tennis at the French Open.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Raffaella Reggi rose to 13th in the world in women’s tennis in the late 1980s despite a serve so balky she once recorded 28 double faults in a match in Rome. With the shrill voices of fans pleading with her to use an underhand motion still ringing in her ears, Reggi said she walked into the press room afterward and professed, “I have no idea how to serve.”

headline: How California’s Diablo Winds Could Worsen Wildfires
abstract: Strong, gusty winds could hamper firefighting efforts by fanning flames that have already destroyed tens of thousands of acres in the northern part of the state.
lead_paragraph: Millions of acres in California have already burned during this year’s California wildfire season. But forecasters say that hot, dry air known as Diablo winds in portions of Northern California could make fires even more destructive.

lead_paragraph: American authorities brought criminal charges on Thursday against the owners of one of the world’s biggest cryptocurrency trading exchanges, BitMEX, accusing them of allowing the Hong Kong-based company to launder money and engage in other illegal transactions.

headline: Stanley McChrystal, a Top General Fired Over Insults to Biden, Says He’ll Vote for Him
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Endorsements']
abstract: Fired after an article portrayed him and senior aides as disrespectful of Obama administration officials, General McChrystal added a coda to the story: He endorsed Joe Biden to be the next commander in chief.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the day it was published in the summer of 2010, the Rolling Stone article electrified Washington in a way that almost seems quaint by today’s news standards: The commander of American troops in Afghanistan, Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, and his aides were quoted privately mocking several government officials. One McChrystal aide referred to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. using the phrase “bite me.”

abstract: When was the last time you cried? Could we all benefit from shedding tears more often?

headline: John Turner, Briefly Its Leader but Long a Force in Canada, Dies at 91
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: He carried out Liberal Party reforms in top cabinet posts but was ousted as prime minister after just 79 days. He later led the opposition to free-trade deals with the U.S.
lead_paragraph: John Turner, a Canadian politician who introduced major reforms to Canadian law, fleetingly served as prime minister and then rose again to prominence by leading the opposition to a free trade deal with the United States, died on Sept. 19 at his home in Toronto. He was 91.

headline: Airlines, Facing a Painfully Slow Recovery, Begin Furloughing Thousands
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: With few people traveling and lawmakers deadlocked on a stimulus package, American Airlines and United Airlines are cutting more than 30,000 jobs.
lead_paragraph: When Congress gave passenger airlines a $50 billion bailout in March, industry executives hoped the aid would tide them over until the fall, when more people might be traveling and a vaccine might be closer at hand. Several months later, that hopeful future remains extremely murky.

headline: From Geoffrey Chadsey, a Visual Diary of the Last Days of Summer
abstract: Known for his riveting portraits of fictional subjects, the artist shares snapshots of some of the people he is closest to in life, and of an idyllic trip to Vermont.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-based artist Geoffrey Chadsey is known for his meticulous water-soluble-pencil-and-crayon drawings on mylar of unnerving figures in various states of undress. They bare themselves while “kind of glaring at you,” the artist, 53, says of his invented subjects, whom he frequently bestows with ambiguous forms and states of mind — a portrait might feature a hairy chest and curvy hips, a ghostly set of extra limbs, or a fanny pack and antlers. Currently, Chadsey is working on a new series for a 2021 show at Jack Shainman Gallery in New York and thinking more than ever about how an exposed body can be “monstrous, clownish and, at the same time, really touching.”

headline: 100,000 New Mail-In Ballots Go Out, but N.Y. Voters Are Now Wary
abstract: The mishap in absentee ballots in Brooklyn raises questions about the ability of the Board of Elections to handle a pandemic-era presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Two days after officials said that as many as 100,000 voters had received faulty absentee ballots in Brooklyn, it remained unclear how many people had actually been affected, and confused voters said they now distrusted the process.

headline: Trump Virtually Cuts Off Refugees as He Unleashes a Tirade on Immigrants
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: The Trump administration said it would lower the annual cap on refugees further into rock-bottom record territory as President Trump pursues pre-election xenophobic attacks.
