headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: It never dawned on me at the start of this pandemic, when everybody was raising their drawbridges and lowering their blinds to hunker down solo in quarantine, that I might make new friends in the midst of it all. But as the days grew longer and I took my dog on increasingly roundabout walks through our neighborhood, people emerged: children first, wanting to pet Whimsy or throw his ball, and then their parents behind them, chatting at an epidemiologically safe distance about sports or school or working from home. Or books! Some of my neighbors are real readers, it turns out, and books — what we’re reading, what we recommend — can provide a reliable source of social connection even in a time of social distancing.

headline: Lebanon and Israel, Officially Enemies, Agree to Talks on Sea Border
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Natural Gas', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States International Relations', 'Territorial Disputes']
abstract: The negotiations will be their first on nonsecurity issues in three decades but officials do not expect them to lead to peace talks.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon and Israel have agreed to open their first negotiations on nonsecurity issues in three decades, a rare if limited breakthrough between hostile neighbors that are technically at war and have no formal diplomatic relations.

headline: Biden breaks the $365 million fund-raising record that he set in August.

headline: Renée C. Fox, Founding Figure of Medical Sociology, Dies at 92
abstract: She is credited with helping to create the field of bioethics and applying the methods of sociology to medical care.
lead_paragraph: Renée C. Fox, a leading scholar of medical sociology, a field she was instrumental in creating in an era when women had a difficult time being heard in academia, died on Sept. 23 at a hospice center in Philadelphia. She was 92.

headline: ‘This Is An Amazing Moment,’ Says N.Y.C. Mayor on Schools Reopening

headline: Yuri Orlov, Bold Champion of Soviet Dissidents, Dies at 96
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Cold War Era', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: A prominent physicist, he founded the Moscow Helsinki Group to hold his government accountable after serving time in prison and in exile.
lead_paragraph: Yuri Orlov, a Soviet physicist and disillusioned former Communist who publicly held Moscow accountable for failing to protect the rights of dissidents and was imprisoned and exiled for his own apostasy, died on Sunday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 96.

headline: Grace Meo, Skilled Seamstress and Serious Sinatra Fan, Dies at 93
abstract: Ms. Meo could sew anything, and she loved her family, but her heart belonged to the Voice. She died of Covid-19.

headline: Wisconsin Is Frazzled by Surging Virus Cases and Growing Campaign Frenzy
abstract: The state, up for grabs in the presidential election, has become a coronavirus hot spot. “It’s too late” to solve, one mayor says.
lead_paragraph: OSHKOSH, Wis. — Steve VanderLoop, 64, heard that several of his co-workers at a manufacturing plant in Wisconsin had fallen ill from Covid-19. Then there was his brother-in-law’s entire family in nearby Washington County. A good friend in Appleton, up the shore of Lake Winnebago. And last week, the gut punch: Mr. VanderLoop’s 96-year-old mother learned she had the virus.

For good reasons, a tone of heightened alarm has become the default setting across the media.

headline: Judge Overturns Murder Conviction, Citing ‘Racial Animus’ in Prosecutors’ Emails
keywords: ['ARSON', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Asian-Americans', 'Discrimination', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Prosecutorial Misconduct']
abstract: New evidence emerged in the case of Frances Choy, who spent half of her life imprisoned in Massachusetts for a fire that killed her parents.
lead_paragraph: Frances Choy was 17 when she was arrested in 2003 and charged with pouring gasoline around her home in Brockton, Mass., and setting a fire that killed her parents. After two trials ended in hung juries, she was convicted on murder and arson charges in 2011 and sentenced to life in prison without parole.

headline: The Oakland A’s Conquer One Demon. Could the Astros Be Next?

headline: 30 Years After Reunification, Old German-German Border Is a Green Oasis
keywords: ['Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves', 'Land Use Policies', 'Berlin Wall', 'Cold War Era', 'Birdwatching']
abstract: Crossing the militarized border that split Germany into east and west once meant risking death. Now? It’s a literal walk in the park.
lead_paragraph: MITWITZ, Germany — Two men, one riding a bicycle, the other wearing binoculars, met in a field in the middle of Germany on a recent afternoon. Both 61, they started arguing politely, the way strangers do, about where exactly the border between East and West Germany had been. Soon, it became clear that both had good reason to think they were right.

abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: ONE GIANT LEAP: The Impossible Mission That Flew Us to the Moon, by Charles Fishman. (Simon & Schuster, 512 pp., $18.) Fishman argues that the race to the moon ushered in not the Space Age but the Digital Age (in particular integrated circuits and real-time computing), which made technology “a force in the everyday lives of consumers.” Our reviewer, Jill Lepore, offered a counterargument: “My country went to the moon and all I got was this lousy surveillance state.”

headline: The Proposal Was a Walk in the Park (the Second Time Around)
abstract: Caroline Gottlieb and David Virenius got engaged in Central Park, a day later than intended after a foiled first attempt.
lead_paragraph: On July 2, all Caroline Mackenzie Gottlieb wanted to do was sit inside her cool, air-conditioned apartment. Ms. Gottlieb, 36, is a features producer for NBC’s “Today” show in Manhattan, and had spent the last few days shooting on location in Charlottesville, Va. It had been hot and humid in Virginia and it was hot and humid when she got back to her Manhattan apartment, where she lived with her boyfriend, David James Virenius. Mr. Virenius, who is a director of programmatic advertising for  the Weather Channel in Manhattan, had other plans.

headline: ‘Always Up for an Adventure’ and He Passed Her Tests

headline: The Grandmother Trees
abstract: We think of humans as destroyers of the Amazon, but for centuries Indigenous people have tended to this landscape.
lead_paragraph: FLORIANÓPOLIS, Brazil — The samaúma tree is one of the largest and tallest of the forest. Its canopy flourishes in the sky and its roots embrace everything around them. Local people call it the “grandmother tree,” and ethnographic researchers have found that Indigenous peoples used to bury their dead in urns among those roots. They also used the tree to communicate with others in the forest: When you hit the roots, the noise reverberates through the trunk like a drum.

headline: Can Our Culture Survive Climate Change?
abstract: My daughter is named Y’Wara, which means the power that forces water downstream. Like the river, she will have to be strong.
lead_paragraph: MARANHÃO STATE, Brazil — My daughter, Y’Wara, is 15. Last September she became a woman in the Menina Moça ceremony, which our tribe, the Guajajara, has performed for centuries.

headline: N.Y.C.’s School Testing Plan May Miss Large Outbreaks, Study Finds
abstract: Half of New York’s students should be tested every two weeks, researchers estimate. Officials plan to test only 10 to 20 percent of each school every month.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s ambitious plan to randomly test students for coronavirus in each of its 1,800 public schools will likely be insufficient to catch outbreaks before they spread beyond a handful of students, according to new estimates of the spread of infections in city schools.

headline: Could the Amazon Save Your Life?
abstract: Scientists are looking at the medicinal potential of plants and animals in the region’s vast tropical forests.
lead_paragraph: Western medicine is the most successful system of healing ever devised and is becoming more so as technology improves and synthetic medicines proliferate. But Mother Nature has been synthesizing weird and wonderful medicinal chemicals for over three billion years, many of which chemists could not predict or devise in their wildest dreams.

headline: Welcome to the Thunderdome
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Debates (Political)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Trump Tax Returns', 'Elections, Senate', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Editorial board member Michelle Cottle joins the podcast to talk disastrous debates, Amy Coney Barrett and Trump’s taxes
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to “The Argument” from your mobile device:

headline: He Won the Argument and Her Heart
abstract: Courtney Stone and Sean Mirski, who met through the dating app Hinge, were married by Supreme Court Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr.
lead_paragraph: Charming is probably not a word most people would use to describe a legal argument. But Sean Mirski’s was just that, when he set out to persuade Courtney Stone, in 2018, that she should forego her inclination to eschew booze for the month of January. He wanted her instead to have a glass of red wine with him on one of their early dates.

headline: After a Royal Wedding, Enter Her ‘Dutch Prince Charming’
abstract: Susanne Bliss Stansell introduced Jordi van den Heiligenberg to thin-crust Domino’s Pizza. He introduced her to Pepernoten cookies.
lead_paragraph: Susanne Bliss Stansell excitedly recapped the festivities of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle’s wedding in May 2018 to Jordi van den Heiligenberg during their first date at Nix, a vegetarian restaurant in Manhattan’s Greenwich Village neighborhood.

headline: Whose Islam? The New Battle for Afghanistan
abstract: Finding common ground on the role of Islam is the most decisive task in the peace talks between the Taliban and the Afghan government.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As the major warring parties in Afghanistan sit down for peace talks in Doha, Qatar, an old, unresolved debate is emerging as the central question: What should be the role of Islam in Afghanistan? A humid seaside resort on the Persian Gulf, where the delegates are gathered, has become the unlikely venue for a search for answers acceptable to most Afghans.

headline: How a #BlackLivesMatter Leader Spends His Sundays
keywords: ['Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: For Hawk Newsome, a co-founder of a movement in New York, the activism does not let up on the weekend.
lead_paragraph: At over 6 feet tall and 300 pounds, often wearing a bulletproof vest beneath his shirt and puffing on a Padron 1964 Anniversary Series cigar, Hawk Newsome is hard to miss.

headline: Will Mormon Women Sink Trump in Arizona?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Women and Girls', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: There are a lot of Latter-day Saints women in the state, and they don’t seem very keen on the president.
lead_paragraph: President Trump may have a problem in the American Southwest. And contrary to popular belief, it is not just liberal California exiles fleeing to states like Nevada and Arizona or a high number of Democratic-leaning Latino voters in those states.

headline: The Amazon Was Sick. Now It’s Sicker.
abstract: Peru’s government did far too little to protect its Indigenous people from the coronavirus, just as it has failed to protect them from the health threats of environmental contamination.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — When he was a boy in the late ’80s, Elmer Hualinga would go to the nearby ravine to catch some odd fish. He’d see them floating on the water, motionless, covered in a slimy black substance. That didn’t seem to concern the elders of Nueva Andoas, Mr. Hualinga’s Quichua community in the Peruvian Amazon near the border with Ecuador. They would yank the creatures from the dark water, rinse them off and take them home to cook.

headline: For Those We Can’t Always Protect
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Turtles and Tortoises', 'Hit-and-Run Drivers', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting']
abstract: In the aftermath of an accident, a reminder of how lucky we all are to live another day.
lead_paragraph: When my daughter opened the front door after a socially distanced walk with a friend, she called out, “Mom, I need to tell you something you really won’t like.”

headline: Apps Will Get You Paid Early, for a Price
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Payday Loans', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Personal Finances', 'Mobile Applications', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments']
abstract: Pay-advance apps have been downloaded millions of times, and more employers are offering them as benefits to workers who need cash.
lead_paragraph: Americans have become accustomed to summoning just about anything on demand, from groceries to car rides. Now it’s just as easy to get paid when you want.

headline: ‘Everything Crossed Over’: Michael Clark’s Cheeky World of Dance
abstract: The British choreographer and provocateur, now 58, is the subject of an eye-popping exhibition at the Barbican Art Gallery.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Dancer, choreographer, ex-heroin addict, prodigal son, perfectionist, art-world darling, club-world star: Michael Clark was for a long time the enfant terrible of British dance. Today he is 58 and the subject of a comprehensive exhibition, “Michael Clark: Cosmic Dancer,” at the Barbican Art Gallery that surveys his career and extensive collaborations.

headline: We Know How to Stop the Fires
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Indigenous People', 'Politics and Government', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The world can learn from Indigenous people’s collective and practical response to climate change.
lead_paragraph: “There’s a lot of land for few Indians.” So goes the tired creed, recently revived by President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil. And yet those “few Indians,” representing 305 Indigenous groups and speaking 274 languages, have accomplished what governments have tried and failed to do for decades: control deforestation in more than 440,000 square miles of Amazon forests.

headline: How Should Schools Hold Students Accountable for Hurting Others?
abstract: When there are incidents of racism, sexism, anti-Semitism, homophobia or just plain bullying in a school community, what should a school do? What does justice look like?
lead_paragraph: Are there ever incidents of racism, hate or bullying at your school? Do students ever use racial slurs or homophobic language, for example? How does your school deal with these situations? Is the response mostly punitive — in other words, does the school generally suspend, or even expel, offending students as punishment? Or is there ever any attempt to create dialogue between victims and offenders, to try to repair harm that was done and to facilitate healing? How effective do you think your school’s response is?

headline: I Traveled to 52 Places. Then I Discovered N.Y. on My Bike.
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Road Trips', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: After a nonstop year journeying to far-flung destinations for The Times, a well-traveled writer learns to love the local attractions — and the spaces in between.
lead_paragraph: I was one of the lucky ones. I already had a bicycle when the coronavirus paralyzed New York City and my world shrunk to the size of a one-bedroom apartment in Harlem. As I dusted off my three-year-old bike, I heard countless stories from friends trying, and failing, to find bikes of their own. One went to Philadelphia to buy one that fit him. Another cobbled together a Frankenbike from three rusty carcasses in her parents’ garage.

headline: They Keep An Iconic Roller Coaster Ready for When Crowds Return
abstract: Two workers at Coney Island’s Luna Park spend their days maintaining the Cyclone. But after a year of being closed, it’s unclear when the park will be able to reopen.
lead_paragraph: Two workers at Coney Island’s Luna Park spend their days maintaining the Cyclone. But after a year of being closed, it’s unclear when the park will be able to reopen.

headline: Are Underhand Serves Underhanded? Tennis Is Opening Up to the Crafty Tactic
abstract: Players concede that the serve can be a good tactic against players who stand far, far back from the baseline. And they know when opponents are trying to show them up.
lead_paragraph: Neither the pioneer nor the present-day popularizer of the underhand serve has been in Paris this year during the French Open.

headline: Many Rivers, Too Many Dams
abstract: And more are on the way in the Amazon, where they have disrupted the environment and Indigenous peoples.
lead_paragraph: Where rivers run free, dams are intruders.

headline: Three Poets on the Amazon
abstract: “On the tree of life, the bird that sang the four hundred voices of blue faded into the flames.”
lead_paragraph: “On the tree of life, the bird that sang the four hundred voices of blue faded into the flames.”

headline: News Quiz: Trump’s Taxes, the Presidential Debate, Nxivm
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: Four Takeaways from Rihanna’s New Lingerie Spectacle
keywords: ['Lingerie and Underwear', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'your-feed-fashion', 'Models (Professional)']
abstract: Savage x Fenty is back for another body-positive bash — now with men’s underwear and a meditation on sexuality.
lead_paragraph: There are no real parties. Concerts? Canceled. Fashion shows are either digital or distanced. So who would dare throw a party-concert-fashion show in the middle — or the beginning or the end — of this? Rihanna, obviously.

headline: An Evangelical Conquista in Amazonia
abstract: This isn’t the first time missionaries have risked spreading disease alongside the word of god.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus spread across the Amazon in March, the evangelical organization New Tribes Mission of Brazil was preparing for a mission to the Javari Valley — a remote region near the border with Peru that is home to one of the world’s largest concentration of Indigenous peoples.

headline: ‘Ridicule’: The French Reaction to ‘Emily in Paris’
abstract: Darren Star’s latest serial goes down like sour wine for actual Parisians.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The old story of the American ingénue who moves to Paris, succumbs to the city’s sensual pleasures (usually by way of a French lover) and masters its hardened customs (never smiling at strangers) is a perennial crowd-pleaser — if the crowds are American, that is.

headline: Football’s Return Is Fodder for Mask Debates and an Enforcement Dilemma
abstract: Leaders in the N.F.L. and in college sports have mandated masks for most people on the sidelines. What happens when the rules are not followed?
lead_paragraph: It was the splashy Southeastern Conference debut that Mississippi State wanted from Coach Mike Leach: His Bulldogs swept into Louisiana State’s Tiger Stadium, passed for 623 yards and conquered the reigning national champion.

headline: No One Is Stopping the Child Sex Abusers
abstract: Three factors contribute to this crisis of child abuse: impunity, poverty and a deeply rooted culture of male domination.
lead_paragraph: PÁRA STATE, Brazil — It’s been nearly five years since J.S. de Brito began a legal battle to protect his daughter, who was sexually abused when she was only 2, and to prosecute the man he suspects committed the crime — the child’s maternal grandfather. Despite medical evidence confirming that the child was molested, the case has stalled. The justice system in this region of the Brazilian Amazon has allowed the possible abuser to continue to have almost daily contact with his victim.

headline: The I.R.S. Is Outgunned
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Trump Tax Returns', 'Tax Evasion', 'Income Inequality', 'Corporate Taxes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The agency doesn’t have the resources to battle the tax lawyers of the ultrarich. Trump’s returns are just one example of how little the wealthy pay.
lead_paragraph: The president of the United States paid less in federal taxes than all but the poorest Americans the year he was elected. This is in large part because he lost more money than nearly anybody else in this country for years, a troubling fact given his promise to “run America like his business.”

headline: They Needed a Place to Marry. Suddenly Their Ship Came In.
abstract: Max Krauss and Emily Young wed aboard the U.S.S. Baylander, which happened to be docked outside his parents’ Harlem home at just the right time.
lead_paragraph: Max Krauss, a social worker by day and a guitarist by night, left his home in Park Slope, Brooklyn, one morning in mid-February 2018, and headed to his parents’ Manhattan apartment, perched high above the Hudson River on West 125th Street, where he grew up.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Awe Walks, Pets and Intermittent Fasting
keywords: ['Fasting', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Cats', 'Dogs', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Medicine and Health', 'Salt', 'Fatigue', 'Bariatric Surgery', 'Weight', 'Heart']
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Why New York Comedy Has Gone Underground (and Onto the Rooftops)
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Unlike live music, stand-up is still not allowed where food and drinks are sold. Comedians are doing pop-up gigs wherever they can.
lead_paragraph: No one expected so many people to come to Michael Che’s impromptu comedy show in June. The Saturday Night Live performer did little to publicize it, except mention it on Instagram the day before.

headline: Tom Who? Cam Newton Is Moving New England Past Brady
abstract: Cam Newton is winning over New England, a racially complicated area accustomed to Hall of Fame quarterback play. All it’s taken are a couple wins, endorsements from his taciturn coach and a whole lot of charm.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Monday morning, Alex Sarkis entered the athletic apparel store next to Gillette Stadium, home to the New England Patriots, and bypassed two racks of Tom Brady jerseys. Sarkis, 21, a lifelong Patriots fan, had driven 90 minutes from his home in western Massachusetts to Foxborough to buy the hottest-selling sports item in New England: the distinctive No. 1 jersey of the Patriots’ new quarterback, Cam Newton.

headline: After Wildfires Stop Burning, a Danger in the Drinking Water
keywords: ['Plumbing', 'Wildfires', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Water Pollution', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Research', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Experts are warning that existing water safety rules are not suitable to a world where wildfires destroy more residential areas than in the past.
lead_paragraph: Two months after a wildfire burned through Paradise, Calif., in 2018, Kevin Phillips, then a manager for town’s irrigation district, walked from one destroyed home to another.

headline: Democrats Mount an All-Out Effort to Get Detroit to Vote
abstract: Urgently trying to avoid a repeat of 2016, when Donald Trump won Michigan by a razor-thin margin, Democrats have been focusing on driving up turnout in a city where tens of thousands didn’t vote the last time.
lead_paragraph: [Watch live VP debate and analysis.]

headline: Leaf Peeping Is Not Canceled: 6 Drives and Hikes to Try This Fall
keywords: ['Autumn (Season)', 'Road Trips', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: From the Berkshires to the Rockies, the vibrant colors of fall are popping, and nothing, not even a pandemic, can stop them. Six writers in six states reveal their favorite drives and hikes.
lead_paragraph: A leafy drive in Nashville, hikes in the Appalachian wilderness, a spin on a scenic Colorado byway: There are many ways to savor autumn while being mindful of pandemic travel precautions. Below are six fall outings in Massachusetts, Ohio, West Virginia, Maine, Tennessee and Colorado, replete with apple cider doughnuts, a highway ghost and sightings of otters, beavers and wild turkeys.

headline: Six Months in the Life of a Locked-Down Theater
abstract: Britain’s National Theater hopes to reopen in October after being closed for more than 200 days. But even with the shutters down, it’s been an eventful and emotional time for its staff.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s National Theater is set to reopen on Oct. 21 — 219 days after it was shuttered with just minutes notice because of the coronavirus. But in the past six months, it hasn’t really closed.

headline: Why ‘Stand Back and Stand By’ Should Set Off Alarm Bells
keywords: ['Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Whites', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: America’s failure to deal with the white power movement.
lead_paragraph: When asked to condemn “white supremacists and militia groups” during his debate with Joe Biden this week, President Trump gave a largely garbled answer, asking for definitions and caveats, attempting to misdirect attention to leftist violence, and repeatedly interrupting the moderator. One part of his answer, however, was crystal clear. “Proud Boys, stand back and stand by,” Mr. Trump said.

headline: Peace Corps Faces Questions Over Another Volunteer Death
keywords: ['Volunteers and Community Service', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Malaria']
abstract: A 24-year-old volunteer died of undiagnosed malaria on the island nation of Comoros. It was one of at least three deaths since 2009 that have been linked to mistakes by Peace Corps doctors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Peace Corps, which suspended all operations for the first time in its history as the novel coronavirus raced around the globe, is facing renewed questions about the quality of its medical care — in particular, after the death of a 24-year-old volunteer from undiagnosed malaria — as it prepares to send volunteers back into the field.

headline: Amazon 4.0. How to Reinvent the Rainforest
abstract: It took tens of millions of years for tropical rainforests to evolve. It may take us just a few decades to destroy them, unless we change course.
lead_paragraph: Rainforests are unique ecosystems of immense complexity that nurture an incredible diversity of plants, animals and micro-organisms. Bulldozers and chain saws don’t care about that.

headline: Breonna Taylor Grand Jury Audio Reveals Conflicting Accounts of Fatal Raid
keywords: ['Jury System', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The 15 hours of recordings include interviews with witnesses, audio of 911 calls and other evidence — but few statements from prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Two very different accounts emerged on Friday from either side of an apartment door in Louisville, the one that police officers knocked off its hinges in March as they delivered a search warrant at the home of Breonna Taylor.

headline: Captain Chain Saw’s Delusion
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Land Use Policies', 'Politics and Government', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: The Amazon was never a “land without men.”
lead_paragraph: Amid political strife and smoke visible from space, the future of the Amazon has rarely been so hazy. Environmentalists see a vanishing rainforest of global consequence. Indigenous leaders see an ancestral home still being exploited by settlers after 500 years of genocidal violence. Brazil’s president, Jair Bolsonaro, sees valuable acreage wasted by “cave men” and Marxists.

headline: Their Matchmaker Was Right
abstract: Three years ago, a mutual friend introduced Mavis Baah, a public relations manager, and Jay Jones, a member of the Virginia House of Delegates.
lead_paragraph: When they were asked to summarize their relationship in one word, Mavis Baah and Jay Jones, who are both 32 and working in Norfolk, Va., blurted out the same word at the exact same time: “partnership.”

headline: It Was Love at First Follow
abstract: Instagram brought them together but a continent separated them, so Dr. Sharath Puttichanda and Sundeep Dosanjh fell in love well before they met in person.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Sharath Puttichanda was an emergency-medicine psychiatrist at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence in December 2019 when he stumbled across Sundeep Dosanjh’s Instagram posts from Machu Picchu.

headline: Romantic Vibes From the Start
abstract: Amanda Herrera and Olujimi Akili Tommasino felt an immediate attraction after meeting in 2010, but didn’t begin dating until six years later.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Herrera and Olujimi Akili Tommasino met through a mutual friend, Kyrah Daniels, on a move-in day at Harvard.

headline: Cycling Helped Our 52 Places Traveler Fall Back in Love with N.Y.
abstract: Here's what he appreciates about leaving behind flights and taking up biking.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: In Pictures: Trump’s Busy Week Before Testing Positive
abstract: President Trump revealed early Friday  that he had tested positive for coronavirus. Over the past week, he interacted with scores of staff members, donors and supporters.
lead_paragraph: President Trump revealed early Friday morning that he and the first lady, Melania Trump, had tested positive for the coronavirus. It is not clear when or how Mr. Trump contracted the virus. But over the past week, he interacted with scores of staff members, donors and supporters. Photographers for The New York Times captured some of those meetings.

headline: What Made This a Record Fire Season? It Started With Lightning
abstract: An unusual confluence of weather conditions sent nearly 14,000 bolts of lightning into the dry, hot forests of Northern California in August. But that was only the beginning.
lead_paragraph: An unusual confluence of weather conditions sent nearly 14,000 bolts of lightning into the dry, hot forests of Northern California in August. But that was only the beginning.

headline: The Field: The Fight for Voting Rights in Florida
abstract: A 2018 ballot initiative in the swing state was supposed to extend the franchise to 1.5 million former felons. A Republican policy and a lack of information threaten to keep these voters from the polls.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.

headline: Leaders Who Caught Virus: Boris Johnson, Jair Bolsonaro and Now Trump
abstract: Mr. Johnson, Britain’s prime minister, was hospitalized. Mr. Bolsonaro, Brazil’s president, appeared to have a mild case. Other top officials worldwide also have been infected.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus has spread around the globe, world leaders have not been spared.

headline: A President’s Positive Test and the Year That Won’t Let Up
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Two Thousand Twenty', 'White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)']
abstract: President Trump’s health news brought on, for many, the kind of psychic doom-spiraling that has felt endemic to the era.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s pre-election turn as the world’s most famous coronavirus case is at once stunning, startling and somehow spiritually consistent with the bleaker-than-fiction course of this endless, relentless year.

headline: What happens if Trump becomes too ill to perform his duties?
abstract: In the wake of President Trump’s testing positive for the coronavirus, the White House did not immediately offer information on what the plan would be if the president became too ill to do his job.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of President Trump’s testing positive for the coronavirus, the White House did not immediately offer information on what the plan would be if the president became too ill to do his job.

headline: The 22-Year-Old Force Behind Egypt’s Growing #MeToo Movement
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', '#MeToo Movement', 'Social Media', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: In a moment of rage, Nadeen Ashraf created an Instagram page naming a man accused of being a sexual harasser. Within a week, it had 70,000 followers.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Nadeen Ashraf had a burning secret. Earlier this summer, an anonymous Instagram page that named and shamed a man accused of being a notorious sexual harasser at Egypt’s most prestigious university was causing a sensation among her friends. Unknown to them, she was running it.

headline: The Trumps Test Positive
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and his wife, Melania, have tested positive for the coronavirus, he announced in a tweet shortly before 1 a.m. Eastern today. Afterward, she added that they were “feeling good.” The White House did not say whether they were experiencing symptoms.

headline: ‘If He Doesn’t Win Ohio, It’s Over’: Trump Slips in the Heartland
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Whites', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Suburbs']
abstract: Four years ago, the president easily won Ohio by building a balanced coalition among white voters across educational lines. But his support has waned since then, particularly in the suburbs.
lead_paragraph: [Watch live VP debate and analysis.]

headline: The Pandemic Comes for the President
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)']
abstract: Donald Trump has the coronavirus. Let’s learn from that.
lead_paragraph: It’s a measure of the cynicism that has infected American politics — and, yes, me — that among my initial reactions to the news that President Trump had tested positive for the coronavirus was: Are we sure? Can we trust that? A man who so frequently and flamboyantly plays the victim, and who has been prophylactically compiling ways to explain away or dispute a projected loss to Joe Biden, is now being forced off the campaign trail, which will be a monster of an excuse.

headline: Trump Tests Positive. What Comes Next ...
abstract: Now, everything is in flux.
lead_paragraph: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.

headline: Trump Has the Coronavirus. What Risks Does He Face?
abstract: Older men have a greater chance of becoming severely ill from Covid-19, though many recover quickly. Experts say the next week will be crucial.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s announcement on Friday that he had tested positive for the coronavirus has raised many questions about what the infection could mean for the health of America’s top leader.

headline: ‘The Glorias’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Julie Taymor narrates a sequence from her film featuring Alicia Vikander and Julianne Moore.
lead_paragraph: Julie Taymor narrates a sequence from her film featuring Alicia Vikander and Julianne Moore.

headline: TV news networks quickly began live coverage of the president’s infection.
abstract: Television news networks leapt into breaking news mode early Friday morning, rousing anchors and correspondents from their beds as the nation began to absorb the news about President Trump and the first lady.
lead_paragraph: Television news networks leapt into breaking news mode early Friday morning, rousing anchors and correspondents from their beds as the nation began to absorb the news about President Trump and the first lady.

headline: Michigan charged two right-wing operatives with felonies over a voter suppression scheme.
abstract: Two right-wing political operatives were charged with felonies in connection with a robocall scheme that Michigan’s attorney general said was part of a broad voter suppression effort.
lead_paragraph: Two right-wing political operatives were charged Thursday with a series of felonies in connection with a robocall scheme that Michigan’s attorney general said was part of a broad effort intended to intimidate minority voters from casting mail-in ballots.

headline: Trump, under pressure to condemn white supremacist groups, does so briefly.
abstract: President Trump on Thursday night gave a clearer condemnation of the Proud Boys, the far-right extremist group whose members support him, after he gave them a call to “stand back and stand by” during the first presidential debate of the general election this week. Mr. Trump has stopped short of fully condemning the group since that comment, giving indirect disavowals of white supremacists when pressed by reporters since the Tuesday night debate.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Thursday night gave a clearer condemnation of the Proud Boys, the far-right extremist group whose members support him, after he gave them a call to “stand back and stand by” during the first presidential debate of the general election this week. Mr. Trump has stopped short of fully condemning the group since that comment, giving indirect disavowals of white supremacists when pressed by reporters since the Tuesday night debate.

headline: News that the president contracted the virus leaves the world shaken.
abstract: The news that President Trump and the first lady had tested positive  shook the world and sent markets tumbling.
lead_paragraph: Once again, the world shuddered at news about President Trump. This time, it wasn’t something Mr. Trump said or did, but rather the fact that he had tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: Trump’s disclosure upends the campaign in its final stretch.
abstract: President Trump’s announcement early Friday that he had contracted the coronavirus upended the presidential race in an instant.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s announcement early Friday that he had contracted the coronavirus upended the presidential race in an instant, inviting significant questions about his cavalier attitude toward the pandemic and the future of his campaign just 32 days before the election.

headline: Democrats are awash in cash as the election nears.
abstract: Money does not itself win elections. But this year Democrats might be forgiven for wishing it did.
lead_paragraph: Money does not itself win elections. But this year Democrats might be forgiven for wishing it did.

headline: A recording of Melania Trump captures her complaining in vulgar terms about Christmas decorations and mocking detained migrant children.
abstract: Melania Trump, the first lady, delivered a profanity-laced rant about White House Christmas decorations and mocked the plight of migrant children who were separated from their parents at the border, during a 2018 conversation secretly taped by her former aide and close confidante.
lead_paragraph: Melania Trump, the first lady, delivered a profanity-laced rant about White House Christmas decorations and mocked the plight of migrant children who were separated from their parents at the border, during a 2018 conversation secretly taped by her former aide and close confidante.

headline: The Florida director of a pro-Trump Latino group is the chairman of the Proud Boys.
abstract: Enrique Tarrio, the Florida state director of Latinos for Trump, a national grass-roots organization unaffiliated with the Trump campaign, is also the chairman of the Proud Boys, a far-right organization linked with white supremacy and acts of violence.
lead_paragraph: Enrique Tarrio, the Florida state director of Latinos for Trump, a national grass-roots organization unaffiliated with the Trump campaign, is also the chairman of the Proud Boys, a far-right organization linked with white supremacy and acts of violence.

headline: How Julie Taymor Brings Visual Flair to ‘The Glorias’
abstract: The director discusses a scene from her film about the life of Gloria Steinem, featuring Julianne Moore and Alicia Vikander.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: In Morocco, a Compact Apartment Filled With Over 10,000 Curios
abstract: By crowding his home to the corners with vintage furniture, antique china and collections of trinkets, a chef proves that too much is never enough.
lead_paragraph: THE ITALIAN HORTICULTURIST and writer Umberto Pasti has always been a collector, not merely of things and plants — his homes in Milan, Tangier and the Moroccan village of Rohuna are chockablock with Neolithic pottery, antique textiles and Berber pots; his gardens hold roughly 2,000 species of native and exotic flora — but also of people: the more creative and eccentric, the better.

headline: Audubon Park, From Hinterlands to Urban Density
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The ornithologist-painter John James Audubon took flight from Lower Manhattan to escape its ‘pestilential vapors.’ He landed in the picturesque woodland of the future Washington Heights, changing its landscape forever.
lead_paragraph: From 1840 to 1841, less than a decade after a cholera epidemic ravaged New York City, two daughters-in-law of John James Audubon, the wildlife painter, died of tuberculosis, the second while living with Audubon in Lower Manhattan.

headline: ‘Chad and Not Chadwick’: How the Bosemans Remember a Superstar

He and his brother used to play on a swing there and chase each other around the backyard. Between Bible studies and summer reading, it was the place where they made their fondest memories.

headline: She had income from three jobs. The pandemic took it all away.

At 2:30 p.m. on game days, she would catch a bus to Oracle Park, the Giants’ baseball stadium, where she worked as a cashier until 10:30 p.m. She also served concessions at Chase Center, home to the N.B.A.’s Golden State Warriors.

headline: When Invasive Species Become the Meal
keywords: ['Conservation of Resources', 'Wildlife Die-Offs', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Invasive Species', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: Is dining on nature’s predators an act of environmentalism — or just a new way for humans to bend the world to our will?
lead_paragraph: ON THE PLATE, the red lionfish looks benign, denuded of its grand mohawk of venomous spines, cut down into neat fillets, floured and flopped in a hot pan with white wine and capers, then brought to the table leaking butter. Its flesh is as white as a snapper’s, delicate and faintly sweet. To eat it seems more like decadence than righteousness. But the same fish is considered a menace in the Atlantic. Up to 20 inches long when fully grown and striated in cream and rust, it wobbles underwater with that dorsal mohawk and gauzy pectoral fins fanned out on either side, suggesting a feathered headdress set adrift, dreaming its way through life, until it backs its prey up against the reef and snaps. Its hunger is legend: The predator has been known to graze on more than 50 species, and its stomach can inflate to 30 times its natural size to accommodate its feasts, which sometimes equal 90 percent of its body weight.

headline: A Foosball Table That Elevates the Level of Play
abstract: Louis Vuitton’s design includes a textured leather exterior and hand-painted, aluminum-cast players.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps surprisingly for a game redolent of fraternity-house basements, foosball has a sophisticated and mysterious provenance. Referred to by the British, straightforwardly, as table football, and by the French, adorably, as le baby-foot (the term “foosball” comes from the German word for soccer), it was, by some accounts, created in the 1930s by a French automobile engineer, Lucien Rosengart. The Spanish anarchist and publisher Alejandro Finisterre also claimed to have invented futbolín while recovering from injuries sustained in the Spanish Civil War, and the Englishman Harold Searles Thornton filed a patent for a similar setup in 1923. The French fashion and leather goods company Louis Vuitton, however, is less concerned with establishing the republic’s title to le baby-foot than in designing the most aesthetically pleasing version imaginable. Offered in seven different finishes, including leathers such as the brand’s textured Epi in colors like cyan and pistachio, as well as the iconic logoed canvas pictured here, the table’s hand-painted, custom-matched aluminum-cast players are modeled on the hotel porter character from Vuitton’s 1921 advertising campaign. Foosball’s origins may not be certain, but this is: You won’t find this particular amusement in the corner of some subterranean rec room. Louis Vuitton Le Babyfoot in Monogram Canvas, $71,000, (866) 844-8866.

headline: Uncouth, Cranky and Rude: Movies in 1988 Were a Far Cry From Today
abstract: In films like “Die Hard,” “Cocktail” and “A Fish Called Wanda,” characters were loud, obscene, neurotic and mean. Now the edges are razored off.
lead_paragraph: The regular box office is back. Ordinarily, that sentence would arrive with exclamation points. But after six months of pandemic-induced nothing, the numbers are still off. Theaters are showing films but at a reduced capacity, and mine in New York City are still closed, which helps explain how, in the last weekend of August, the Top 10 movies made just $12.5 million. I would love to see “Kajillionaire,” but “in a schlep to New Jersey and maybe get sick” sort of way? As it is, I raced over there for “Tenet” a few weeks ago and left sad.

headline: A Tiffany Necklace That Transcends Time
abstract: The diamonds perched atop Elsa Peretti’s fluid gold mesh collar, which the house recently reimagined, resemble droplets of dew.
lead_paragraph: “I have the feeling of having to prove I exist … through houses and objects,” the jewelry designer Elsa Peretti once said. “I have to crystallize a form.” Peretti’s career grew out of her chance travels as a model in the late ’60s and early ’70s, when she was a muse to Helmut Newton and Halston. After stumbling upon a very tiny flower vase made of sterling silver at a flea market, which she wanted to wear as a necklace, she began sketching ideas with a silversmith in Spain. Her early creations were instinctive and macabre, inspired by animal skulls, scorpions and even X-rays of her own skeleton. In 1974, she joined Tiffany & Co. as a designer, where her sinuous and sculptural pieces — such as the Bean, Diamonds by the Yard and the Open Heart — quickly became signatures of the 1837-founded American jewelry house. That same year, Peretti traveled throughout Jaipur, India, and the city’s glittering light inspired her to begin working with mesh. Halston debuted a gold mesh bra and scarf designed by Peretti for Tiffany in his fall 1975 runway collection, which she produced on old machinery that had been used to make handbags in fine metal netting and chain mail in the early 20th century. The mesh designs were a hit: “Tiffany was swamped with calls from people dying to get a gold bra,” Peretti recalled.

abstract: Hours after his positive test for Covid-19, President Trump did not appear on a scheduled call with governors from across the country early Friday afternoon, and Vice President Mike Pence took his place on the call.
lead_paragraph: Hours after his positive test for Covid-19, President Trump did not appear on a scheduled call with governors from across the country early Friday afternoon, and Vice President Mike Pence took his place on the call.

headline: S. P. Balasubrahmanyam, Indian Singer With Huge Repertory, Dies at 74
abstract: Known as S.P.B., he sang in a number of languages and was known for his film work. He died of complications of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

abstract: Positive tests inch up in New York City as Cuomo calls for fines for lax enforcement.
lead_paragraph: With New York City watching to see if a recent uptick in coronavirus cases could trigger another wave of shutdowns and closings, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Friday that the city’s seven-day average for positive test results had risen to 1.53 percent.

headline: Jalen Rose’s N.B.A. Finals Diary: ‘I Can’t Wait for the Game’
abstract: The ESPN analyst is enthralled by the 2020 series, with players isolating and “Black Lives Matter” painted on the court.
lead_paragraph: Even in a pandemic, Jalen Rose gets his hair cut about twice a week. He likes to look sharp when he’s on TV, and these days, he and his well-groomed head are highly visible. From the basement of his house in Connecticut, the ESPN analyst and former N.B.A. player tapes “Jalen & Jacoby,” his afternoon talk show with the commentator David Jacoby. And at ESPN’s studio at the South Street Seaport in Manhattan, he helps anchor “NBA Countdown” before and during halftime of N.B.A. games — including the championship finals, which started this week between the Los Angeles Lakers and the Miami Heat.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Cases on Voting Rights and Climate Change
keywords: ['Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The justices will consider challenges to Arizona’s ban on “ballot harvesting” and a suit against energy companies accused of contributing to climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, returning from its summer break, announced Friday that it would hear cases on whether voting restrictions in Arizona violated the Voting Rights Act and whether suits by state and local governments seeking to hold energy companies liable for their contributions to climate change may be heard in federal court.

lead_paragraph: Health and Human Services Secretary Alex M. Azar II praised the department’s handling of the pandemic during his appearance before House lawmakers.

headline: What the ‘Cuties’ Critics Can’t See: The Complexities of Black Girlhood
abstract: The Netflix film and a handful of other recent titles movingly explore what it means to come of age at the crossroads of racism and sexism.

headline: Meet Theater’s Most Famous Superfan: Hillary Clinton
abstract: She’s been to 39 shows since the 2016 election, and believes Broadway will return. But she doesn’t have the “gumption” to see herself depicted just yet.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has long loved theater — back in the day, she wore out a “Camelot” cast album and got standing room tickets to the original production of “Hair.”

headline: Love Letter: Is It Time to Break Up?
abstract: Plus: How to disagree like a grown-up.
lead_paragraph: As that old song goes, “breaking up is hard to do,” especially during a global pandemic. While ending things with a partner might be tougher right now, putting a breakup on hold could do more harm than good. If you’re not sure if now is a good time to call it quits, here are a few questions from relationship experts to help you gain some clarity.

headline: Baltimore Museum to Sell 3 Blue-Chip Paintings to Advance Equity
abstract: As museum staffs demand social justice in the office, an institution sells off prime works to answer the call. Is this the right way to do it?
lead_paragraph: As museums face increasing financial pressures and industrywide demands from staff to create more equitable workplaces, a second institution is taking advantage of the Association of Art Museum Directors’ temporary pandemic-era loosening of its deaccessing guidelines: They now allow the selling of art from museum collections to fund the direct care of collections — not just the acquisition of other artworks.

headline: Chris Wallace, Awaiting Virus Test, Tells Fox News Viewers: ‘Wear the Damn Mask’

lead_paragraph: Chris Wallace, the Fox News anchor who sat within 12 feet of President Trump while moderating Tuesday’s presidential debate in Cleveland, has some stark advice for his network’s viewers: “Wear the damn mask.”

headline: Sometimes, the Funny Thing About Poetry Is the Poems
abstract: Two debut collections, Sumita Chakraborty’s “Arrow” and Chessy Normile’s “Great Exodus, Great Wall, Great Party,” both show that humor can be a valuable weapon in a serious poet’s arsenal.
lead_paragraph: When we were both young and unknown poets, Patricia Lockwood had a blog with the tagline “Poems Are Jokes.” For years, this phrase has come back to me, when I hear an especially poetic joke or read an especially jokelike poem. It has the lifted-brow provocation of all good aphorisms, daring you to believe it.

headline: 17 Republicans decline to condemn QAnon as the House votes to reject its conspiracy theories.
abstract: Seventeen House Republicans voted Friday against a bipartisan resolution condemning QAnon, the viral pro-Trump movement, and rejecting its baseless conspiracy theories, days after a Democratic congressman said he was receiving death threats from followers of the group.
lead_paragraph: Seventeen House Republicans voted Friday against a bipartisan resolution condemning QAnon, the viral pro-Trump movement, and rejecting its baseless conspiracy theories, days after a Democratic congressman said he was receiving death threats from followers of the group.

headline: Harvey Weinstein Faces Six Additional Sexual Assault Charges in Los Angeles

lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein, the once powerful movie mogul who was sentenced in March to 23 years in prison for sex crimes, has been charged with six additional counts of forcible sexual assault in Los Angeles, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: My Screens Are Filled With Black Death, but I Won’t Look Away
abstract: Scenes of racist brutality both real, in news videos, and imagined, in series like “The Boys,” can veer between exposure and exploitation. But sometimes we need to pay the price of our contentment.
lead_paragraph: This essay includes spoilers from the current season of “The Boys.”

headline: When Waking Life Feels Like a Dream
abstract: How do you interpret it?
lead_paragraph: Welcome. I’ve been thinking lately about the tension between dreams and waking life. So much of the recent months has felt uncharted, unreal — how many times have we compared what’s happening to the plot of a movie, to fiction? When a dream feels particularly “big” or poignant, I examine it, marveling at the creativity of my sleeping brain to traffic in metaphor, to make connections, to rifle through the contents of my subconscious and arrange it into something coherent. There’s clarity to be found, often, in observing what the brain is mulling over while the narrator is off duty.

headline: Revisiting George Smiley and the British Secret Service
abstract: In 1974, Richard Locke reviewed “Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy,” John le Carré’s novel following a spymaster’s pursuit to uncover a Soviet mole in the British secret service, for the Book Review.
lead_paragraph: In 1974, Richard Locke reviewed “Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy,” John le Carré’s novel following a spymaster’s pursuit to uncover a Soviet mole in the British secret service, for the Book Review.

headline: Rochester Mayor Is Indicted, Throwing City Into Further Turmoil

headline: Cat Bordhi, Who Challenged Traditional Ways of Knitting, Dies at 69
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Knitting and Knit Goods', 'Wool and Woolen Goods', 'Socks', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Confounded by the complicated instructions that had become the standard, she thought up whimsical new techniques to create socks, scarves and other items.
lead_paragraph: Cat Bordhi, who found joyful rebellion in thinking up new techniques for knitting socks, cowls and other clothing, and whose books encouraged others to question the orthodoxy of that age-old practice, died on Sept. 19 at her home in Friday Harbor, Wash. She was 69.

lead_paragraph: Jacques-Louis Monod, a French composer, conductor and pianist known for his fierce dedication to new music, died on Sept. 21 in Toulouse, France. He was 93.

headline: Remembering a Father’s Love of the Dystopian
abstract: In the middle of a plague, a son thinks back to the way his father devoured any book that intimated disaster was near.

headline: Sexual Harassment Underreported at State Department, Report Says

abstract: The findings confirm years of complaints that women have made against the department for perpetuating a culture of harassment and mishandling claims of misconduct.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sexual harassment at the State Department most likely goes underreported because employees lack confidence in the agency’s responsiveness to the issue and because the department has failed to handle complaints properly, an internal review concluded Friday.

headline: Job Gains Are Waning, a Blow to Economic Recovery

lead_paragraph: Six months after the coronavirus pandemic tore a hole in the U.S. economy, the once-promising recovery is stalling, leaving millions out of work, and threatening to push millions more — particularly women — out of the labor force entirely.

headline: Trump’s Illness Makes It Clear: This Election Was Always About the Virus
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)']

headline: Why Philip Guston Can Still Provoke Such Furor, and Passion
abstract: Guston’s Ku Klux Klan paintings are but one facet of an incendiary artist’s storied career, stretching from social realism to abstraction and back.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a handful of museums decided to postpone a retrospective of the painter Philip Guston over concerns that Ku Klux Klan imagery in his work, intended to criticize racism, anti-Semitism and bigotry, would upset viewers or that the works would be “misinterpreted.” On Wednesday, a letter drafted by the art critic Barry Schwabsky addressed to those museums — the National Gallery of Art in Washington; Museum of Fine Arts, Boston; Museum of Fine Arts, Houston; and Tate Modern, London — and signed by nearly 100 artists, writers and curators, was published by the Brooklyn Rail, protesting the postponement. To date, more than 2,000 names have been added — young and old, Black, Asian, Persian, Arab, L.G.B.T.Q.

headline: Cleveland says 11 cases have been linked to planning and set up for the debate.

headline: Testing Was Not Enough to Protect the White House
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Quarantines', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)']
abstract: The key to slowing down the spread of coronavirus infections is to have few, if any, close contacts. There’s just no getting around it.
lead_paragraph: The president has been infected with coronavirus. Schadenfreude is inappropriate. This is, however, a good opportunity for leaders to rethink their current policies and rhetoric on prevention — because what the president’s case highlights are the limitations of even the best testing regimes.

headline: Voter-advocacy groups in Texas sue to block an order limiting ballot drop-off locations.

lead_paragraph: With only a month before Election Day, a legal battle is erupting in Texas over an order this week by Gov. Greg Abbott, a Republican, to limit the number of drop-off locations for voters to cast absentee ballots.

headline: Soraya Santiago Solla, Transgender Trailblazer, Dies at 72
abstract: She was the first in Puerto Rico to change a gender designation on a birth certificate and the first there to reveal that she’d had sex-reassignment surgery.
lead_paragraph: Always wearing her signature sun hat and large bangle bracelets, Soraya Santiago Solla would bristle when constantly asked about the dreaded “t-word.”

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: An N.B.A. season like no other. Taking the SATs in a pandemic. Millions raised for a Humans of New York legend. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. Laughter’s been sorely missing from a lot of our lives this year. But that’s exactly what some doctors and nurses are recommending to get us through these difficult times. Luckily, streaming platforms are releasing new comedy specials guaranteed to get you cracking a smile. So as darker days creep in with the start of October, don’t feel guilty for choosing to stay in and watch a funny movie or three. However you spend this weekend, I hope you also make time for some fantastic journalism.

headline: The Tragedy of Donald Trump
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)']
abstract: In the drama of 2020, the president’s own coronavirus infection is one more seemingly pre-scripted twist.
lead_paragraph: Last week, just two short days before Donald Trump tested positive for the coronavirus, several of my colleagues wrote a story about the early days of the pandemic, and the strong global public health consensus at the time that open borders and free movement of peoples should not be suspended, even in the face of a swiftly spreading virus.

headline: It’s Time for Diners to Ask the Servers: How Are You Doing?

lead_paragraph: In the small dining room of the acclaimed Manhattan restaurant where Brian Williams waits tables, all the windows were open on Wednesday. It was the day indoor dining returned to New York City, and the state is strongly recommending that windows and doors be kept open for as long as the temperatures cooperate, to let in fresh air.

headline: Australians Watching American Politics: ???!!!!***$%%#

headline: Four Black Men, Lost in Thought
abstract: With this new painting, Jammie Holmes challenges the viewer to speculate about the unspoken worries weighing on his subjects.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a piece — a recent commission for the Dallas Museum of Art included in the exhibition “To Be Determined” — by Jammie Holmes, whose paintings, often featuring scenes and people from his own life, mine the Black American experience.

headline: Trump’s Travail: A Virus That Thrives Indoors

headline: You’re Telling Me!

lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you like mining your puzzles for puns, you certainly won’t find this grid boring! The rest of his job is panning for cruciverbal gold and refining the nuggets as part of our team of puzzle editors.

headline: Sebastian Korda and the Runs That Make This French Open So Unpredictable

headline: President Trump, Jobs, Leaf Peeping: Your Friday Evening Briefing

headline: Amid a Fashion Month Like No Other, Scenes of a Not-So-Distant Past
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Models (Professional)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: The industry has been quick to adapt to the realities of making and showing clothes during a pandemic, but that doesn’t mean the community and the pageantry aren’t missed.
lead_paragraph: Usually, by this time, fashion editors would have descended upon and bustled all around New York, and then London, Milan and now Paris, for the test of endurance known as fashion month. Not this season. During the past few months, designers have been quick to adapt to the constraints of the pandemic, hosting virtual presentations and navigating the logistical challenges of socially distanced events with characteristic imagination. And indeed, there are numerous persuasive silver linings to the advent of the online show — fewer flights, lower costs and a somewhat democratic bent among them — though something else is lost. As the designer Ulla Johnson recently told T, a live fashion show — that extravagant, expensive, but undeniably exciting spectacle — generates a “crazy, buzzy energy” that a digital image or video can hardly match. And yet the videos here do two things: They remind us of a freer time in both fashion and the world, and also that creativity exists in many forms, on and off the runway, whether on the street, at an atelier workbench or with a beloved pet.

headline: After 30 Years, East and West Germans Wonder: How United Are We?

abstract: With Germany now an established, reunified democracy, it is taking stock of what is working and what still needs work, especially as the economy continues to lag in the former East.

Some two decades later, he decided to quit the East after graduating from university, like so many of his generation looking for brighter futures, and move to the capital of a reunified Germany.

I live in Philadelphia, which means that by the time I board, the train has already picked up new passengers at several other stops. headline: If Commercial Gyms Can Reopen, Why Can’t the One in My Building?
abstract: State guidelines do not differentiate between stand-alone gyms and those inside residential buildings, which can make things tough for condos and co-ops.
lead_paragraph: Q: Commercial gyms have reopened in New York City, but my condo’s gym remains closed, and the managing agent says it will remain that way for the foreseeable future because the building doesn’t have the staff or resources to comply with city guidelines. Are gyms in residential buildings really held to the same standard as commercial gyms? Couldn’t the building devise sensible safety measures, like limiting use to one household at a time, or letting residents sign a liability waiver?

headline: The Votes Cast, a Fat Bear Is Crowned
abstract: Each year, people vote for the heftiest brown bear at the Katmai National Park and Preserve during the Fat Bear Week contest.

headline: Contact Tracing, Key to Reining In the Virus, Falls Flat in the West
abstract: Tracing is seen as a vital tool to avoid lockdowns and open economies, but that requires a robust system, widespread rapid testing and public trust. All are lacking in the West.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the coronavirus stampeded across Europe and the United States this spring, governments made their depleted citizens a tantalizing promise: Soon, legions of disease detectives would hunt down anyone exposed to the virus, confining them to their homes and letting everyone else get on with their lives.

headline: With Patchwork Pitching, the Padres Turn Another Page

lead_paragraph: When the San Diego Padres announced their first-round playoff roster Wednesday, it was hard not to look and think: Well, it was fun while it lasted. There were 14 pitchers among the 28 names, but not Mike Clevinger or Dinelson Lamet.

headline: Variety: Marching Bands

lead_paragraph: MARCHING BANDS — Here we have one of those variety puzzles that draws elements from others that we solve, when you stop to think about it. I’m reminded of the cryptic, where our perception of hidden words has been honed, and the diagramless, where you need to keep track of where to start and end entries so they don’t screw up your unnumbered grid.

headline: ‘They Chose to Stay Open and Fight’
abstract: Restaurant workers share their struggles since the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: For those working in the restaurant industry, “Every day is a negotiation: of labor costs, food costs, rent, insurance, health inspections, and the art and craft of creating an experience special enough to keep people coming through the doors,” writes Priya Krishna in her Op-Ed, “How to Save Restaurants.”

headline: Now the President and Frontline Workers Have Something in Common
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Income Inequality', 'Discrimination', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Disease Rates', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The difference is not all frontline workers can protect themselves on the job. The coronavirus race gap, explained.
lead_paragraph: Most of the women in Maria Jose Bastias’s English language class, at Mujeres Unidas y Activas, a nonprofit in San Francisco, did not know that they could get a coronavirus test without health insurance, or that they were legally entitled to paid sick leave if they contracted the virus, regardless of their immigration status. They worked grueling hours at menial jobs that offered little security; it had not occurred to many of them to even ask about such benefits, let alone to expect them.

headline: Why a Pro-Trump Town No Longer Sees Him as a Rescuer
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Portsmouth, Ohio, was facing hard times when our reporter spent a week there leading up to Election Day 2016. She went back to find the town rebounding, and loyal to President Trump. But its residents no longer tie their fortunes to him.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio — It was right around 10 p.m. at Buffalo Wild Wings on Scioto Trail when the needle swung from Hillary Clinton to Donald J. Trump.

headline: A Toxic Alien Is Taking Over Russia
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Invasive Species', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Rural Areas', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The giant hogweed isn’t just an invasive plant. It’s a metaphor for what is happening to much of this country.
lead_paragraph: BALASHIKHA, Russia — Take any of the many highways out of the Russian capital and you can dissect the country’s strata like rings on a tree. Sentinel apartment towers replace the bustling illuminated center, then the belt of auto dealerships and box stores drifts by. Gradually, the landscape becomes sparse, with villages and towns sporadically punctuating the stretch of meadows and forests for thousands of miles in every direction.

headline: Profits and Social Responsibility: Revisiting Milton Friedman
abstract: Fifty years after publication of his influential manifesto on free-market capitalism, readers discuss whether profits should be a corporation’s top priority.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Workers Face Permanent Job Losses as the Virus Persists
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Soon, a wave of people will have been out of work for more than six months, the threshold for long-term unemployment.
lead_paragraph: The United States economy is facing a tidal wave of long-term unemployment as millions of people who lost jobs early in the pandemic remain out of work six months later and job losses increasingly turn permanent.

headline: Armenia and Azerbaijan: What Sparked War and Will Peace Prevail?
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'War and Armed Conflicts']
abstract: How did a deep-rooted local conflict draw in regional powers? And after a cease-fire agreement, what are the prospects for peace?
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A simmering, decades-long conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh erupted in late September into the worst fighting the area had seen since a vicious ethnic war in the 1990s.

headline: Patriots-Chiefs Game Postponed After Positive Coronavirus Tests on Both Teams
abstract: Cam Newton was among those who tested positive. Sunday’s game was rescheduled for Monday night after no new positives were reported.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has rescheduled Sunday’s highly anticipated game between the New England Patriots and the Kansas City Chiefs to Monday night after Cam Newton, the Patriots’ star quarterback, and the practice squad quarterback on the Chiefs tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: Floodgates in Venice Work in First Major Test
abstract: The fiercely contested floodgate system was used to stop a high tide from flooding Venice’s fragile streets. The system held, but will it work as the climate worsens?
lead_paragraph: ROME — After decades of bureaucratic delays, corruption and resistance from environmental groups, sea walls designed to defend Venice from “acqua alta,” or high water, went up on Saturday, testing their ability to battle the city’s increasingly menacing floods.

headline: Chris Christie, who helped Trump prepare for the debate, has the virus.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As America locked down this spring during the worst pandemic in a century, inside the Trump White House there was the usual defiance.

headline: To Hold Police Accountable, Ax the Arbitrators
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: Communities should have the power to fire abusive officers. But that power often rests with an obscure group of unelected labor arbitrators.
lead_paragraph: Since the death of George Floyd sparked a wave of national protests, at least 42 of the 50 largest cities in the country have adopted new rules aimed at curbing abuses by the police, according to a tally by Samuel Walker, an expert on police accountability who is affiliated with the University of Nebraska Omaha. From May through August, 15 cities banned chokeholds. A dozen passed “duty-to-intervene” statutes, requiring police officers to act if they see a fellow officer endanger a civilian. Still others banned so-called “no knock” warrants or changed policies related to the use of force.

headline: Attorney General Barr will not self-quarantine, despite possible exposure to the coronavirus.
abstract: He attended a reception for Amy Coney Barrett, an event where several other attendees later tested positive.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General William P. Barr, the nation’s top law enforcement officer, has decided not to self-quarantine, despite potential prolonged exposure to the coronavirus.

headline: McConnell Delays Senate’s Return as a Third Senator Falls Ill
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)']
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell postponed the Senate’s return for two weeks but said lawmakers would continue confirmation hearings as planned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, said on Saturday that the Senate would not meet as planned next week after three senators tested positive for the coronavirus, even as he pledged to press ahead to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court.

headline: Sofia Kenin’s Knack for Rebounds Is Being Tested at the French Open. And in 2020.
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic took away a window of opportunity for Sofia Kenin after she won the Australian Open in January. But she’s still motivated.
lead_paragraph: It takes grit for a tennis player at any level to bounce back quickly from losing 6-0, 6-0.

headline: With Trump Hospitalized, Covid-19 Continues Its Onslaught on the U.S.
abstract: The infection of President Trump and some of his top associates makes clear that the country is still in the throes of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Covid-19 has proved itself an unpredictable and ever-changing threat. As President Trump and some of his allies and associates test positive for the coronavirus, the number of new cases reported each day across the United States has been slowly rising. The nation’s response has been uneven and inconsistent. Here is where the country is now.

headline: Clinical Trials Hit by Ransomware Attack on Health Tech Firm
keywords: ['Clinical Trials', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Research']
abstract: No patients were affected, but the incident was another reminder of the risks in the increasingly common assaults on computer networks.
lead_paragraph: A Philadelphia company that sells software used in hundreds of clinical trials, including the crash effort to develop tests, treatments and a vaccine for the coronavirus, was hit by a ransomware attack that has slowed some of those trials over the past two weeks.

headline: Trump’s Covid Treatments Are Aimed at Preventing Severe Illness
abstract: Outside experts pointed to the therapies as signs that the president’s health may not be as good as his doctors said. His age, weight and gender put him at high risk.
