abstract: The special project Young Black Poets showcases a promising new generation of writers whose verses respond to this moment in America.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Let’s Make a Deal
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The nation needs another round of federal aid. President Trump and Congress need to rise to the moment.
lead_paragraph: Economic growth is sputtering as the coronavirus continues to spread. Workers laid off temporarily in the spring or summer are discovering that their jobs are gone forever. Small businesses are guttering out like so many candles in a rainstorm. State and local governments are cutting services. Millions of children are hungry; millions of families can’t pay their rent.

headline: A.O.C.’s Mistake in Pulling Out of a Rabin Memorial
abstract: How politicians cave in an age of absolutist moral judgments.
lead_paragraph: Robert Mackey of The Intercept tweeted this week: “I give up. It’s pointless to report on anything other than the president of the United States having a personal social media feed that reveals he’s a lunatic.”

headline: Hurricane Delta Brings High Winds and Rain to Louisiana’s Coast
abstract: Storm surge rose more than seven feet on Friday in some areas of Louisiana, where Hurricane Delta made landfall as a Category 2 storm. It struck 20 miles east of Hurricane Laura’s landfall six weeks earlier.
lead_paragraph: Storm surge rose more than seven feet on Friday in some areas of Louisiana, where Hurricane Delta made landfall as a Category 2 storm. It struck 20 miles east of Hurricane Laura’s landfall six weeks earlier.

headline: Election Less Than a Month Away, Trump Leans on Barr and Pompeo for a Lift
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The secretary of state said he would make Hillary Clinton’s emails public, handing the president a weapon to attack his political foes as the attorney general resisted his overtures to prosecute them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump forced the State Department on Friday to commit to releasing at least some of Hillary Clinton’s emails before next month’s election, resurrecting a four-year-old issue in hopes that it would prove as helpful to his political prospects as it was when he defeated her in 2016.

headline: The 1619 Chronicles
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Declaration of Independence (US)', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Journalism does better when it writes the first rough draft of history, not the last word on it.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one word admirers and critics alike can agree on when it comes to The New York Times’s award-winning 1619 Project, it’s ambition. Ambition to reframe America’s conversation about race. Ambition to reframe our understanding of history. Ambition to move from news pages to classrooms. Ambition to move from scholarly debate to national consciousness.

headline: Battle Cry
abstract: Brian Thomas hits us squarely with a piercing Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid is really loopy and fun; it’s the fourth construction we’ve seen from Brian Thomas this year, the kind of statistic that honestly impresses the heck out of 2020 me. I wrestled with at least one entry in all four corners — tough trivia, a bemusing misdirect, an odd letter sequence and an unfamiliar term. There are lots of sparklers in between the stumpers, adding up to an entertaining solve.

headline: Former Philadelphia Officer Charged With Murder in 2017 Shooting
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Eric Ruch Jr.’s killing of Dennis Plowden, an unarmed Black man, after a high-speed chase was unjustified, a grand jury found.
lead_paragraph: A former Philadelphia police officer has been charged with first-degree murder in connection with the fatal shooting of an unarmed Black man after a high-speed chase in December 2017 that ended in a crash, prosecutors said Friday.

headline: Trump Claims in Interview That He Is ‘Medication Free’
keywords: ['White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Dexamethasone (Drug)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The president said on Fox that he went to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center last Friday because he “didn’t feel strong,” but he denied that he had experienced any trouble breathing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Friday night in his first televised interview since he learned he had Covid-19 that he was “medication free” and he claimed to be back to normal, a week after being hospitalized after having trouble breathing.

headline: Rays Send Yankees to Another Off-Season of Vexing Questions
abstract: Mike Brosseau’s eighth-inning homer was the difference on Friday, but the Yankees again were left to analyze how a talented roster fell short in the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The timing was coincidental, but fitting nonetheless.

headline: Justice Dept. Suspends All Diversity and Inclusion Training for Staff
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The move was the latest effort by the Trump administration to eliminate any training that encourages workers to acknowledge that implicit racial and gender biases exist in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department suspended all diversity and inclusion training for its employees and managers this week, complying with President Trump’s recent executive order to eliminate any training that suggests that implicit racial and gender biases exist in the workplace, according to a memo distributed to the department’s executive officers.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Son of the City, and Cornerstone of a Dynasty
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 10, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “He was like a master chess player who used his brain to take the bat right out of my hands.”

headline: 2020 French Open: Women’s Final Preview
abstract: Sofia Kenin and Iga Swiatek face off, each looking to secure their first French Open title.
lead_paragraph: How to watch: 9 a.m. on NBC; streaming on the NBC app.

headline: Teenagers in Turmoil

headline: Corrections: Oct. 10, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 10, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about President Trump’s criticism of his top officials for not prosecuting or implicating his political enemies referred incorrectly to a video of the president speaking on the White House lawn. While on first inspection it appeared that the backdrop might have been on a loop, a deeper examination by The Times and by Catalin Grigoras, a director at the National Center for Media Forensics at the University of Colorado, Denver, indicated no evidence of manipulation.

headline: Federal Judge Blocks Texas Governor’s Move to Limit Ballot Drop-Off Sites
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott had ordered that counties in the state be limited to one site each.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas on Friday blocked Gov. Greg Abbott’s move to limit counties in the state to one ballot drop-off site each.

headline: Will This Be the Last French Open With Only Human Eyes Minding the Lines?
abstract: Clay-court events have been the last holdouts against electronic line calling, in large part because of how well the surface absorbs marks wherever a ball lands.
lead_paragraph: A ball lands close to a line. A call is made. A player expresses doubt. A chair umpire descends to inspect the ball mark on the red clay and renders final judgment, often with the umpire and the player both hunched over the evidence in the soil like archaeologists.

headline: How Long Should Trump Be in Isolation?
abstract: Some White House staff members who were exposed to the virus have not followed public health guidance to quarantine or self-isolate.
lead_paragraph: Some White House staff members who were exposed to the virus have not followed public health guidance to quarantine or self-isolate.

headline: Airline Miles Programs Sure Are Profitable. Are You the Loser?
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Frequent Flier Programs', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Credit Cards', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: United and Delta have been boasting to lenders about fat margins in frequent-flier mile programs. Time for customers to pay a bit more attention.
lead_paragraph: The airlines of the United States have extra-special status. How special? Many of them may get a second pile of coronavirus relief money before citizens who can’t afford to fly get another $1,200 check.

headline: Europe’s Economic Recovery Is a Summer Memory
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Credit and Debt', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: As the coronavirus resumes spreading rapidly across the continent, hopes for an economic revival have given way to diminished expectations.

headline: Hong Kong Arrests Nine Over Protesters’ Escape by Speedboat
abstract: The arrests appeared intended to deter others from helping antigovernment protesters flee the Chinese territory, where Beijing’s grip is tightening.

headline: Huge Absentee Vote in Key States Favors Democrats So Far

abstract: In Wisconsin, about 146,000 people voted by mail in the 2016 general election. This fall, about 647,000 people have already voted absentee, many in Democratic strongholds.
lead_paragraph: In Madison, Wis., thousands of people have gone to parks to deliver their ballots during Saturday voting festivals. In Milwaukee, Facebook feeds are inundated with selfies of Democrats inserting ballots into drop boxes. And along the shores of Lake Superior, voters in Wisconsin’s liberal northwest corner still trust the Postal Service to deliver ballots.

headline: This Miami Heat Player Rained 3-Pointers on the Lakers’ Parade
abstract: The Los Angeles Lakers expected to win a championship on Friday, but they were denied by the hot shooting of Miami’s Duncan Robinson (and, of course, Jimmy Butler).
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Duncan Robinson was struggling with his 3-point shot in the N.B.A. finals, and that was a problem because shooting 3-pointers is the one thing he does exceptionally well. Jimmy Butler, his teammate on the Miami Heat, invited him to his hotel room for a late-night chat. It was a pep talk with a heavy dose of tough love.

headline: Trump sent more than 2,000 invitations for an event on the White House lawn on Saturday.
abstract: President Trump is planning to host up to 2,000 people on the South Lawn of the White House on Saturday for his first in-person event since he announced he had tested positive for the coronavirus, three people familiar with the plans said on Friday, and his campaign announced that he would hold a rally in Florida on Monday.

abstract: The president claimed that he went to the hospital last Friday because he “didn’t feel strong,” but denied that he had experienced any trouble breathing, although there had been congestion in his lungs.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, in his first televised interview since he announced that he had tested positive for the coronavirus, said Friday night that he was “medication free” and back to normal, a week after he was hospitalized after having trouble breathing.

headline: Can a Broker Change the Details to Make an Old Listing Look New?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: What difference does it make if an apartment is called 13P or 13D? A big one to many prospective renters, which is why brokers sometimes change those numbers.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a rental building on the Upper West Side and follow the building’s listings on StreetEasy. Like many buildings, it has had multiple listings that have been up for a long time. I now see that the brokers have changed the letters of the apartments so that they appear as new listings. For example, apartment 13D is now listed as 13P. (Our building only has apartments lettered A through K.) They have done this with a couple of apartments. Is this legal?

headline: Iga Swiatek Steamrolls Through the French Open, Besting Sofia Kenin in the Final
abstract: Swiatek became the first player from Poland to win a Grand Slam singles title. She did it without losing a set at Roland Garros, and no more than five games in any match.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Polish national anthem reverberated through a mostly empty Philippe Chatrier Court to the delight of Iga Swiatek, who had barely broken a sweat in her 6-4, 6-1 defeat of the No. 4 seed and reigning Australian Open champion Sofia Kenin in their French Open singles final on Saturday.

headline: Not Sure Who to Vote For? Seriously? OK, This Quiz Is for You

headline: It’s a Hellscape Out There. Try a Galette.
abstract: They’re messy. They’re forgiving. They’re the pastry form we need in 2020.
lead_paragraph: After six months at home, I have no idea what I sound like on the page anymore. I’ve lost my voice to underuse — or that’s what it feels like. I don’t know what I look like either. It’s not that I’m sitting around in my pajamas. I’m getting as dressed as I ever did, even putting on perfume. But without daily immersion in society, my sense of the world’s outside-in gaze on me has attenuated.

headline: Everything I Know About Elite America I Learned From ‘Fresh Prince’ and ‘West Wing’
abstract: Television taught me how to move between social classes — but at what cost?
lead_paragraph: At first, I thought class was about money. “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air” taught me that it wasn’t.

headline: Hurricane Delta Brings Floods and Destruction to an Already Battered Louisiana
abstract: The storm made landfall some 20 miles from where Laura touched down a few weeks ago, intensifying the devastation the state has experienced during a brutal hurricane season.
lead_paragraph: BELL CITY, La. — Hurricane Delta tore across Louisiana late Friday, leaving a trail of destruction as it turned roadways into rapids and uprooted trees that crashed onto roofs. It also dealt a demoralizing blow to a state still staggering its way back from one of the most powerful storms that it had ever endured.

Fauci, the nation’s leading infectious disease expert, is “there to serve the president.”

headline: Variety: Acrostic

The passage is from a 21st-century book, “1491,” by Charles C. Mann, a science and technology journalist; it concerns one of the great Mesoamerican civilizations, the Olmec, who lived in a greatly sophisticated culture before both the Mayas and the Aztecs.

headline: Without Live Music to Play, Pearl Jam Reimagines Rock Activism in 2020
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: The pandemic has grounded rock tours and left clubs empty. So Pearl Jam is turning to the tools of modern politics to get out the vote.
lead_paragraph: Back in March, as the coronavirus first gripped the country, Pearl Jam made the difficult decision to postpone all its concert dates for the foreseeable future. In doing so, the band was canceling not just a fall tour, but also a trip through presidential battleground states like Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin that would have doubled as a get-out-the-vote campaign.

abstract: Lawmakers in Central Asia's only democracy selected a man sprung from jail by protesters just days ago in an effort to end days of violent political unrest
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A man who had been convicted of kidnapping was chosen to be the prime minister of Kyrgyzstan on Saturday after feuding politicians agreed on a new government in an effort to end nearly a week of violent turmoil in the Central Asian country.

headline: There Will Be No Trump Coup
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: A final pre-election case for understanding the president as a noisy weakling, not a budding autocrat.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks from now, we will reach an end to speculation about what Donald Trump will do if he faces political defeat, whether he will leave power like a normal president or attempt some wild resistance. Reality will intrude, substantially if not definitively, into the argument over whether the president is a corrupt incompetent who postures as a strongman on Twitter or a threat to the Republic to whom words like “authoritarian” and even “autocrat” can be reasonably applied.

headline: Who’s the Tax Cheat: The Lady in Jail or the Man in the White House?

In 2016, when the veterans were in their 80s and 90s, the Obama administration agreed to allow some of their relatives in the Philippines to come to the United States before they completed the long wait for formal admission.

abstract: Even people who aren’t obese may be more likely to become seriously ill when infected with the coronavirus, the C.D.C. said.
lead_paragraph: Obese Americans are more likely to become dangerously ill if they are infected with the new coronavirus. Now public health officials are warning that a much broader segment of the population also may be at risk: even moderately excess weight may increase the odds of severe disease.

headline: Nevada Revokes Halt on Rapid Antigen Testing in Nursing Homes

headline: Princeton to Name Residential College After Black Alumna
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Names, Organizational', 'Discrimination', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: It will be named after Mellody Hobson and built where a college once bore Woodrow Wilson’s name. Princeton in June said the former president was a racist who segregated the Civil Service.
lead_paragraph: On the site of a residential college that for more than 50 years bore the name of Woodrow Wilson, the president who oversaw the segregation of the federal Civil Service, a new Princeton residential college will be built and named after Mellody Hobson, a prominent Black alumna, the university said.

headline: Trump Makes First Public Appearance Since Leaving Walter Reed
keywords: ['White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president continued to play down the threat of the virus, but the event that the White House had previewed as a huge “peaceful protest for law and order” was uncharacteristically brief.

But Mr. Trump, eager to prove he had fully recovered a week after being hospitalized for Covid-19, appeared briefly on Saturday afternoon in front of hundreds of chanting supporters gathered at the White House.

Biden Jr., takes his presidency into new territory — until now, occupied by leaders with names like Putin, Xi and Erdogan.

headline: πr²
abstract: Gary Larson’s Sunday puzzle makes us circle back and get square.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s grid hangs on an interesting angle, one that you’ll miss if you don’t notice its title — πr² — or remember that this mathematical term describes the area of a circle (with a radius of r). Its constructor, Gary Larson, is a former cruise ship entertainer, not a cartoonist; this is only his fourth Times puzzle, but he’s prolific elsewhere, including The Los Angeles Times. This is also his Sunday debut with us; it’s heavy with theme and there are a lot of unusual entries to buoy the fill.

headline: It’s Djokovic-Nadal Yet Again. But This French Open Duel Is Not Like the Others.

headline: Draw Your Life, One Coffee Mug at a Time
abstract: Taking the time to sketch your belongings can help capture moments and memories.
lead_paragraph: Find an old receipt in your wallet. Feel that thin paper on your fingers, and look at the inky machine type. Why is this telling you to have a nice day? Did you? Instead of throwing the receipt away, draw it. It’s not only a marker of money spent — a replacement for the cash that was once in its place — but of a real moment.

headline: 4 Podcasts That Go Bump in the Night
abstract: These shows are perfect for Halloween creeps and scares. Listen, if you dare.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to horror, no C.G.I. monstrosity is quite as terrifying as what your mind can conjure. We’ve collected some of the most delightful frights and spooky scintillations in audio drama and non-fiction podcasting.

headline: Support Independent Restaurants
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Restaurants', 'Small Business', 'Gift Cards and Certificates']
abstract: As the weather gets colder in many places, mom-and-pop establishments are under even more strain. You can take some simple steps to help them survive.
lead_paragraph: Even with outdoor dining this summer, many restaurants across the country have closed or remain on the brink of disaster — especially smaller, independently owned neighborhood businesses. Loyal patrons have rallied to support their favorite local restaurants, but as the pandemic drags on, business owners have had to hustle hard to stay afloat.

headline: Rest Better With Light Exercises
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Back (Human Body Part)', 'Legs', 'Knees', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Yoga', 'Sleep', 'Neck', 'Exercise', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Stretching and meditative movement like yoga before bed can improve the quality of your sleep and the amount you sleep. Here is a short and calming routine of 11 stretches and exercises.
lead_paragraph: Sleep should be a welcome respite, but with our regular routines upended and an almost daily onslaught of anxiety-inducing news, many people are tossing and turning. A study published in June by the journal Sleep Medicine found a 37 percent increase in the rates of clinical insomnia among adults in China from before the peak of the pandemic.

headline: Discover the Culinary History of Witchcraft and Join a Digital Self-Care ‘Crawl’
abstract: Enjoy a reading from Marilynne Robinson’s new book, attend the opening night of a film fest and take the kids on a virtual tour of a museum for musical instruments.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: At the French Open, Players Look to the Tao of Rafael Nadal
abstract: For many of the players, Nadal has given the most cleareyed view of a tournament held during a pandemic and a career chasing Grand Slam titles.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Playing to his Paris audience, Rafael Nadal usually speaks in French for his on-court interviews at Roland Garros, where his astounding success on the red clay has afforded him abundant practice at polishing his sentences. But on Sunday, after winning his 13th French Open singles championship, Nadal, usually so unrelenting in his routine, dispensed with this particular habit.

headline: QAnon Is Thriving in Germany. The Extreme Right Is Delighted.
keywords: ['QAnon', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Politics and Government', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Neo Nazi Groups', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: As the U.S. conspiracy theory goes global, it has found fertile ground in the putsch fantasies and anti-Semitic tropes long popular on Germany’s far-right fringe. Counterterrorism officials worry.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Early in the pandemic, as thousands of American troops began NATO maneuvers in Germany, Attila Hildmann did a quick YouTube search to see what it was all about. He quickly came across videos posted by German followers of QAnon.

headline: In Belarus, Women Led the Protests and Shattered Stereotypes
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: The women who organized the political campaign and the subsequent protests against President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko may ultimately be defeated. But society may never be the same.
lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — With masked riot police officers massing nearby, threatening to attack protesters like him with batons and fists, Aleksei D. Zulevsky felt safe for the first time in weeks of anti-government unrest in Belarus: He was surrounded by hundreds of women he knew would shield him.

headline: Training Tomorrow’s Newshounds
abstract: Two new books about the press urge young people to leave their social media feeds and read reliable news and information from many different sources.
lead_paragraph: GUARDIANS OF LIBERTYFreedom of the Press and the Nature of NewsBy Linda Barrett Osborne

abstract: “The Talk” and “This Is Your Brain on Stereotypes” offer two very different approaches to helping children understand and confront bias.
lead_paragraph: THE TALKConversations About Race, Love & TruthEdited by Wade Hudson and Cheryl Willis Hudson

headline: Corrections: Oct. 11, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2020.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an opinion article on Sept. 27 about blackface in film and television misidentified an actor. He is Mark Proksch, not Rainn Wilson.

headline: Quotation of the Day: C.D.C.’s Director Is Challenged to ‘Stand Up to a Bully’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 11, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “As much as we want to believe we can operate independently of politics and it’s all about science, it took just a few months to hobble our ability to steer the course of this pandemic. So we can pretend that the politics don’t matter, but we have been kneecapped.”

headline: ‘My First Piña Colada Was the Summer Before Seventh Grade’
abstract: A drink brings back childhood memories, a game goes on and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.

headline: In a Small Alabama Town, Suddenly All Politics Is National
keywords: ['Elections, Mayors', 'Local Government', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Police Reform', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The race for mayor in Montevallo used to be low-key and nonpartisan. In the Trump era, one candidate learned the hard way that’s no longer the case.
lead_paragraph: MONTEVALLO, Ala. — Perhaps no one was more surprised to learn that Joyce Jones wanted to defund the police than Joyce Jones herself.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Has a Theory About the Fly That Landed on Mike Pence’s Head
abstract: “Saturday Night Live” satirized Wednesday’s vice-presidential debate in an episode of comedy monologues guaranteed to press everyone’s buttons.
lead_paragraph: From the moment that an errant fly touched down on Vice President Mike Pence during Wednesday’s vice-presidential debate, “Saturday Night Live” viewers started imploring the show to recreate the awkward moment. And “S.N.L.” did just that — at some extravagant length — in this weekend’s opening sketch, leading off an episode full of comedy monologues that were certain to offend almost every sensibility and political viewpoint.

headline: Latino, Evangelical and Politically Homeless
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Evangelical Movement']
abstract: Hispanic evangelicals identify as religious first and foremost. That’s why, despite his harsh rhetoric on immigration, many back President Trump.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — At the Church of God of Prophecy, hundreds come each Sunday for two hours of worship in Spanish. They share passages from the Bible, sing and embrace each other tightly. The evangelical congregation, led for nearly 25 years by Pastor Jose Rivera, is nearly all Latino, the vast majority with roots in Mexico.

headline: What ‘The Babylon Bee’ Thinks Is So Funny About Liberals
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The comedy site, a conservative answer to ‘The Onion,’ used to have Trump squarely in its cross hairs. But now it’s less about him and more about the people who can’t stand him.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, in the heat of the Republican primary, a fledgling satire site jabbed at the party’s leading contender: “Psychopathic Megalomaniac Somehow Garnering Evangelical Vote.” The story proceeded to describe Donald Trump as “a man who would seemingly have no qualms obliterating hundreds of thousands of people for purely egotistical reasons.”

headline: Why Are N.F.L. Scores So High This Season?
abstract: Some look to the effects of the disruptions caused by the pandemic, while others find other explanations. But it’s irrefutable teams are scoring more points than in last season.
lead_paragraph: Taking place during a global pandemic, the 2020 N.F.L. season always figured to be an outlier, and predictably there have been persistent coronavirus outbreaks, a hastily restructured playing schedule and games contested in stark, empty stadiums.

headline: With Elections Ahead, Some African Presidents Try Engineering Results
abstract: Presidential elections are scheduled soon in at least 10 African countries. Many incumbents are changing constitutions and bending rules to ensure they stay in power.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The president of the West African nation of Guinea is running for a third term on Oct. 18, even though Guinea requires its presidents to step down after two. But because of a constitutional change he initiated, his first two terms don’t count.

headline: Campaign rallies, Trump properties, Hurricane Delta: Your Weekend Briefing

headline: Pakistan Bans TikTok, Citing Morals. Others Cite Politics.
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Politics and Government', 'Mobile Applications', 'Blacklisting', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity']
abstract: Conservatives have raised questions about public decency on the Chinese-owned service, but opposition groups see an effort to stop criticism of the country’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan has become the latest country to ban TikTok, the Chinese-owned social media platform, in a move that government critics said stemmed as much from politics as from allegations of immoral content.

headline: Rafael Nadal Routs Novak Djokovic at French Open to Catch Roger Federer
abstract: Rafael Nadal won his 20th Grand Slam men’s singles championship to tie Roger Federer’s record. It was Nadal’s 13th title at the French Open.
lead_paragraph: Neither Novak Djokovic nor Roger Federer could resist Rafael Nadal on Sunday.

headline: Offering few details, the White House doctor says Trump is no longer contagious.
abstract: President Trump’s doctor said in a memo released Saturday night that he was “no longer considered a transmission risk to others,” as the president prepared to resume campaign activities this week.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s doctor said in a memo released Saturday night that he was “no longer considered a transmission risk to others,” as the president prepared to resume campaign activities this week.

headline: C.E.O.s Rediscover the Family Dinner Table
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Children and Childhood', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: Remote work during the coronavirus pandemic has given executives with children a taste of a different way to live.
lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus pandemic, John Foley, the chief executive and founder of Peloton, and his wife, Jill, a vice president at Peloton, would leave the house each morning by 7:45 a.m. and not come home until 7:30 p.m. By then, their nanny had already fed and gotten their two children ready for bed.

headline: Supreme Court Hearing Presents a Big Stage, and Big Risks, for Harris
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Though a junior member of the panel, the vice-presidential contender will draw heightened scrutiny as the Senate Judiciary Committee takes up Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s nomination.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just seconds into the Supreme Court confirmation hearing of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh in 2018, Senator Charles E. Grassley, then the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, was interrupted by a sharp demand to be recognized from far down the Democratic side of the dais.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘David’s Ankles’
abstract: A writer’s obsession with the flaws, reproductions and potential collapse of Michelangelo’s masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: There are cracks in the ankles of Michelangelo’s David. The weakness was first discovered in the 19th century, but it wasn’t until a paper by Italian geoscientists was published in 2014 that the extent of the statue’s precariousness was fully understood: If the David were to be tilted 15 degrees, his ankles would fail.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $625,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Can Trump Squeeze More From His White Base in Pennsylvania and Beyond?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Whites', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: With President Trump trailing Joseph R. Biden Jr. in Pennsylvania in nearly every poll, his last refuge and perhaps best hope is to maximize the turnout of working-class white voters.
lead_paragraph: OLYPHANT, Pa. — President Trump’s narrowing path to victory in Pennsylvania, and the country, runs through small towns like Olyphant, where Dave Mitchko’s street might be quieter if not for the large sign he put on his front lawn urging supporters of the president to honk when they pass.

headline: Absentee voting in several key states is favoring Democrats.
abstract: In Madison, Wis., thousands of people have gone to parks to deliver their ballots during Saturday voting festivals. In Milwaukee, Facebook feeds are inundated with selfies of Democrats inserting ballots into drop boxes. And along the shores of Lake Superior, voters in Wisconsin’s liberal northwest corner still trust the Postal Service to deliver ballots.
lead_paragraph: In Madison, Wis., thousands of people have gone to parks to deliver their ballots during Saturday voting festivals. In Milwaukee, Facebook feeds are inundated with selfies of Democrats inserting ballots into drop boxes. And along the shores of Lake Superior, voters in Wisconsin’s liberal northwest corner still trust the Postal Service to deliver ballots.

headline: A new poll shows little change in the race since Trump’s coronavirus diagnosis.
abstract: A Washington Post/ABC News poll released Sunday shows Joseph R. Biden Jr. leading President Trump by 12 percentage points, similar both to his margin in a Post/ABC poll last month and to his margins in polls released by several other organizations in the past week.
lead_paragraph: A Washington Post/ABC News poll released Sunday shows Joseph R. Biden Jr. leading President Trump by 12 percentage points, similar both to his margin in a Post/ABC poll last month and to his margins in polls released by several other organizations in the past week.

headline: After refusing to participate in the second presidential debate, Trump retreats to conservative media safe spaces.
abstract: When President Trump picked someone to conduct his first on-camera interview since testing positive for the coronavirus, he made the safest of choices: Dr. Marc Siegel, a physician and Fox News personality who has criticized Democratic governors for closing down schools and businesses to fight the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump picked someone to conduct his first on-camera interview since testing positive for the coronavirus, he made the safest of choices: Dr. Marc Siegel, a physician and Fox News personality who has criticized Democratic governors for closing down schools and businesses to fight the pandemic.

headline: Trump, still recovering from Covid, plans a return to campaign rallies.
abstract: President Trump, still recovering from Covid-19, plans to return to the campaign trail on Monday with a rally in Florida.
lead_paragraph: As Election Day draws ever closer, President Trump is leaning into the kind of campaigning he feels most comfortable with. He is set to return to holding rallies on Monday, just over a week after he announced he had contracted the coronavirus and with stimulus negotiations in perilous standing.

headline: Premier League Reform Plan Seeks to Reshape English Soccer
abstract: A proposal engineered by Liverpool and Manchester United would yield an 18-team Premier League and hundreds of millions of dollars in payments to lower leagues. But key players are not on board.
lead_paragraph: Taken together, the proposals amount to the biggest changes in English soccer in more than a quarter of a century. An 18-team Premier League. Hundreds of millions of dollars in extra payments from Premier League clubs to their poorer rivals. And an end of direct payment to clubs relegated from the top division.

headline: This week’s presidential debate has officially been canceled.
abstract: The second presidential debate, originally scheduled for Oct. 15 in Miami, has been canceled by the Commission on Presidential Debates, according to a statement released on Friday by the group.
lead_paragraph: The second presidential debate, originally scheduled for Oct. 15 in Miami, has been canceled by the Commission on Presidential Debates, according to a statement released on Friday by the group.

headline: Biden will build on his economic populist message in Ohio on Monday.
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. will continue promoting his economic message to “Build Back Better” in a trip to Ohio on Monday, where he will deliver remarks in Toledo before a visit to Cincinnati. It was a message he pushed over the weekend, swinging through a county in Pennsylvania that voted for Donald Trump in 2016 and Barack Obama in 2012, and making a direct pitch to union and blue-collar workers on Saturday afternoon, in a speech laden with economic populist tones.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. will continue promoting his economic message to “Build Back Better” in a trip to Ohio on Monday, where he will deliver remarks in Toledo before a visit to Cincinnati. headline: Nancy Pelosi merely panned the White House’s $1.8 trillion relief offer, but Republicans revolted against it.
abstract: Senate Republicans revolted over the contours of a $1.8 trillion relief proposal that is the Trump administration’s latest and largest offer to House Democrats, further jeopardizing already dim prospects for an agreement on a broad stimulus bill before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans revolted over the contours of a $1.8 trillion relief proposal that is the Trump administration’s latest and largest offer to House Democrats, further jeopardizing already dim prospects for an agreement on a broad stimulus bill before Election Day.

headline: N.F.L. Reshuffles Schedule After Rash of Coronavirus Cases
abstract: The league rescheduled several games in the already crowded calendar as it postponed a Patriots-Broncos matchup.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has rescheduled Monday’s game between the Denver Broncos and the New England Patriots to next week, and reshuffled several other games on the league’s cluttered schedule to accommodate a rash of positive tests for the coronavirus.

headline: N.F.L. Week 5 Results: Cowboys Field Goal Salvages Win Over Giants
abstract: Dallas beat the winless Giants but lost starting quarterback Dak Prescott, who was carted off the field with what appeared to be a severe injury to his right leg.
lead_paragraph: Around the league, as Bill Pennington writes, “Through four weeks of the 2020 season, the average combined score of a game is 51.3 points, an increase of 16 percent over the same period a year ago and a roughly 20 percent increase in the average score of games since 2000.”

headline: Amy Coney Barrett lays out her vision of the court in a copy of her opening statement released ahead of her confirmation hearings.
abstract: Amy Coney Barrett lays out her vision of the court in a copy of her opening statement released ahead of her confirmation hearings.
lead_paragraph: In Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s opening statement before the Senate Judiciary Committee this week, as she begins hearings for her nomination to the Supreme Court, she plans to speak of having “humility about the responsibility I have been asked to undertake,” according to a copy of the statement released in advance of the first hearing tomorrow.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Follow J. Kenji López-Alt’s lead, and set up some “culinary building blocks” — shortcuts to fast flavor — to improve your weeknight cooking.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. J. Kenji López-Alt wrote a fascinating article for The Times last week about improving your cooking by using “culinary building blocks” — homemade and store-bought sauces and compotes and condiments — to build fast flavor.

headline: ‘Call Me a Dreamer’: A Shattered Beirut Neighborhood Rebuilds
abstract: Many worry that a full recovery won’t be possible, but residents of one of Beirut’s most diverse and cosmopolitan areas are moving back in and trying to repair the damage from the August explosion.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After the August port explosion that disfigured much of Beirut, many compared the city to a phoenix that would rise again.

abstract: Perhaps no one was more surprised to learn that Joyce Jones wanted to defund the police than Joyce Jones herself.

headline: Three Rockefellers Say Banks Must Stop Financing Fossil Fuels
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Global Warming']
abstract: JPMorgan Chase and other big banks should use their lending power to force cuts in greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: One hundred years ago, as a deadly influenza gripped the world and the stock market dropped precipitously, our great-grandfather John D. Rockefeller Jr. began investing in New York banks to diversify the family’s business away from fossil fuels in the midst of the economic uncertainty.

headline: Kamala Harris Should Grill Amy Coney Barrett
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senate Democrats would be wise to let Joe Biden’s running mate lead their questioning at the nominee’s confirmation hearing.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans have already cast votes ahead of the election, and democracy demands that one of the candidates on the ballot be the Democrats’ lead questioner at the confirmation hearing for Amy Coney Barrett that begins Monday.

headline: New York’s Commercial Rents Are ‘Too Damn High’
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Small Business', 'Landlords', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: They’re making it harder for the city to recover. Here’s how to lower them.
lead_paragraph: What’s getting in the way of a recovery for New York City’s small businesses? Continued weak demand is surely the main factor. But the fact that commercial rents remain artificially inflated compounds the problem. More businesses could survive, more commercial spaces repurposed for other uses and more new businesses started if commercial rents actually reflected market conditions.

headline: Leave Judge Barrett’s Faith Out of This
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Examine her jurisprudence, not her religious practice.
lead_paragraph: One of the most enduring descriptions of American pluralism was composed by a religious Jew. In 1790, Moses Seixas led the dwindling Jewish community of the Touro Synagogue in Newport, R.I. He had struggled to sustain the religious observances that endowed Jews with a distinct identity: public readings of the Torah, circumcisions of baby boys, and the keeping of kosher dietary laws. Soon Newport’s remaining Jews would depart for other communities as opportunity there dwindled, and Seixas could have easily been forgotten in the annals of American history.

headline: ‘I Feel Like I Have Dementia’: Brain Fog Plagues Covid Survivors
abstract: The condition is affecting thousands of patients, impeding their ability to work and function in daily life.
lead_paragraph: After contracting the coronavirus in March, Michael Reagan lost all memory of his 12-day vacation in Paris, even though the trip was just a few weeks earlier.

headline: Change the Supreme Court? You Have Ideas
keywords: ['Constitution (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Term Limits (Political Office)', 'Constitutional Amendments']
abstract: We asked readers if and how you would alter the way justices are chosen and how the court works, and received more than 1,500 responses. Some of your suggestions would require constitutional amendments.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Concerts Were Canceled Months Ago. So Where Are the Refunds?
abstract: As fans await money for called-off shows at the Nassau Coliseum, officials say they are the responsibility of the company run by a Russian oligarch who had operated the venue.
lead_paragraph: Early this year, Joanne Brakatselos, a rock fan in Queens, spent just over $1,000 for tickets to six concerts. In the months since those events were canceled because of the coronavirus, she got her money back for every show.

headline: Socially Distant, Except for the Dogs, Sheep and Chickens
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Theater', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: On the farm with Isabella Rossellini, as she readies a streaming theater piece with cameos from her animal friends.
lead_paragraph: BELLPORT, N.Y. — From the sheep’s point of view, rehearsal had been going on long enough. On the lawn in front of Isabella Rossellini’s house, an elegant barn-to-home conversion in a chicly rural corner of Long Island, a few of them stood around baaing, waiting for their person to emerge.

headline: Feared Shabab Exploit Somali Banking and Invest in Real Estate, U.N. Says
abstract: Despite sanctions, Shabab militants have found ways to extort, move and invest money using Somalia’s banking system, a United Nations panel says.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Shabab, the Somalia-based militant group that is Al Qaeda’s most powerful ally in Africa, is not only collecting millions of dollars in tariffs and payoffs but moving the money through local banks and even investing it in real estate and businesses, according to a new United Nations Security Council report.

headline: Trump surrogates deflected questions about the coronavirus and the debate.
abstract: As President Trump continued to trail by double digits in polls, several of his surrogates tried on Sunday to shift attention away from the details of his coronavirus infection and his administration’s handling of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: As President Trump continued to trail by double digits in polls, several of his surrogates tried on Sunday to shift attention away from the details of his coronavirus infection and his administration’s handling of the pandemic.

headline: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer says she is concerned about the rise of right-wing armed groups in Michigan.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan, who was targeted last week in a planned kidnapping operation by an armed group, whose alleged members have been arrested, said on Sunday that she remains worried about the presence of right-wing militias in her state.

headline: Four Tricky Issues for the Biden-Harris Ticket
abstract: The campaign has learned it’s not always easy appealing to progressives in the party and moderates in the broader electorate.
lead_paragraph: During the vice-presidential debate last week, several issues came up, including the Supreme Court, climate change and taxes, that underscored the tightrope Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kamala Harris are trying to walk as they seek to balance appeals to progressives and moderates alike.

headline: Trump’s Campaign Talk of Troop Withdrawals Doesn’t Match Military Reality
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: President Trump has brought home few American combat troops over all even as his pressure campaign against Iran risks a new Middle East conflict.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump said on Twitter last week that all American troops in Afghanistan might be home by Christmas, he was reiterating a goal that has eluded him for years — and most likely hoping that when it comes to ending military deployments, voters will give him more credit for his messaging than for his results.

headline: Jaime Harrison Raises $57 Million as Democratic Cash Floods Senate Races
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Campaign Finance', 'Voting and Voters', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The amount is the highest quarterly fund-raising total for any Senate candidate in U.S. history and part of an extraordinary surge of money pouring into Democrats’ campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Jaime Harrison, the Democrat challenging Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, raised an astonishing $57 million from July through September, the highest quarterly fund-raising total for any Senate candidate in U.S. history and part of a flood of Democratic money remaking the battle for control of the Senate.

headline: Review: A Classic Western Sheriff on the Other Side of the World
abstract: In “Mystery Road,” Aaron Pedersen plays a lawman with Indigenous roots and John Wayne style.
lead_paragraph: While America debates how it wants its television cops to look and act — or whether it wants them at all — the rest of the world is happily sending us theirs. This month alone we’ve received cop or cop-adjacent shows from Armenia (“Special Division,” MHz Choice), Brazil (“Good Morning, Verônica,” Netflix), Britain (“Code 404,” Peacock), Canada (“Coroner,” CW) and France (“The Crimson Rivers” and “The Paris Murders,” PBS Masterpiece Prime Video).

headline: For Novak Djokovic, Another Well-Meaning Effort Goes Off the Rails

lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic may look back on these last months as some of the most dreadful in his career, a series of moments that appeared to be filled with opportunity but fizzled in spectacular fashion.

keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Voting and Voters', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Law and Legislation', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: Vote-by-mail has become one of the most contentious issues of the 2020 election. But while battles rage on social media and in the courts, a group of bipartisan Michigan election officials worry they won’t have the time or resources to ensure results on election night.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has made voting by mail one of the election’s most contentious issues. More than 25 states have expanded access to universal mail voting, a move President Trump has repeatedly, and erroneously, equated with a fraudulent election.

headline: Fauci says his words were ‘taken out of context’ by the president’s campaign.
abstract: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the U.S. government’s top infectious disease expert, took issue Sunday with a decision by the Trump campaign to feature him in an advertisement without his consent and said it had misrepresented his comments.

headline: Are Amazon Jobs Worth 1,400 Loads of Traffic? French Region Is Split
abstract: The picturesque Gard desperately needs more employment. But environmentalists are pushing back at what they see as a looming blight.
lead_paragraph: FOURNÈS, France — On a sultry September morning, Claudie Cortellini headed into the vineyards to survey the grapes that go into her family’s heady Côtes du Rhône wines. In recent years, she has fought to ensure a good harvest as the climate grows warmer. But these days, she is facing an even bigger foe: a giant Amazon sorting center slated for construction near her land.

headline: Virus Hits Foreign Farmhands, Challenging Canadians’ Self-Image

abstract: Outbreaks at farms have made Canadians question how well their system is really protecting vulnerable migrant workers.
lead_paragraph: SIMCOE, Ontario — Three weeks after they began cutting asparagus in the thawing fields, Luis Gabriel Flores Flores noticed that one of his co-workers was missing. He said he found the man shivering with a fever, in bed — where he would remain for a week.

headline: Eric Trump conceded that his father ‘lost a fortune,’ but dismissed questions about influence-peddling.
abstract: President Trump’s son Eric on Sunday angrily dismissed a New York Times investigation showing that more than 200 companies, special-interest groups and foreign governments obtained favors from the Trump administration while patronizing Mr. Trump’s properties, earning the president millions of dollars.

lead_paragraph: The first two rounds of the Major League Baseball playoffs reflected the modern game: lots and lots of home runs. In 11 of the 12 series before Sunday, 54.8 percent of all runs were scored on homers.

abstract: The idea: a portrait session with the actress Isabella Rossellini that involves sheep, dogs and chickens. She was totally game. Thankfully, so were the creatures.

headline: Private Security Guard Held in Fatal Denver Shooting, Officials Say

keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Women and Girls']

headline: Sweetie
abstract: Let’s tiptoe through the clues of this Joe Hansen puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Joe Hansen is a 2020 addition to the constructor pack; his only other Times puzzle until now was back in April and similarly offbeat. This is an intricate-looking grid that presents a good challenge, mainly because the key to “getting” it isn’t laid out for you in the clues. Even though there is a two-part revealer that provides a hint, you have to do some visual and literal deduction to find your hidden set of theme entries. Some toughies in the fill, and some interesting and creative entries, contribute to the gratification of figuring everything out.

headline: An Arrest in Canada Casts a Shadow on a New York Times Star, and The Times
abstract: A top editor is now reviewing Rukmini Callimachi’s reporting on terrorism, which turned distant conflicts into accessible stories but drew criticism from colleagues.

abstract: The F.B.I. and state authorities last week arrested 13 men in connection with a domestic terrorism plot directed against the first-term governor.
lead_paragraph: BAY CITY, Mich. — The fallout from a failed domestic terrorism plot to overthrow Michigan’s state government and kidnap Gov. Gretchen Whitmer has quickly become embedded in state politics and the presidential race in a key swing state during the final weeks of the campaign.

lead_paragraph: At a time when elected officials appear stymied by the challenge of climate change, or even in denial about it, it is heartening to see a royal prince pitch in with a good initiative.

headline: How to Connect With the Co-Workers You’re Missing
abstract: What you gain with remote work — increased flexibility and productivity — comes at the expense of interacting and socializing with colleagues in person. Here are some tips to help deal with that.

headline: Trump’s Virus Treatment Revives Questions About Unchecked Nuclear Authority
keywords: ['White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Dexamethasone (Drug)', 'Twenty-Fifth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'War and Emergency Powers (US)', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: Even before the president was given mood-altering drugs, there was a movement to end the commander in chief’s sole authority to launch nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s long rants and seemingly erratic behavior last week — which some doctors believe might have been fueled by his use of dexamethasone, a steroid, to treat Covid-19 — renewed a long-simmering debate among national security experts about whether it is time to retire one of the early inventions of the Cold War: the unchecked authority of the president to launch nuclear weapons.

headline: What We Learned From Week 5 of the N.F.L. Season
abstract: Dak Prescott’s season is over, Alex Smith came back after nearly two years away, the Ravens demolished Joe Burrow and the Bengals, and the Raiders shocked the Chiefs.
lead_paragraph: Sunday got off to a rocky start when the N.F.L. announced it would delay this week’s game between the Denver Broncos and the New England Patriots because of continuing issues with the coronavirus. The decision led to a cascade of changes in the coming schedule, and is sure to be a frequent topic of conversation as teams adjust on the fly.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Season 4, Episode 4 Recap: Something Rotten
abstract: Sometimes when a bag of money smells a little suspect, that’s because it is.
lead_paragraph: Underneath the expected mélange of funny names, regional dialect, Coen references and knottily orchestrated mayhem, this season of “Fargo” has sought to make a big statement about America. That was clear from the opening sequences in Kansas City, which depict the succession of immigrant groups who turned to criminality as a path to legitimacy. Becoming a true American, the show suggests, involves surviving a cycle of discrimination and conquest — and no single group of people is going to hand power to another willingly.

headline: Barrett’s Record: A Conservative Who Would Push the Supreme Court to the Right
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Law and Legislation', 'Constitution (US)', 'ABORTION', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Gun Control', 'Capital Punishment', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As an appeals court judge, Judge Barrett has issued opinions that have reflected those of her mentor, Justice Antonin Scalia, but with few of his occasional liberal rulings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Amy Coney Barrett, President Trump’s pick for the Supreme Court, has compiled an almost uniformly conservative voting record in cases touching on abortion, gun rights, discrimination and immigration. If she is confirmed, she would move the court slightly but firmly to the right, making compromise less likely and putting at risk the right to abortion established in Roe v. Wade.

headline: Quotation of the Day: C.E.O.s Rediscover Family Mealtime, a Ritual That’s Become a ‘Priority Again’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 12, 2020.

lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV Oct. 12-18. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Regeneron’s C.E.O. says its promising Covid-19 treatment must be rationed.

headline: In Emptier Subways, Violent Crime Is Rising
keywords: ['Subways', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Vandalism', 'Sex Crimes', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Reports of homicides, rapes and burglaries are posing another challenge to regaining the confidence of passengers during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: It began in the early days of the pandemic in March, when someone lit a fire inside a subway car that killed the train operator and injured 16 others. In the following months, nearly 500 subway car windows were smashed on the No. 7 line. In August, a man tackled and tried to sexually assault a young woman at a station on the Upper East Side. And in September, a train derailed after a man threw metal clamps that he had stolen onto the tracks.

headline: The Digital Divide Starts With a Laptop Shortage
keywords: ['Laptop Computers', 'Shortages', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Learning', 'Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: A surge in worldwide demand by educators for low-cost laptops has created shipment delays and pitted desperate schools against one another. Districts with deep pockets often win out.
lead_paragraph: When the Guilford County Schools in North Carolina spent more than $27 million to buy 66,000 computers and tablets for students over the summer, the district ran into a problem: There was a shortage of cheap laptops, and the devices wouldn’t arrive until late October or November.

headline: ‘Everything Is Closed Down.’ The Lack of Youth Sports Is a Crisis.
abstract: Despite a glut of sports on TV, the lack of youth leagues and teams in the pandemic could cost us for years to come.

headline: Planned Parenthood’s Plan for Amy Coney Barrett
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ABORTION', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: As one woman, Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett, stands ready to derail reproductive rights, another, Planned Parenthood President Alexis McGill Johnson, stands ready to defend them.
lead_paragraph: Roe v. Wade is under threat. As Republican senators scramble to fill Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s seat with a conservative justice who would tilt the court six to three, the nation’s largest abortion and reproductive rights provider has its own power playbook. In this episode of Sway, Kara Swisher speaks to Planned Parenthood’s president and C.E.O., Alexis McGill Johnson.

headline: Charles Koch’s Big Bet on Barrett
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Corporations', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: For almost 50 years, the multibillionaire has been pushing for a court unfriendly to regulation of the market. He may be on the brink of victory.
lead_paragraph: Charles Koch has activated his political network to support Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s nomination, and to tip the scales on her nomination battle in the U.S. Senate. While much of the commentary about Judge Barrett’s nomination has focused on the real prospect that Roe v. Wade may be undermined or overturned, Mr. Koch has other concerns. Judge Barrett’s nomination is the latest battleground in his decades-long war to reshape American society in a way that ensures that corporations can operate with untrammeled freedom. It may be a pivotal one.

headline: In Terms of Child Mortality, It’s a Good Time for Public Health
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Infant Mortality', 'Babies and Infants', 'Parenting', 'Epidemics', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Smallpox', 'Cholera', 'ANTIBIOTICS']
abstract: Despite the crises of 2020, parents can realistically expect that children born today will outlive them. That wasn’t always the case.
lead_paragraph: Rule one of Hollywood screenwriting is, “don’t kill the kid.” Well, actually, rule one is more famously, whatever you do, don’t kill the dog. But if you happen to be a pediatrician who occasionally moonlights as a screenwriter, children come up more frequently; my limited life writing television scripts has involved being hired because someone wants high-stakes pediatric drama, and then being asked to delete story lines about seriously ill children, because sick and dying children are hard to watch. It’s not easy to construct high-stakes pediatric drama without endangering children, though I’ve tried.

headline: When Symptoms of Covid-19 Don’t Go Away
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Lungs', 'Heart', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Guillain-Barre Syndrome']

keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']

keywords: ['Birth Rates', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Child Car Seats', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

headline: Karen Elson on Body Shaming, Nudity and Speaking Up for Herself

Such is the case with Karen Elson, the red-haired mannequin who dominated fashion imagery at the turn of the millennium, and who has just written a no-holds-barred autobiography.

headline: When the U.S. and China Fight, It Is the Environment That Suffers
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Pollution', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Environment']

headline: What It’s Like to Watch Hurricanes Batter Your Hometown — Over and Over
abstract: Epic storms have battered Lake Charles, La., my hometown. Each hurricane season, a part of my chest tightens and I brace for what may be next.
lead_paragraph: Storm after storm after storm seems to head right for the small Louisiana town where I was born. In late August, Hurricane Laura hit Lake Charles hard. Over the weekend, many homes were again flooded after Hurricane Delta rolled through. Years ago, a powerful hurricane pushed my family into Lake Charles, and later, another pushed us out.

headline: The Billionaire Who Stood by Jeffrey Epstein
abstract: Leon Black, whose $9 billion fortune could buy the best counsel in the world, paid at least $50 million to Mr. Epstein for advice and services after most others had deserted him.

The two men had known each other for decades, and investors of Mr. Black’s investment company, Apollo Global Management, wanted to know how close they had been.

headline: No Home, No Wi-Fi: Pandemic Adds to Strain on Poor College Students
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'E-Learning', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Community Colleges', 'Homeless Persons', 'Poverty', 'Historically Black Colleges and Universities', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Generation Z']
abstract: Some low-income students have dropped out, and there are growing concerns about hunger and homelessness.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Macario was struggling to follow online classes through the tiny screen of her smartphone. She had no laptop and no Wi-Fi at home, and the library where she normally studied at her community college in Los Angeles was closed. So two weeks into the coronavirus shutdown in the spring, she dropped all of her courses to avoid failing.

headline: A Glance at Daily Life Among the Caretakers of Britain’s Small Islands
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Islands', 'Boats and Boating', 'Birdwatching', 'Birds', 'Careers and Professions', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Stationed off the coast of Britain, island wardens manage the preservation of their small speck of land — while coping with extreme weather and limited access to the mainland.
lead_paragraph: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Alex Ingram shares a collection of images from small British islands.

headline: After a Year in the Ice, the Biggest-Ever Arctic Science Mission Ends
abstract: The research ship Polarstern docked in Germany after nearly 13 months studying the rapidly changing region.
lead_paragraph: After a year spent drifting across the top of the world, frozen in sea ice, a German research ship returned home on Monday, ending the largest Arctic science expedition in history, one aimed at better understanding a region that is rapidly changing as the world warms.

headline: U.S. Auction Theorists Win the 2020 Nobel in Economics
abstract: Paul Milgrom and Robert Wilson were honored for work that has pushed auctions into new and useful territory.
lead_paragraph: Two American economists, Paul R. Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson, were awarded the Nobel in economic science on Monday for improvements to auction theory and inventions of new auction formats — innovations that have had huge practical applications when it comes to allocating scarce resources.

headline: Why the Left Is Losing on Abortion
abstract: The volatile issue is front and center in Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s nomination to the Supreme Court. An abortion rights leader tells us how we got to this point.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans say that abortion should be legal with some restrictions, but President Trump’s nominee for the Supreme Court, Amy Coney Barrett, signed a statement in a 2006 newspaper advertisement opposing “abortion on demand.” Her accession would bolster a conservative majority among the justices.

headline: Florida Sees Signals of a Climate-Driven Housing Crisis
abstract: Home sales in areas most vulnerable to sea-level rise began falling around 2013, researchers found. Now, prices are following a similar downward path.
lead_paragraph: If rising seas cause America’s coastal housing market to dive — or, as many economists warn, when — the beginning might look a little like what’s happening in the tiny town of Bal Harbour, a glittering community on the northernmost tip of Miami Beach.

headline: On Facebook, Misinformation Is More Popular Now Than in 2016
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Research']
abstract: People are engaging more on Facebook with content from outlets that publish falsehoods and distortions, even though the social network has tried limiting misinformation, new research found.
lead_paragraph: During the 2016 presidential election, Russian operatives used Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and other social media platforms to spread disinformation to divide the American electorate. Since then, the social media companies have spent billions of dollars and hired tens of thousands of people to help clean up their act.

headline: Making Sense of Sweden
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: The White House event to celebrate Amy Coney Barrett’s Supreme Court nomination — a gathering that appears to have spread the coronavirus — would have violated the law in Sweden.

headline: Aaron Pedersen Is a Different Kind of Archetypal Leading Man
keywords: ['Television', 'Indigenous Australians', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: The star of the Australian police drama “Mystery Road” harks back to the rugged icons of old westerns. He is also Aboriginal, which makes the role more complicated — and rare.
lead_paragraph: Hat, boots, holster. Furrowed brow and taciturn demeanor. The grizzled, bearded detective Jay Swan may hail from Down Under and travel in an S.U.V. instead of a horse, but he is an immediately recognizable archetype — straight out of a Hollywood western.

headline: Microsoft Takes Down a Risk to the Election, and Finds the U.S. Doing the Same
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Elections', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Fearing Russian ransomware attacks on the election, the company and U.S. Cyber Command mounted similar pre-emptive strikes. It is not clear how long they may work.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft and a team of companies and law enforcement groups have disabled — at least temporarily — one of the world’s largest hacking operations, an effort run by Russian-speaking cybercriminals that officials feared could disrupt the presidential election in three weeks.

headline: Barrett’s record: a conservative who would push the Supreme Court to the right.
abstract: Judge Amy Coney Barrett, President Trump’s pick for the Supreme Court, has compiled an almost uniformly conservative voting record in cases touching on abortion, gun rights, discrimination and immigration. If she is confirmed, she would move the court slightly but firmly to the right, making compromise less likely and putting at risk the right to abortion established in Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Judge Amy Coney Barrett, President Trump’s pick for the Supreme Court, has compiled an almost uniformly conservative voting record in cases touching on abortion, gun rights, discrimination and immigration. If she is confirmed, she would move the court slightly but firmly to the right, making compromise less likely and putting at risk the right to abortion established in Roe v. Wade.

headline: Can Trump cede the spotlight to Judge Barrett’s hearings?
abstract: As the Supreme Court confirmation hearings begin for Judge Amy Coney Barrett, can President Trump cede the spotlight? And what is Democrats’ strategy?
lead_paragraph: The event that conservatives hoped would reshape the 2020 election is upon us: The Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Judge Amy Coney Barrett began Monday morning and promise to last most of the week. Republicans have regarded her nomination as an opportunity to reinvigorate voters on the right and shift focus away from the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Handcuffed by a New Rule, Rays Manage to Escape

lead_paragraph: This is the rule that was meant to seem weird in 2020. Before the four-month shutdown, plus-size playoffs, cardboard cutouts, phantom runners, neutral sites and so on, the three-batter-minimum was the radical change for this season.

The neighborhood is family-oriented, with annual Fourth of July and Easter events. Within walking distance is West Jetty View Park, a strip of waterfront that includes the Wedge, a spot known for its high waves and for inspiring the surf music legend Dick Dale’s 1963 hit of the same name.

headline: Cooking Can Help
abstract: Mondays land heavily sometimes. You may find joy in making something new.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. You doing all right? Mondays land heavily sometimes, especially seven months into this pandemic that stalks the world. It’s been exhausting. We’re working more, or not working enough or at all. We’re staying safe while others aren’t. We’re worrying, staring, thinking, overthinking. We are on, all the time. The weekend comes and maybe we get outside and into the world and maybe that’s a relief, but then it’s over and the circus music blares once more. So I hope you’re all right. I hope you’ll take the time to be all right. That’s work, too, sometimes.

headline: Spirit Halloween Rises from the Dead. Again. And Again.

headline: Joe Morgan, Hall of Fame Second Baseman, Is Dead at 77
abstract: Morgan, who later became a well-known television commentator, was among the smallest great players in the history of the game and among the greatest second basemen.
lead_paragraph: Joe Morgan, the Hall of Fame second baseman who was the National League’s Most Valuable Player for two consecutive seasons and the engine of the Big Red Machine — as the Cincinnati Reds of the 1970s, one of baseball’s most powerful teams, were known — died on Sunday at his home in Danville, Calif. He was 77.

headline: How Russell Wilson’s Latest Clutch Drive Beat the Vikings

lead_paragraph: The Seattle Seahawks trailed the Minnesota Vikings by 26-21 on Sunday night and were stuck at their 6-yard line. The bad news: There was only 1 minute 57 seconds to go in the game. The good news: Russell Wilson is the team’s quarterback.

headline: Sauce Makers and Scoundrels: Four Hot Romance Novels

lead_paragraph: The start of the school year is always autumn’s great punctuation mark: I tend to think of it as the opening of a pair of brackets, but this year with all the confusion and panic it feels more like an interrobang. We’ll have to scrabble together what scraps of learning we can — just like the scientists, scholars, sauce makers and stroke survivors featured in this month’s romances.

headline: Don DeLillo, an Old Hand at Paranoia and Dread, Meets Us Where We Are
abstract: In “The Silence,” two wealthy couples watch the Super Bowl together as power grids mysteriously go down all over the world.
lead_paragraph: One day in the aughts, a colleague at The New York Times Book Review, D.J.R. Bruckner, known to all as Don, wandered over to my cubicle. Don was very tall, slightly stooped, had enormous hands and feet, and had been on Nixon’s enemies list. He was visibly shaking. He pointed to his right. “If I have to read one more 2,000-word review of a John Updike book,” he said, “I am going to throw myself out that window.” I’ve omitted his obscenities.

At the beginning of the pandemic, the city did not have enough volunteers and officials to staff its 180 polling sites, leading it to shutter 175 of them.

headline: Britain’s New Measures to Control Virus Inflame North-South Tensions
abstract: Boris Johnson campaigned on a promise to “level up” struggling northern areas, but his three-tier plan threatens to keep them in economically debilitating lockdowns.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Monday ordered pubs, bars and gyms in the high-risk city of Liverpool to be closed, a move that inflamed tensions with local officials and laid bare how the second wave of the coronavirus pandemic is hitting Britain’s north harder than London or the rest of the south.
