keywords: ['Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: In their prepared remarks, the leaders of Facebook, Twitter and Google detailed why they supported Section 230.
lead_paragraph: At Wednesday’s Senate hearing, the chief executives of Twitter, Facebook and Google will deliver a full-throated defense of speech on their platforms, according to their prepared testimony, which was made public on Tuesday.

headline: Watch Full Video: Tech C.E.O.s Testify Before the Senate
abstract: Executives from Facebook, Twitter and Google testified to senators on the Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation.
lead_paragraph: Executives from Facebook, Twitter and Google testified to senators on the Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation.

headline: Gun Rooms Turned Bedrooms off the English Coast
abstract: Spitbank Fort, a refurbished 19th-century military fortress off the southern coast of England, is on the market for $5.2 million.
lead_paragraph: Spitbank Fort, a refurbished 19th-century military fortress off the southern coast of England, is on the market for $5.2 million.

headline: House Hunting in England: A Refurbished Army Fortress in the English Channel
abstract: In the harbor city of Portsmouth, the housing market is rebounding thanks in large part to Londoners looking for an escape.
lead_paragraph: This circular man-made island, known as Spitbank Fort, sits about a half-mile off the southern coast of England in the Solent, a narrow waterway feeding the English Channel. One of three similar islands built by the British military during the 1860s and ’70s, the refurbished fortress has 33,000 square feet of living space covering three floors, with 12 bedrooms, two kitchens, a pool, a central courtyard and multiple leisure, event and dining areas.

headline: 10 Classical Concerts to Stream in November
abstract: Highlights include Philip Glass at the Metropolitan Opera, the Seattle Symphony and the pianist Vicky Chow.
lead_paragraph: With many opera houses and concert halls still closed by the coronavirus pandemic for months to come, the musical action has moved online. That’s been the case since March, of course — but as the weather cools and outdoor presentations grow more difficult, artists and institutions are creating digital presentations with more care and intention.

headline: The San Francisco Symphony Plunges Into a New World
abstract: The virtual premiere of Nico Muhly’s “Throughline,” Esa-Pekka Salonen’s first presentation as music director, is testing the limits of pandemic music-making.
lead_paragraph: Esa-Pekka Salonen didn’t expect to make his entrance at the San Francisco Symphony with a virtual premiere.

headline: As Climate Disasters Pile Up, a Radical Proposal Gains Traction
abstract: The idea of modifying Earth’s atmosphere to cool the planet, once seen as too risky to seriously consider, is attracting new money and attention.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the effects of climate change become more devastating, prominent research institutions and government agencies are focusing new money and attention on an idea once dismissed as science fiction: Artificially cooling the planet, in the hopes of buying humanity more time to cut greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Michelangelo Pistoletto Endures. Even Covid Couldn’t Stop Him.
abstract: His career covers more than 60 years, ranging from Pop to Arte Povera. A New York gallery has mounted a rare show of his work.
lead_paragraph: For someone who is 87 and who survived a severe bout of Covid-19 that put him in the hospital for a month, the Italian artist Michelangelo Pistoletto was steadily upbeat on the phone, speaking from a respite on the Ligurian coast.

headline: He Helped Create Lollapalooza. Now He Wants to Save Live Music.
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'AGENTS (BUSINESS)', 'Lollapalooza (Music Festival)', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Venture Capital', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Many small venues where artists get their start are in peril. Marc Geiger, a longtime music executive, is starting a venture he hopes lives up to its name: SaveLive.
lead_paragraph: For small music venues, the situation is dire. Starved for revenue since March, and with no lifeline from Congress, independent clubs across the country are shuttering by the dozen — devastating fans and artists alike and delivering a brutal blow to the ecosystem that develops tomorrow’s Grammy winners and underground heroes.

headline: How Musk Oxen Make It Through Arctic Nights and Never-Ending Days
abstract: Scientists wondered whether animals living above the Arctic Circle had the same circadian rhythms as the rest of us.
lead_paragraph: In the distant reaches of northeastern Greenland, musk oxen amble across the tundra, grazing as they go. As Arctic creatures, they need to gather enough energy to make it through cold, dark winters. So when the bright summers come, they eat as if their lives depend on it — as in fact they do.

headline: Your New Favorite Sauce
abstract: Yotam Ottolenghi’s roasted red-pepper sauce can turn just about any meal into a special occasion.
lead_paragraph: Yotam Ottolenghi brought us a smart new recipe this week for a giant couscous cake with roasted pepper sauce (above). What’s great about it is, you can use that amazing sauce on anything you like. You could spoon it on pan-fried tofu, Yotam wrote, or pair it with leftover meatballs. You could eat it with eggs in the morning, or with a cheese sandwich at lunch.

headline: Mark Morris Dance Group Celebrates Its 40th Anniversary Online
abstract: Mr. Morris has made new video dances, and the company will also stream classic works from the repertory.
lead_paragraph: The Mark Morris Dance Group will celebrate its 40th anniversary with a digital season, its first since the coronavirus shutdown. Not that the company has been absent from the digital world. In May, it released four new dances by Mr. Morris, the company’s artistic director, made using Zoom, and has been streaming archival material.

headline: ‘I can never do enough’: I.C.U. workers record their anguish as the coronavirus surges.
abstract: A journal that sits in a staff room just off the intensive care unit at a Milwaukee hospital tells the story of the devastating surge of the coronavirus that much of the country is experiencing. In longhand, the nurses and doctors who are tending to desperately ill Covid-19 patients share their thoughts in the journal, as a way to help one another through this.
lead_paragraph: A journal that sits in a staff room just off the intensive care unit at a Milwaukee hospital tells the story of the devastating surge of the coronavirus that much of the country is experiencing. In longhand, the nurses and doctors who are tending to desperately ill Covid-19 patients share their thoughts in the journal, as a way to help one another through this.

headline: Several people went to hospitals after a Trump rally in Omaha where hundreds were stranded in the cold.
abstract: Several people went to hospitals after a Trump rally in Omaha where hundreds were stranded in the cold.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA —  After hundreds of people who attended a Trump rally in Omaha Tuesday night were left stranded on an airport tarmac for hours in near-freezing temperatures, at least six people were taken to a hospital and about two dozen others sought medical attention, according to local authorities, rally attendees and reports from journalists at the scene.

headline: As Supreme Court Weighs Election Cases, a New Life for Bush v. Gore
keywords: ['Elections, Courts and the Judiciary', 'Presidential Election of 2000', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: After two decades of legal obscurity, the ruling that handed the 2000 election to George W. Bush is getting fresh attention.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s decision in Bush v. Gore 20 years ago was supposed to work like the tape recorder in “Mission: Impossible.” It was meant to produce a president and then self-destruct.

headline: Social Security Seemed Like a Future Problem. The Virus Changed That.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Social Security (US)', 'Retirement', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Recession and Depression', 'Payroll Tax']
abstract: Even before the pandemic, Social Security’s finances were under growing pressure. The next president and Congress will play a crucial role in what happens next.
lead_paragraph: Social Security has always seemed like a future problem, with experts long predicting a benefits squeeze in the decades ahead. But the coronavirus has put tens of millions of Americans out of work, and economists are predicting that the recovery will take years.

headline: The election’s big twist: the racial gap between Republicans and Democrats is shrinking.
abstract: American politicians have often sought to exploit the nation’s racial and ethnic divides for political gain. During the Trump era, voters are not responding as expected.
lead_paragraph: American politicians have often sought to exploit the nation’s racial and ethnic divides for political gain. During the Trump era, voters are not responding as expected.

headline: The Issue That Might Sink the Brexit Trade Talks: Fishing
keywords: ['Fishing, Commercial', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: In cash terms, the fishing industry contributes little to the British economy. So why is it proving such a sticking point in negotiations?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the greater scheme of things, fishing is a tiny industry. Just 12,000 people in Britain fish from 6,000 vessels, contributing less than half of one percent of gross domestic product — less than the upmarket London department store Harrods, according to one analysis. The same holds true for most continental European nations.

headline: ‘City Hall’ Review: Frederick Wiseman, for the People
abstract: In his latest movie, the celebrated documentarian explores the ideas and ideals, the faces and spaces of Boston’s City Hall.
lead_paragraph: For more than a half-century, Frederick Wiseman has been telling the story of the United States, one documentary and fluorescent-lit room at a time. Since directing his first film, “Titicut Follies” (1967), about a Massachusetts prison for the criminally insane, he has trained his precise, unflinching eye on different dimensions of the country, with a focus on social institutions. Again and again, he has returned to the spaces in which human beings organize their lives, charting the great, bright ebb and flow of people and power in offices, schools, cities — all worlds within worlds.

headline: A Cutting-Edge Tactic to Get Out the Vote in 2020: Handwritten Letters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Letters', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: To mobilize new or inactive voters this election, adding a personal touch has been key.
lead_paragraph: The hand-addressed envelope stood out to Bria East, next to the sleek fliers featuring smiling politicians promising criminal justice reform or tax cuts. It had been awhile since anyone had written to Ms. East, 26; the letter, signed only “Maria,” evoked her childhood pen pals.

headline: New York’s School Reopening is Not Proceeding as Planned
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Education', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Just 26 percent of students have attended any in-person class.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after this newsletter was published on Monday, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York dropped two bombshells.

headline: Protest Erupts in Poland After New Abortion Ban
abstract: Tens of thousands of people across Poland have defied Covid-19 restrictions to protest against a new court ruling that imposes a near-total ban on abortion.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people across Poland have defied Covid-19 restrictions to protest against a new court ruling that imposes a near-total ban on abortion.

headline: One Thing You Can Do: Vote
abstract: Also this week, what’s at stake in a shake-up at NOAA.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Prepping Your Pet for a Walk Down the Aisle? Hire a Concierge
abstract: Pet attendant services take care of everything your furry friend needs (grooming, feedings, walks and more) before, during and after your wedding day.
lead_paragraph: On her way to the wedding at Holiday Acres Christmas Tree Farm in Manvel, Texas, on Nov. 10, 2018, Madison Logan Edwards picked up Ruger, a nine-month-old golden retriever. “I had to pick him up a little early,” she said. “Because of his personality profile, I knew he’d be hyper. So I took him to the dog park and then brushed him out and got him all ready.”

headline: So You Think You Can Run a Dance Cardio Business
abstract: Anna Kaiser, the founder of AKT, sold her brand to Xponential Fitness before the pandemic. Now she wants it back.
lead_paragraph: Anna Kaiser, a celebrity fitness trainer, is known for dispensing advice like “top tips for busy moms who can’t find time to exercise” and for longtime clients like Shakira, whom she trained for the Super Bowl Halftime Show, or Kelly Ripa, whom she guided in a home workout using wine bottles and a dish towel.

headline: People Are Still Having Sex. So Why Are S.T.D. Rates Dropping?
keywords: ['Tests (Medical)', 'Disease Rates', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases', 'Sex', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Shortages', 'your-feed-healthcare', 'Gonorrhea', 'Chlamydia', 'Syphilis', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome']
abstract: Public health officials believe many cases are going undetected as clinics close during the pandemic and testing supplies are diverted to coronavirus screening.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in years, rates of chlamydia, gonorrhea and syphilis, which had been on track in 2020 to hit record highs in the United States, have taken an abrupt downturn.

headline: Business Partner of Giuliani Associate Is Expected to Plead Guilty
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry']
abstract: David Correia was charged with duping investors in a start-up he founded with Lev Parnas, an associate of Rudolph W. Giuliani.
lead_paragraph: A business partner of Lev Parnas, who helped Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, dig up dirt on the president’s political rivals, is expected to plead guilty on Thursday to defrauding investors in a start-up, according to two people with knowledge of the case.

headline: It’s Easier to Parent With a Partner in Many Ways, Except This One
keywords: ['Single Persons', 'Children and Childhood', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Parenting', 'Babies and Infants', 'Single Parents', 'Single Mothers']
abstract: I was my son’s only parent and our bond was strong. Now, I’m worried my daughter and I won’t have that connection.
lead_paragraph: It’s been almost eight months now, and my daughter and I still don’t have our song. Her older brother, Sam, and I have an album’s worth. I crooned a rotating playlist of off-pitch lullabies — “American Girl,” “Sweet Baby James,” “Me and Bobby McGee” — to him every night for the first two years of his life. But when Eve needs extra help drifting off, I can just hand her off to her dad. This is amazing. And it worries me.

headline: A Biden Win Could Renew a Democratic Split on Trade
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States International Relations', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Democrats have been unified by their desire to oust President Trump. But if that happens, deep divisions on the issue of trade are likely to reappear.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign has unified the Democratic Party around a shared goal of ousting President Trump from office. But as the campaign nears an end, a deep split between progressives and moderate Democrats on trade policy is once again spilling out into the open.

headline: Lil Buck Feels the Dancing Spirit All Over Again
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Movies']
abstract: In “Nobody Knows,” the jookin star presents a short film that explores his struggles as a Black man and his relationship to dance.
lead_paragraph: Lil Buck, the willowy dancer who spins on the toes of his sneakers as if they were point shoes, was a little boy — probably around 6 — when a church choir filled him with such spirit that he got up and began to dance.

headline: Pennsylvania’s top elections official urges voters to drop off absentee ballots in person.
abstract: Pennsylvania’s top election on Wednesday urged voters who have not yet mailed back their absentee ballots to deliver them to a drop box or county election office rather than rely on the Postal Service, as a court fight over ballot deadlines looms.
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania’s top election on Wednesday urged voters who have not yet mailed back their absentee ballots to deliver them to a drop box or county election office rather than rely on the Postal Service, as a court fight over ballot deadlines looms.

headline: We Need Policy, Not WrestleMania
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Censorship', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Lawmakers could debate an important law that affects speech on the internet. Or they could yell.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: U.S. Charges 8 in Plot to Harass Chinese Dissidents
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations', 'Fugitives', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Law enforcement officials said that Chinese operatives hired private investigators to locate their targets and then stalked, surveilled and threatened them.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department announced charges on Wednesday against eight people accused of conspiring to conduct an aggressive harassment campaign on behalf of China to pressure political dissidents and fugitives in the United States to return home to face trial.

headline: ‘City So Real’ Is an Election Story Pulsing With Life
abstract: In Steve James’s documentary of the 2019 Chicago election and its aftermath, politics is local, and it’s fascinating.
lead_paragraph: Midway through the documentary “City So Real,” Christie Hefner, the former chief executive of Playboy, hosts a “salon dinner” for some Chicago luminaries. With a stunning high-rise view as a backdrop, they talk about their town’s future: whether it will become a gleaming “global city” or descend into “chaos.”

headline: Biden Holds 8-Point Lead in Michigan as He Tries to Reconstruct the ‘Blue Wall’
abstract: While President Trump counted Michigan as one of his most surprising victories in 2016, he is struggling to maintain support among white voters in the state this year.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. is leading President Trump by eight percentage points in Michigan, according to a new poll from The New York Times and Siena College on Wednesday, the latest survey to show Mr. Trump’s troubled standing in Midwestern battleground states as white voters without college degrees, his political bulwark, turn away from him.

headline: Review: From Neil LaBute, a Case of He Said, She Said, No One Said
abstract: The story of a marriage saved by the pandemic, “True Love Will Find You in the End” features a live audience but recorded actors.
lead_paragraph: NEW PALTZ, N.Y. — If you’d never seen a Neil LaBute play before “True Love Will Find You in the End,” which opened recently at the Denizen Theater here, you might be surprised by the huge twist that comes exactly two-thirds of the way through. I, on the other hand, having seen so many, dreaded the twist the whole time, as if watching an atomic clock count down to a cataclysm.

headline: Disinformation Moves From Social Networks to Texts
abstract: Last week, a political action committee called the American Principles Project unveiled a new video on Twitter falsely claiming that Democratic presidential nominee Joseph R. Biden Jr. supported sex changes for 8-year-olds.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a political action committee called the American Principles Project unveiled a new video on Twitter falsely claiming that Democratic presidential nominee Joseph R. Biden Jr. supported sex changes for 8-year-olds.

headline: It’s Biden! No, It’s Trump! Here Are Your Predictions
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Our readers suggest a wide range of scenarios that include landslides, pardons, claims of fraud, violence and the courts.
lead_paragraph: We asked readers for their prophecies, not their wishes. Below is a selection from the more than 500 responses.

headline: Bile and the Beat Fight Heartbreak on Sam Smith’s ‘Love Goes’
abstract: The sound of the singer and songwriter’s third album is sweeping and luxurious: intimacy blown up to cinematic scale.
lead_paragraph: “Put your hands in the air if you sometimes ever get sad like me,” Sam Smith urges in “So Serious,” one of the triumphantly forlorn songs on their third studio album, “Love Goes.” (Smith’s preferred pronouns are they/their.) Romance is all that matters in Smith’s musical universe. Love is all-important and all-consuming, even — perhaps especially — when it’s going wrong. Obsession prevails, even more than passion.

headline: The 13 Scariest Horror Movies on Netflix Right Now
abstract: Halloween is nigh. These screamers are bound to get your blood curdling.
lead_paragraph: Netflix has done a fine job in recent years of stockpiling horror films — from established classics to newer pictures discovered at international film festivals. But which are the scariest? It’s a pleasure to watch a smart, artful and culturally relevant fright flick. But it’s even better when it spooks you into leaving the lights on after bedtime. Looking to be thoroughly terrorized this Halloween season? Here are 13 devilish films that will have even the most stoic souls jumping at shadows.

headline: Palestinian Leaders Are Banking on Biden Win Next Week
abstract: A Biden victory could bring economic relief for Palestinians and friendlier relations with Washington, though not a return to 2016. A Trump win? They’d rather not think about it.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The Palestinians are counting on a Trump defeat next Tuesday. They don’t even want to think about Plan B.

headline: After 12 Years, Arrest Made in Abduction of Former Times Journalist David Rohde
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Terrorism', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A former Taliban commander was arrested in the November 2008 kidnapping of Mr. Rohde and two others in Afghanistan. He was brought to the United States to face charges.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years after a New York Times journalist and two others were taken hostage at gunpoint in Afghanistan and held for more than seven months, an Afghan man has been arrested and charged in the kidnapping, federal authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: K.G.B. Museum Closes; Lipstick Gun and Other Spy Relics Go on Sale
abstract: A Lithuanian collector is shutting his espionage museum in Manhattan after less than two years, citing the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Julius Urbaitis had a grand plan: Take his collection of K.G.B. memorabilia, acquired over three decades, and create a museum in Downtown Manhattan. People would come from all over the world to admire Cold War relics like a gun masquerading as a tube of lipstick, a replica of an umbrella with a hidden poison needle and a bronze desk lamp that supposedly sat in Joseph Stalin’s villa.

headline: Biden vowed to ‘deal honestly with the American people’ on the pandemic, and then went to vote.
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his wife, Jill, voted by appointment in Delaware on Wednesday, joining more than 70 million Americans who have already cast their ballots.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his wife, Jill, voted by appointment in Delaware on Wednesday, joining more than 70 million Americans who have already cast their ballots.

headline: The New York Store Where Furniture Is Theater
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Carpets and Rugs', 'Furniture']
abstract: The family behind ABC Carpet & Home has been enchanting the city with otherworldly finds for over a century.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.

headline: Stocks sink as lawmakers fail to reach agreement on stimulus deal, and coronavirus cases surge.
abstract: Stocks on Wall Street slid on Wednesday, erasing any remaining gains for October. Traders on Wall Street had already been on edge as the presidential election approaches and lawmakers failed to reach an agreement on what economists say is an essential plan to support businesses and out-of-work Americans.
lead_paragraph: Stocks on Wall Street slid on Wednesday, erasing any remaining gains for October. Traders on Wall Street had already been on edge as the presidential election approaches and lawmakers failed to reach an agreement on what economists say is an essential plan to support businesses and out-of-work Americans.

headline: In Rural Virginia, a Militia Tries to Recruit a New Ally: The County Government
keywords: ['Second Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Gun Control', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: After Virginia passed gun laws, conservatives began invoking the state’s colonial-era constitution, which calls for a “well regulated militia.”
lead_paragraph: HALIFAX, Va. — The board of supervisors meeting in September opened with the familiar liturgy of local government: the prayer, the Pledge of Allegiance, the roll call. The chairman was recognized for completing a course for public officials. “Constitution Week” was hereby proclaimed.

headline: M.T.A. Slashes in Service Could Erase 450,000 Jobs
keywords: ['Transit Systems', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Subways', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: A new report found that service cuts could cost the New York metropolitan area 450,000 jobs by 2022, resulting in $50 billion in lost earnings.
lead_paragraph: Since the pandemic plunged the Metropolitan Transportation Authority into its worst financial crisis, the agency has warned of doomsday cuts, including slashing service in half and scrapping much-needed infrastructure improvements, that would cripple the region’s public transit network.

headline: Biden’s Caution: Wise Campaign Tactic or Misguided Gamble?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)']
abstract: Joe Biden is counting on voters to view him as a safe and steady alternative to a president who regularly dismisses virus precautions. But his measured campaign pace may be scrutinized if he loses.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — On the Friday before Election Day, Joseph R. Biden Jr. will be in the Midwest, campaigning in both Iowa and Wisconsin as he presses his closing argument.

headline: After Backlash, Philip Guston Retrospective to Open in 2022
abstract: Four museums had delayed the touring exhibition until 2024 because of concerns about works that depict Ku Klux Klansmen.
lead_paragraph: The much-discussed Philip Guston retrospective will now open in 2022, a spokeswoman for the National Gallery of Art in Washington said on Wednesday, after the announcement last month of a delay until 2024 sparked a backlash in the art world.

headline: Virus-Stricken Wisconsin Cancels Nebraska Game
abstract: The Big Ten football schedule did not leave any room for rescheduling games upended by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic, which has ravaged the Midwest in recent weeks, upended a regional rite — the Big Ten Conference football season — on Wednesday, when No. 9 Wisconsin canceled a game and suspended team activities because of an outbreak in its ranks.

headline: Polish Women Lead Strike Over Abortion Ruling Amid Threats of Crackdown
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Strikes', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation', 'Politics and Government', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The leader of Poland’s ruling party, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, accused demonstrators of seeking the destruction of the nation and appealed to supporters to “defend Poland.”
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of women took to the streets in dozens of Polish cities and towns for a nationwide strike on Wednesday to protest a top court’s decision to ban nearly all abortions, even as the nation’s leading politician urged his conservative supporters to “defend Poland.”

headline: 2 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Robert Kobayashi’s not-to-be-missed show at Susan Inglett; and Toyin Ojih Odutola’s enigmatic, affecting drawings at Jack Shainman.
lead_paragraph: Robert Kobayashi (1925-2015) — whose work is the subject of the rigorous yet endearing show “Moe’s Meat Market” — was one of New York’s great outlier artists. He had a brief phase as an Abstract Expressionist, but in the early 1960s devised his own folk-artist version of pointillist painting, packing the signature dots of the style so close together that his textured images seemed solid. How solid? Trees resemble broccoli crowns.

headline: How Memory Maps Fashion’s Future
abstract: In celebrating the Met’s 150th anniversary, Andrew Bolton of the museum’s Costume Institute could not have designed a better show for this strange, complicated moment.
lead_paragraph: Can you cast your mind back for a moment to spring 2019?

headline: U.S. to Establish Embassy in the Maldives
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Competing for influence in the region with China, the United States will for the first time have an embassy in the tiny nation of islands off the shore of India.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States will establish an embassy in the Maldives for the first time since the countries opened diplomatic relations in 1966, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Wednesday, signifying the archipelago’s growing role in the U.S. strategy to increase America’s presence in the region.

headline: Read the Statement by Miles Taylor
abstract: Miles Taylor, the former chief of staff at the Department of Homeland Security who was the anonymous author of the New York Times Op-Ed two years ago, released a statement on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Miles Taylor, the former chief of staff at the Department of Homeland Security who was the anonymous author of the New York Times Op-Ed two years ago, released a statement on Wednesday.

headline: Miles Taylor, a Former Homeland Security Official, Reveals He Was ‘Anonymous’
keywords: ['News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Taylor, whose criticisms of President Trump in a New York Times Op-Ed article and subsequent book roiled Washington and infuriated Mr. Trump, resigned from the administration last year and endorsed Joe Biden this summer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Miles Taylor, the former chief of staff at the Department of Homeland Security, was the anonymous author of The New York Times Op-Ed article in 2018 whose description of President Trump as “impetuous, adversarial, petty and ineffective” roiled Washington and set off a hunt for his identity, Mr. Taylor confirmed Wednesday.

headline: Biden and Trump will both campaign in Tampa on Thursday, though not at the same time.
abstract: The city of Tampa will be the center of the presidential election universe on Thursday when President Trump and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. visit the crucial battleground state of Florida.
lead_paragraph: The city of Tampa will be the center of the presidential election universe on Thursday when President Trump and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. visit the crucial battleground state of Florida.

headline: ‘The American People Deserve So Much Better Than This,’ Biden Says
abstract: On Wednesday, Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic nominee for president, addressed President Trump’s rally he held in Nebraska that left his supporters standing out in the cold for hours.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic nominee for president, addressed President Trump’s rally he held in Nebraska that left his supporters standing out in the cold for hours.

headline: Utah Jazz to Sell Majority Stake to Tech Entrepreneur
abstract: The Miller family, which has owned at least 50 percent of the team since 1985, has agreed to sell a majority interest to Ryan Smith, a billionaire who co-founded a Utah software company.
lead_paragraph: Gail Miller, whose family has owned the Utah Jazz for 35 years, has agreed to sell a majority interest in the franchise to Ryan Smith, the co-founder of Qualtrics, a Utah-based software company.

headline: Republicans Blast Social Media C.E.O.s While Democrats Deride Hearing
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Social Media', 'Law and Legislation', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Censorship', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Republican senators accused the leaders of Twitter, Facebook and Google of censorship. Democrats denounced that as posturing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers hammered the chief executives of Twitter, Facebook, Google and one another at a Senate hearing on Wednesday, with Republicans claiming the companies were suppressing conservative views while Democrats accused their colleagues of holding a “sham” hearing for political gain.

headline: Listen to Soundscapes from Home
abstract: Nature and civilization create our soundtracks.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. I wrote a few weeks ago about the sounds of pigeons undertaking their vigorous morning drills, their wings slapping against my windows. It’s easy, when we’re caught up in a day’s worth of doing and getting done, to ignore the soundtrack that’s always accompanying us, whether furnished by nature or by civilization.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Devoted but Doomed
keywords: ['Love (Emotion)', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: When it comes to forbidden love, a “romantic plan isn’t enough.”
lead_paragraph: In college, Malcolm Conner penned a rambling email intended for his crush. “You have cow eyes,” he wrote. “I know that sounds like a bad thing but have you ever looked into a cow’s eyes? They are so deep and brown and beautiful.”

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: A national lockdown in France.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron announced on Wednesday that France would go into a second national lockdown starting on Friday and lasting one month. Most schools will remain open and visits in retirement homes will remain possible. Otherwise, people may not leave their homes other than for essential reasons.

headline: Statins May Have Cancer Benefits
abstract: Statin drugs, commonly prescribed for heart health, may prolong survival in some cancer patients.
lead_paragraph: Cholesterol-lowering statin drugs don’t just lower the risk of heart attacks. They may also help some cancer patients live longer.

headline: Cecilia Chiang, Who Brought Authentic Chinese Food to America, Dies at 100
abstract: With her famed Mandarin restaurant in San Francisco, she enticed diners with the dishes she grew up with, leaving the American chop suey and chow mein era far behind.
lead_paragraph: Cecilia Chiang, whose San Francisco restaurant, the Mandarin, introduced American diners in the 1960s to the richness and variety of authentic Chinese cuisine, died on Wednesday at her home in San Francisco. She was 100.

headline: Ford and Fiat Chrysler report strong profits as car sales rebound.
abstract: Ford Motor reported a big jump in profit in the third quarter after a yearslong restructuring and a rebound in sales after the pandemic shut down dealerships and factories for about two months this spring.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor reported a big jump in profit in the third quarter after a yearslong restructuring and a rebound in sales after the pandemic shut down dealerships and factories for about two months this spring.

headline: Officer Who Pressed a Knee Into Bystander’s Neck Leaves N.Y.P.D.
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: A police officer facing charges for his conduct during a social-distancing arrest has retired. The incident caused an uproar over racial disparities in such arrests.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer facing misconduct charges for kneeling on a bystander’s neck during a social-distancing arrest has retired, according to the victim’s lawyer and the officer’s labor union.

headline: Black Women’s Hair and Horror Movies: What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: An evil weave turns a shy character into a serial killer in “Bad Hair,” but the film doesn’t understand that styling locks can be a source of intimacy and communal pride.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through “Bad Hair,” Justin Simien’s horror-comedy on Hulu, a group of Black women sit in a conference room and debate the merits of changing their hairstyles to conform to the new corporate climate at Culture, the Black music television network where they work.

headline: Oklahoma Ice Storms Leave Thousands Without Power on Eve of Early Voting
abstract: Tree limbs are breaking under the weight of an unseasonable ice storm, downing power lines and cutting off electricity to nearly 375,000 households and businesses across the state.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands in Oklahoma are still without power on Wednesday after powerful ice storms downed electrical lines across the state on Monday, creating hazardous conditions the day before in-person early voting is set to begin in the state.

headline: Juan Torruella, Groundbreaking U.S. Appeals Judge, Dies at 87
keywords: ['Appeals Courts (US)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Puerto Ricans']
abstract: He was the only Hispanic to serve on the First Circuit court in Boston. In July he moved to overturn a death sentence in the Boston Marathon bombing.
lead_paragraph: Juan R. Torruella, a groundbreaking Hispanic federal judge in New England who championed the rights of his fellow Puerto Ricans and, in a recent case, joined a decision to overturn the death penalty imposed on a Boston Marathon bomber, died on Monday in San Juan. He was 87.

headline: At Arizona rally, Trump says the country is ‘rounding the turn,’ despite a record number of virus cases.
abstract: Rallying supporters in Bullhead City, Ariz., the first of two stops in the state on Wednesday, President Trump claimed that a vaccine for the coronavirus would be available “momentarily,” speeding up an already exaggerated timeline in the final days of the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Rallying supporters in Bullhead City, Ariz., the first of two stops in the state on Wednesday, President Trump claimed that a vaccine for the coronavirus would be available “momentarily,” speeding up an already exaggerated timeline in the final days of the presidential race.

headline: In Azerbaijan, a String of Explosions, Screams and Then Blood
abstract: Caught in an Armenian rocket attack, a New York Times reporting team captures the agony of an expanding, dirty war.
lead_paragraph: BARDA, Azerbaijan — The first explosion was loud enough to make us stop the car. It seemed close and sounded like a rocket, so we quickly jumped out and crouched down by a wall.

headline: France and Germany Lock Down as Second Coronavirus Wave Grows
abstract: The new steps are the toughest since the spring and follow added restrictions in Spain and Italy aimed at curbing the spread of the virus and easing the strain on hospitals.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — France announced a second nationwide lockdown and Germany moved to the very edge of one on Wednesday, testing their pandemic-weary populations as they tried to stop a mounting new wave of coronavirus infections from swamping hospitals and undoing hopes of economic recovery.

headline: France imposes a new nationwide lockdown, and braces for fresh economic pain.
abstract: President Macron pledged massive financial aid to prevent a wave of bankruptcies and layoffs from hitting the eurozone’s second-largest economy.
lead_paragraph: France was bracing for a fresh blow to its beleaguered economy as President Emmanuel Macron reimposed a nationwide lockdown through December to prevent an alarming surge of coronavirus cases from spiraling out of control.

headline: ‘I Am a Proud Patriotic American,’ Harris Says at Rally
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Kamala Harris, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, campaigned in Tucson, Ariz., Wednesday, and criticized the White House’s handling of the coronavirus and pushed back on Republicans saying she is pressing a “socialist” agenda.
lead_paragraph: Senator Kamala Harris, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, campaigned in Tucson, Ariz., Wednesday, and criticized the White House’s handling of the coronavirus and pushed back on Republicans saying she is pressing a “socialist” agenda.

headline: After a Dampened Celebration, Enduring Glory Still Awaits the Dodgers
abstract: For years, Los Angeles’s players have borne the burden of a title drought. The unusual circumstances of their World Series win won’t dim the joy and relief that come with the long-awaited championship.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Texas — At the very end, 2020 did what it does best, intruding on joy with an unwelcome risk-or-reward calculation. Justin Turner, part of the soul of the Los Angeles Dodgers, learned that he had tested positive for the coronavirus during the World Series clincher on Tuesday night at Globe Life Field. Then he defied orders from Major League Baseball security and celebrated on the field with teammates and family members, at times without wearing a mask.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: France and Germany reimposed nationwide lockdowns as cases surge.
lead_paragraph: Europe has tried for weeks to slow the spread of the virus with targeted restrictions instead of the unpopular nationwide lockdowns that were imposed in the spring. But as a furious second wave pushes hospitalizations, deaths and cases to levels not seen since the beginning of the pandemic, countries have begun to change course.

headline: What Are You Seeing at the Polls?
abstract: Voters are turning out in record numbers to cast ballots in the 2020 election. We want to hear what is happening when you go to vote.
lead_paragraph: Do you have a tip about voting problems? The New York Times is partnering with ProPublica and hundreds of other news organizations to track voting impediments and other challenges to the reliability and integrity of the election. Submit your tips here.

headline: Diane di Prima, Poet of the Beat Era and Beyond, Dies at 86
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: She traveled in the circles of Ginsberg and Ferlinghetti, a rare female voice in a male world, and went on to a long, prolific career in poetry.
lead_paragraph: Diane di Prima, the most prominent woman among the male-dominated Beat poets, who after being immersed in the bohemian swirl of Greenwich Village in the 1950s moved to the West Coast and continued to publish prolifically in a wide range of forms, died on Sunday in San Francisco. She was 86.

headline: Covid Relief for Nonprofits
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Mines and Mining', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: “Nonprofits throughout the country and the millions of Americans who depend on them cannot wait until after the election for relief.” Also: Helping coal miners; how the use of pens can help learning.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Supreme Court Allows Longer Deadlines for Absentee Ballots in Pennsylvania and North Carolina
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans in both states opposed the extensions. Justice Amy Coney Barrett, who joined the court on Tuesday, did not participate in either case, saying she had not had time to fully review the briefs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a pair of decisions welcomed by Democrats, the Supreme Court on Wednesday let election officials in two key battleground states, Pennsylvania and North Carolina, accept absentee ballots for several days after Election Day.

headline: After 50 Years, a Suspect Emerges in a Cold Murder Case
keywords: ['Forensic Science', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: With the help of DNA technology, John Jeffrey Sipos, 75, was arrested in Pennsylvania last weekend in the 1969 murder of Mary Scott, a 23-year-old California woman.
lead_paragraph: Rosalie Sanz was a teenager in 1969 when she looked out the window of her family’s San Diego home on a dark November night and saw two men in suits. She remembers her mother listening quietly to the detectives telling her that her 23-year-old daughter, Mary Scott, had been murdered.

headline: The 2020 Campaign Is the Most Expensive Ever (By a Lot)
abstract: The total cost of the races for the White House, the Senate and the House is expected to hit nearly $14 billion.
lead_paragraph: The 2020 election has blown past previous records to become the most expensive campaign in American history, with the final tally for the battle for the White House and control of the Senate and the House expected to hit nearly $14 billion, according to new projections made by the Center for Responsive Politics.

headline: The Supreme Court allows longer absentee ballot deadlines in Pennsylvania and North Carolina.
abstract: The Supreme Court will allow election officials to accept ballots after Election Day in two key battlegrounds: Pennsylvania and North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: In a pair of decisions welcomed by Democrats, the Supreme Court on Wednesday at least temporarily let election officials in two key battleground states, Pennsylvania and North Carolina, accept absentee ballots for several days after Election Day.

headline: Stocks Post Worst Day in 4 Months as Infections Rise Around the Globe
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The S&P 500 was down 3.5 percent after France and Germany announced new lockdown measures, an unwelcome reminder of the recovery’s fragility.
lead_paragraph: Coronavirus flare-ups across the United States and new lockdown measures in major European economies sent stocks sliding to their worst performance in months on Wednesday.

headline: The Best of the Kennedys?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: Neal Gabler’s “Catching the Wind” makes clear that Ted Kennedy’s record in the Senate far outshone the legislative accomplishments of his brothers.
lead_paragraph: CATCHING THE WINDEdward Kennedy and the Liberal HourBy Neal Gabler

headline: Europe, 2020 Election, Dodgers: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Finally, the Resistance Gets to Vote
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Now is our chance to put an end to this presidency.
lead_paragraph: We are now entering the homestretch. Voters will finally have a say in whether Donald Trump’s reign of terror and idiocy continues or ends.

headline: Say Yes to Progressive Taxation
abstract: The people of Illinois, Arizona and California have a chance to make the distribution of state taxation a little more fair.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans accept the common-sense case for progressive taxation: Those who have more ought to contribute more to the society that is the foundation of their prosperity.

headline: Trump claims the nation is ‘rounding the turn’ on the virus as cases climb; Biden vows to ‘deal honestly with the American people.’
abstract: President Trump claimed the nation was ‘rounding the turn’ on the virus even as cases climbed, as Joe Biden vowed to ‘deal honestly with the American people.’
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic — which has reshaped the presidential race by transforming the conventions, the debates, the way the candidates campaign and how voters cast their ballots — dominated the race on Wednesday as President Trump and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. held fast to the diametrically opposed positions they have staked out.

headline: Wedding and Birthday Party Infect 56, Leaving Nearly 300 in Quarantine
abstract: “This kind of blatant disregard for the well-being of others is not only extremely disappointing; it will not be tolerated,” a Long Island official said.
lead_paragraph: Long Island health officials scrambled to contain a coronavirus outbreak in Suffolk County when dozens of people tested positive for the virus after attending a high-end Sweet 16 party in September that violated state restrictions on gatherings.

headline: Baltimore Museum of Art Cancels Painting Sale that Drew Complaints
abstract: The museum was prepared to sell three major works to pay for salary increases and to diversify its collection, but many critics disagreed with the plan.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Museum of Art is pausing its plan to sell three major paintings from its collection. A Sotheby’s sale of works by Brice Marden, Clyfford Still and Andy Warhol was estimated to bring in $65 million to fund acquisitions of art by people of color and staff-wide salary increases.

headline: Cuba Says U.S. Restrictions Will Force Western Union Offices to Close
abstract: The moves could severely restrict the flow of remittances from abroad and worsen a profound economic crisis on the island.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In the face of widening American financial restrictions on Cuba, more than 400 Western Union offices on the island will close, Cuban authorities said, a move that could severely restrict the flow of remittances from abroad and worsen a profound economic crisis that has led to widespread food shortages on the island.

headline: Days From Election, Police Killing of Black Man Roils Philadelphia
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Looting (Crime)', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The shooting and its aftermath were guaranteed to ratchet up tensions in a country already on edge. Debates about how to improve police accountability have been complicated by looting.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — There is a grim familiarity to it all. In the final days of a bitter election, it is a reprise of the terrible images that the country has come to know all too well this year: The shaky cellphone video, the abrupt death of a Black man at the hands of the police. The howls of grief at the scene. The protests that formed immediately. The looting of stores that lasted late into the night.

headline: M.L.B. Says Justin Turner Refused to Stay Off Field After Dodgers’ Win
abstract: “Turner’s decision to leave isolation and enter the field was wrong and put everyone he came in contact with at risk,” the league said in a statement.
lead_paragraph: The joy of the Dodgers’ long coveted World Series title was overshadowed on Tuesday night when Justin Turner, the team’s veteran third baseman, joined his teammates in celebration on the field shortly after learning he had tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: Er, Can I Ask a Few Questions About Abortion?
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Bible', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: You know who really reduced abortion numbers in the U.S.? President Obama, with the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Millions of American Christians are likely to vote for President Trump on Tuesday because they believe it a religious obligation to support a president who will appoint “pro-life” judges.

headline: Trump’s Closing Argument on Virus Clashes With Science, and Voters’ Lives
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president has continued to downplay the severity of the coronavirus and declare before largely maskless crowds that it is vanishing. The surge in new cases across the country says: Not so.
lead_paragraph: As an immense new surge in coronavirus cases sweeps the country, President Trump is closing his re-election campaign by pleading with voters to ignore the evidence of a calamity unfolding before their eyes and trust his word that the disease is already disappearing as a threat to their personal health and economic well being.

headline: Into the Unknown
abstract: At this point, I’m thinking less about polling averages and more about a few key variables that we can’t predict.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Writing and Writers', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: A lifelong Republican and a former top official at the Department of Homeland Security, Mr. Taylor took a leave of absence from his job at Google this summer to campaign for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Miles Taylor, who revealed on Wednesday that he was the anonymous author of a New York Times Op-Ed article in 2018 that was critical of President Trump, is a lifelong Republican whose service as a senior homeland security official in the Trump administration led him to endorse former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic nominee, for president this year.

headline: Take This Trump Election Day Quiz Before It’s Too Late
abstract: Some of the president’s moments are unforgettable, even if you try.

headline: A Privacy Measure That’s Hard to Like
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Referendums', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Law and Legislation', 'Attorneys General']
abstract: An update to California’s groundbreaking privacy law falls short.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, California lawmakers passed a data privacy bill that gave consumers back some control over the reams of personal information they share with tech firms. The legislation became a model for the rest of the country.

headline: $300 Million Telemarketing Scheme Preyed on Older People, U.S. Says
abstract: Officials announced that 60 people had been charged in the scheme, in which federal prosecutors said deceptive tactics were used to sell magazine subscriptions to more than 150,000 older and vulnerable people.
lead_paragraph: Sixty people have been indicted in a nationwide telemarketing scheme in which federal prosecutors say people were tricked into signing up for expensive magazine subscriptions they could not afford, did not want and often did not receive, and in which over 150,000 people were defrauded of more than $300 million.

headline: M.L.B. says a Dodgers player insisted on celebrating with teammates despite his positive coronavirus test.
abstract: The Los Angeles Dodgers’ joy over winning the World Series on Tuesday night was overshadowed when Justin Turner, the team’s veteran third baseman, joined his teammates in celebration on the field shortly after learning he had tested positive for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Dodgers’ joy over winning the World Series on Tuesday night was overshadowed when Justin Turner, the team’s veteran third baseman, joined his teammates in celebration on the field shortly after learning he had tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: ‘Perception Hacks’ and Other Potential Threats to the Election
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Absentee Voting', 'Elections', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: In the final days of voting, election officials and cybersecurity experts are keeping a close eye on a range of possible ways foreign governments and other hackers could interfere.
lead_paragraph: In Georgia, a database that verifies voter signatures was locked up by Russian hackers in a ransomware attack that also dumped voters’ registration data online.

headline: First a Sweet 16 party, now a wedding and a birthday: Long Island has more superspreading events.
abstract: Health officials on Long Island were scrambling on Wednesday to respond to two coronavirus superspreader events that left 56 people with the virus and nearly 300 in quarantine after attending a wedding and a birthday party.
lead_paragraph: Health officials on Long Island were scrambling on Wednesday to respond to two coronavirus superspreader events that left 56 people with the virus and nearly 300 in quarantine after attending a wedding and a birthday party.

headline: Officials Warn of Cyberattacks on Hospitals as Virus Cases Spike
abstract: Government officials warned that hackers were seeking to hold American hospitals’ data hostage in exchange for ransom payments.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of American hospitals are being targeted in cyberattacks by the same Russian hackers who American officials and researchers fear could sow mayhem around next week’s election.

headline: Begins Some Evasive Maneuvering
abstract: Kurt Weller makes a tricky New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I’ve been pretty busy lately with my recent staycation — thank you to Caitlin Lovinger and Helen Verongos for steering the ship in my absence — but I would never shoo away people like Kurt Weller seems to be doing. Maybe he’s just stressed out. Or maybe he has a reason for saying “I’m busy!” as he does at 71A.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Tools of the Trail: Masks, Zoom, Thermometers
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 29, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “All we’re missing is the asteroid landing with flesh-eating zombies, and our year will be complete.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 29, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Oct. 29, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the reasons that New York’s indie movie theaters may survive the pandemic, using information from the theater owner Nick Nicolaou, misidentified the month when he began offering the documentary “The Booksellers” online. It was in June, not April.

headline: Life Without Parole for Man Who Killed Chicago Police Commander
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: “Justice was served today,” Mayor Lori Lightfoot said after sentencing for the midday fatal shooting of Cmdr. Paul Bauer in the Loop.
lead_paragraph: A 47-year-old man was sentenced to life in prison without parole on Wednesday for fatally shooting a high-ranking Chicago police official in a midday confrontation in the city’s busy Loop district in 2018.

headline: Trump wrested control from doctors as the pandemic grew, Jared Kushner told an interviewer.
abstract: As coronavirus cases and deaths were rising in the United States last spring, Jared Kushner, President Trump’s senior adviser and son-in-law, told an interviewer that the president had taken the “country back from the doctors.”

abstract: Counting votes by mail involves multiple steps, and in several critical swing states, that process doesn’t begin until Election Day or very close to it.

headline: Typhoon Molave Slams Into Vietnam, Bringing Death and More Misery

headline: Florida, where Trump and Biden converged, is in the ‘red zone’ for coronavirus cases.

abstract: In many American cities, where economies have been ravaged by the coronavirus pandemic, there been a surge in gun violence, including six killings of juveniles in Oakland, Calif., since June and a 40 percent increase in homicides over all. To the south, in Los Angeles, the picture is equally bloody, with the city on pace to have more than 300 homicides for the first time since 2009.

headline: Getting Lost Helped V.E. Schwab Find the Idea for Her 20th Book
abstract: ‘The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue’ took 10 years to write. The fantasy author describes the process as a ‘very, very long labor of love.’
lead_paragraph: SHED DREAD Ten years ago, at the suggestion of a friend who is no longer a friend, the fantasy author V.E. Schwab relocated from Nashville to Liverpool, England, where she paid 200 pounds per month to live in an unheated garden shed furnished with a single bed and a metal bar for hanging clothes. There was no plumbing. Her landlord was a former prison warden who also owned a neighboring house that was “benignly haunted” by a man who had lived there for 40 years. Schwab says, “You could literally hear his footsteps moving through the halls and down the stairs a few times a day.”

lead_paragraph: It finally looks as if Big Tech may face some breakups. Lawmakers are interrogating tech C.E.O.s on Capitol Hill while the Justice Department pursues a landmark antitrust case against Google. For decades, tech giants have avoided such scrutiny — hiding behind the idea that their products are free, beneficial, even beloved.

headline: Poem: Gemini
abstract: A poem that reminds us of the intricate linkages of everyday life.
lead_paragraph: This is what we have had to do, amid pandemic, grief, political chaos, fires, human rights disasters: continue on with our lives. Doing chores … taking walks … teaching kids … trying to stay steady. In his brilliant forthcoming book, “Tethered to Stars,” Fady Joudah writes about the mysterious cosmos swirling with intricate linkages — as his phone is pinging. Ah, yes, Jerusalem, the Holy City! Right now, let’s call all our cities holy. Let’s hope our trees continue to communicate, whatever humans can or can’t accomplish.

headline: The Stressful Conclusion of a Clinical Trial
abstract: Does a pharmaceutical company have a moral obligation to acknowledge my participation with an ongoing supply of the product that I helped test?
lead_paragraph: When I learned this summer that the clinical trial of the cancer drug that seems to be keeping me alive had unexpectedly shut down, I discovered the murky rules governing drug trials and the stressful confusion they breed in participants.

headline: It’s Election Day. Do You Know How Your Matches Are Voting?
keywords: ['Single Persons', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Online Dating']
abstract: Singles are putting their political affiliations front and center on the apps.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Cibbarelli, 23, was texting with a man on Hinge while Senator Kamala Harris and Vice President Mike Pence debated on her TV screen in early October. When she told her match what she was watching, he said he didn’t know who either of the people in the debate were, or which political office they were running for.

headline: How to Do School When Motivation Has Gone Missing
abstract: Here’s what teenagers can do to equip themselves to move forward during this difficult and frustrating time.
lead_paragraph: The school year is still young, yet parents and students alike may have noticed that academic motivation is already low. No surprise there. Whether school is remote, in-person or hybrid, many students have come to feel that, if this year were a meal, it would be all vegetables and no dessert. Gone, or hamstrung by screens, masks and plexiglass, are the encouraging company of classmates and teachers, the camaraderie of tackling tedious work alongside friends and the school day boost of exchanging a few words with one’s crush. Still here is the steady stream of assignments, assessments and lectures.

headline: How Trump Lowered America’s Standing in the World
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Nationalism (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: It has become impossible for democracies to believe it is in their interest to take Trump’s America seriously.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday’s election will be seen globally as a referendum on the durability of democracy. If American democracy, long a beacon, cannot self-correct, then all democracies are at risk. European nations have watched with alarm as President Trump has set about undermining American democracy while attacking the very foundations — the European Union and NATO — that allowed war-torn Europe to become whole, democratic and free.

headline: Are There Any Mothers Out There Like Me?
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Infertility', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Single Persons', 'ANTIDEPRESSANTS', 'ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION']
abstract: I spent months agonizing over my lack of a partner or high-powered career. But it was my depression that almost upended my dream of motherhood.
lead_paragraph: Motherhood was a dream of love planted in my heart before I was born, always a “when,” never an “if.” Even after I divorced at 34, childless, I still assumed my future would follow the date-marry-procreate blueprint I’d always imagined. But four years, dozens of dates and not a single serious boyfriend later, it seemed that a husband’s second coming was unlikely in my immediate future.

headline: Where Covid Left Holes, Volunteers Stepped In
abstract: As their communities’ needs shifted amid the pandemic, these neighbors offered help.
lead_paragraph: On a blustery day in May, Vanessa Fransen rolled her wagon up to a house in Makoti, N.D. She deposited a bundle on the doormat, rang the doorbell and sprinted away. But this wasn’t your typical ding-dong-ditch: When her neighbors opened their door, they found a bag full of books.

headline: How the Nxivm Sex Cult Leader Tore One Family Apart
keywords: ['Religious Cults', 'Human Trafficking', 'Sex Crimes', 'Racketeering and Racketeers', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Keith Raniere, the founder of Nxivm, had abusive sexual relationships with three sisters who joined his organization, the family said. Their father still supports him.
lead_paragraph: She walked into a hushed courtroom on Tuesday, turning to face the man who had sexually abused her as a 15-year-old and slept with her older sisters as well, sometimes at the same time. He had ensnared her entire family with his pseudophilosophy of self-fulfillment and pitted them against one another.

headline: So, Russia, You Want to Mess With Our Voting Machines?
abstract: The United States should threaten to retaliate — and I’m not talking about economic sanctions or legal indictments.
lead_paragraph: Put yourself in the shoes of Russian or Iranian leadership for a moment. Why not interfere with the voting in the U.S. presidential election? What could be more advantageous than catalyzing a bitter and protracted battle over the results of the election, with a chance of igniting civil unrest throughout the country? Sure, it might not work — but with little to lose and so much to gain, why not try?

headline: How Suckerfish Surf Across Blue Whales Without Falling Off
keywords: ['Whales and Whaling', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Physics', 'Research', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-animals']
abstract: Remoras — known for hitching rides on whales and sharks — swim surprisingly freely over the surfaces formed by their hosts.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, Jeremy Goldbogen, a marine biologist at Stanford University, stuck video cameras on the backs of blue whales, hoping to learn more about their feeding habits. When he retrieved the footage, he realized he had been photobombed. Dozens of Remora australis were treating his research subjects like dance floors, skimming and twisting across them — even as the whales swam at high speeds.

headline: Police Pin a Rise in Murders on an Unusual Suspect: Covid
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Awash in new firearms, cities are drawing connections between the stresses of the coronavirus and a surge in homicides.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Family and friends of Aaron Pryor say they may never know exactly why the 16-year-old star football player, a lightning-fast running back, was killed in broad daylight on a Sunday in September in a driveway near his Oakland home. Video of the shooting viewed by family members shows an assailant, who has not been arrested, confronting the baby-faced teenager before firing more than a dozen rounds.

headline: Facing Gap in Pennsylvania, Trump Camp Tries to Make Voting Harder
abstract: Trailing in the polls, President Trump and his campaign are pursuing a three-pronged strategy that would effectively suppress the mail-in vote in the critical state of Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — President Trump’s campaign in the crucial battleground of Pennsylvania is pursuing a three-pronged strategy that would effectively suppress mail-in votes in the state, moving to stop the processing of absentee votes before Election Day, pushing to limit how late mail-in ballots can be accepted and intimidating Pennsylvanians trying to vote early.

headline: Death Rates Have Dropped for Seriously Ill Covid Patients
abstract: Survival rates have improved with medical advances and less crowded hospitals, studies say. But the latest record-breaking surge in infections could reverse the gains.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus struck the United States earlier this year with devastating force. In April, it killed more than 10,000 people in New York City. By early May, nearly 50,000 nursing home residents and their caregivers across the country had died.

abstract: What’s more fundamental to scary movies than the bone-chilling shriek? But delivering a terrifying wail isn’t easy. It’s an entire art with a history and a world of its own.

headline: ‘It’s Going Away’: A Small Movie Theater Struggles to Survive
keywords: ['Movies', 'Theaters (Buildings)', 'Small Business', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The pandemic has staggered the industry and left independent operations like the Park Plaza Cinema in Hilton Head Island, S.C., fighting to stay afloat.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy day last week, 72 moviegoers visited the Park Plaza Cinema in Hilton Head Island, S.C., to see Liam Neeson in “Honest Thief.” It was the largest single-day attendance the independently owned five-screen theater had seen since reopening in August after a five-month shutdown. The feeling of celebration was short-lived. The next day, only 22 people showed.

headline: 16 New Books to Watch For in November
abstract: Barack Obama’s memoir is landing. So is a biography of Adrienne Rich and buzzy fiction from Jo Nesbo, Nicole Krauss and Susie Yang.

We know it’s the first of a projected two-volume project and encompasses the former president’s campaign and early years in the White House. Crown is printing 3 million copies, and booksellers are hoping the book will offset a string of difficult months since the pandemic hit.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Celebrities']
abstract: In a letter to Alex M. Azar II, the health secretary, House Democrats detailed how a $265 million public relations campaign tried to bolster President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A $265 million public campaign to “defeat despair” around the coronavirus was planned partly around the politically tinged theme that “helping the president will help the country,” according to documents released on Thursday by House investigators.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Leftovers Etiquette
abstract: Should your wife have poured ketchup into your shared leftovers?
lead_paragraph: Jake writes: My wife puts ketchup on her macaroni and cheese. I disagree with this, but I don’t mind. Today, however, she dumped ketchup right into a container of leftovers with three servings left. She sees nothing wrong. I see a monster.

headline: Have a Creepy, Crawly Halloween
abstract: Why spiders and snakes and things that crawl fill so many of us with dread.
lead_paragraph: The fear of snakes has plagued Sydney Masters as long as she can remember. Ms. Masters, a New York public relations executive, experiences an overwhelming panic-attack type of fear — shortness of breath, rapid heartbeat — whenever she’s near anything that slithers.

headline: Simon Pegg and Nick Frost Are Back With a British ‘X-Files’
abstract: “Truth Seekers,” the comedy duo’s first TV collaboration in two decades, is rooted in their own ghost hunting exploits.
lead_paragraph: Simon Pegg and Nick Frost know it’s been a while. Despite being best friends and an acclaimed comic double act in films like “Hot Fuzz” and “Shaun of the Dead,” they have seldom crossed paths, creatively speaking, since 2013’s “The World’s End.” It’s been even longer since they worked together in television — they haven’t co-starred in a series since the British sitcom “Spaced” aired over 20 years ago.

headline: Trump’s Thoroughly Modern Masculinity
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Men and Boys', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president isn’t a throwback to old-school masculinity. He’s a he-man specifically engineered for our image-based, sensation-saturated times.
lead_paragraph: Remarkably, in these fractious times, President Trump has managed to forge a singular area of consensus among liberals and conservatives, Republicans and Democrats: Nearly everyone seems to agree that he represents a throwback to a vintage version of manhood.

headline: Has Texas finally become a true presidential battleground state?
abstract: When Senator Ted Cruz of Texas spoke with President Trump on the phone last week, he congratulated him on his debate performance, nudged him to keep driving policy-oriented attacks against his opponent, Joseph R. Biden Jr., and relayed one more message.
lead_paragraph: When Senator Ted Cruz of Texas spoke with President Trump on the phone last week, he congratulated him on his debate performance, nudged him to keep driving policy-oriented attacks against his opponent, Joseph R. Biden Jr., and relayed one more message.

headline: As Coronavirus Surges, Chastened Dutch Wonder, ‘What Happened to Us?’
abstract: They have long prided themselves on an efficient government, some say to the point of smugness. Ranking high in the rate of daily infections is forcing a reckoning.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — As coronavirus cases have shot through the roof, waiting times for tests and results have grown so lengthy that the health authorities have considered sending samples to labs in Abu Dhabi. Contact tracing, divided among 25 competing contractors, has never gotten off the ground.

headline: New Terror Attacks Leave France Embattled at Home and Abroad
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: A man with a knife killed three people at a church in Nice, in an assault that bore similarities to the recent killing of a schoolteacher, which has shaken the country.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — A terror attack that killed three people in Nice on Thursday left France increasingly embattled at home and abroad, as the government called for toughening measures against Islamist extremism, amid rising tensions with Muslim nations.

headline: When One Car Has More Horsepower Than Churchill Downs
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Muscle cars have fought for decades to be the brawniest. Now electric cars are pushing the envelope, past even 1,000 horsepower.
lead_paragraph: In 1967, the Ford GT40 was one of the fastest cars on the planet.

abstract: The election anxieties of Americans across the political spectrum are visible in an alarming place: gun sales figures.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.

headline: Trailing in Pennsylvania, the Trump camp tries to make it harder to cast a vote.
abstract: President Trump’s campaign is pursuing a three-pronged strategy in the crucial battleground state of Pennsylvania that would effectively suppress mail-in votes there, moving to stop the processing of absentee votes before Election Day, pushing to limit how late mail-in ballots can be accepted and intimidating Pennsylvanians trying to vote early.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s campaign is pursuing a three-pronged strategy in the crucial battleground state of Pennsylvania that would effectively suppress mail-in votes there, moving to stop the processing of absentee votes before Election Day, pushing to limit how late mail-in ballots can be accepted and intimidating Pennsylvanians trying to vote early.

abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: With coronavirus cases surging across most of Europe and the Americas, it can be easy to give into nihilism and wonder whether there is any good way for a country to fight the virus.
