headline: The connection between ‘Real Housewives’ and public health behavior.
abstract: Kelly Dodd is one of the stars of “The Real Housewives of Orange County,” a show in its 15th season that follows the travails of six women in Southern California.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Dodd is one of the stars of “The Real Housewives of Orange County,” a show in its 15th season that follows the travails of six women in Southern California.

headline: ‘Madre’ Review: A Tense Depiction of a Mother Undone
abstract: Rodrigo Sorogoyen’s feature about a mother in Spain whose son disappears is a compelling and unsettling character study.
lead_paragraph: A parent’s worst nightmare, unfolding in real time, opens this Spanish drama. Elena (the superb Marta Nieto) gets a call from her young son, Iván. He’s vacationing in France with his father, from whom Elena is estranged. Iván’s dad went to their camper to fetch something, supposedly, and the 6-year-old boy is alone on a deserted beach. The bars on his cellphone are going down, he says. And so is the sun.

headline: ‘Spell’ Review: Occult Reprogramming
abstract: Omari Hardwick plays a lawyer who gets trapped in the superstition-laden enclave of Appalachia where he was raised.
lead_paragraph: In “Spell,” Omari Hardwick plays a tenacious, wealthy lawyer named Marquis T. Woods; his boss calls him a “gladiator.” But the boss is also worried that Marquis might go easy on class-action plaintiffs who, like Marquis, are Black. Marquis doesn’t seem to have any misgivings. Then he gets a call: His abusive father has died, compelling him to return with his wife and children to a remote pocket of Appalachia he was thrilled to escape. Superstition rules the area. Even an airstrip gas station sells gear for warding off conjurers.

headline: ‘Come Play’ Review: Alexa, Find Me a Derivative Thriller
abstract: In Jacob Chase’s film, a monster from another realm invades ours through phone screens and tablets.
lead_paragraph: The Babadook goes paperless in “Come Play,” a thriller in which a spindly creature from another realm torments a child and his family through phone screens and tablets.

headline: ‘The Donut King’ Review: Sweet Dreams
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Doughnuts', 'Entrepreneurship']
abstract: This documentary traces the mercurial journey of a Cambodian refugee who became a doughnut mogul in California.
lead_paragraph: In 1975, Ted Ngoy fled the war in Cambodia with his wife and three kids and arrived in America as a penniless refugee. Within a decade, he had become a multimillionaire with a lakeside mansion, fancy European cars and a doughnut empire in Southern California that even Dunkin’ couldn’t rival there.

headline: ‘Fire Will Come’ Review: An Arsonist Returns Home to the Forest
abstract: Oliver Laxe gives us the story of humans and nature in crisis in Galicia, with nonactors playing the roles.
lead_paragraph: There’s not too much story in “Fire Will Come,” but once the title promise comes to fruition, the viewer has come to care about its characters and how they will weather a devastating forest blaze.

headline: Welcome to His World: Bela Tarr’s First Meteorological Event
abstract: “Damnation,” an atmospheric tale of erotic obsession, is the movie with which the Hungarian filmmaker Bela Tarr came into his own as a stylist.
lead_paragraph: Made in 1988 but virtually unknown in the United States, “Damnation” is the movie with which the great Hungarian filmmaker Bela Tarr fully became “Bela Tarr.”

headline: ‘Us Kids’ Review: They’re Not All Right
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: This documentary by Kim A. Snyder asks difficult questions about what it means to grow up in an America where gun violence is far too common.
lead_paragraph: Columbine. Sandy Hook. Parkland. Before the pandemic, school shootings had become so commonplace in the United States that they warranted distressingly detailed charts. “Us Kids,” a documentary directed by Kim A. Snyder (“Newtown”), uses the 2018 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., to ask difficult questions about what it means to grow up in an America habituated to gun violence.

headline: ‘Raining in the Mountain’ Review: A Martial Arts Gem From 1979
abstract: This recently restored film by King Hu is a spectacular, exhilarating entertainment.
lead_paragraph: From the mid-60s to the end of the ’70s, the Hong Kong director King Hu (who died in 1997) made some of the most distinctive, daring and enjoyable wuxia (literally, “martial heroes”) films ever. “Raining in the Mountain,” from 1979, is the latest Hu to benefit from a restoration and it’s a treat.

headline: Halloween for Kids: Different This Year, but Still Delightful
keywords: ['Halloween', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: In New York, trick-or-treating has been curtailed, and parades called off. But there are plenty of ways to please and spook the little ones.
lead_paragraph: If you have children, then Halloween will see a lot more trick than treat this year. Here in New York, cruising neighborhoods for candy has been discouraged, parades are canceled and bobbing for apples is the kind of innocent party game that makes virologists cry. It might seem that not even a pillowcase full of mini Kit Kats can improve the situation.

headline: What Turn Are We Really Rounding on the Virus?
abstract: The president leans into denial for his closing argument: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Trump continues to insist that a vaccine is coming, while the Supreme Court let stand decisions in two battleground states allowing more absentee ballots to be counted. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: ‘The True Adventures of Wolfboy’ Review: A Hirsute Teen Drama
abstract: A 13-year-old boy, his body covered in hair, searches for the mother he never knew.
lead_paragraph: Paul (Jaeden Martell), the titular 13-year-old of “The True Adventures of Wolfboy,” has a condition that causes his body to be covered in hair; if he tries shaving, the hair grows back thicker. Bullies ridicule him for his appearance and don’t even spare his single father (Chris Messina).

keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: Echoes of the past are spooking investors.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 17 and 18, DealBook is holding our first Online Summit. Join us as we welcome the most consequential newsmakers in business, policy and culture to explore the pivotal questions of the moment — and the future. Watch from anywhere in the world, free of charge. Register now.

headline: As the West Stumbles, ‘Helmsman’ Xi Pushes an Ambitious Plan for China
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: China’s leader emerged from a key Communist Party meeting newly emboldened, outlining a road map for the country for years to come. Some have warned of overreach.
lead_paragraph: The United States is embroiled in a bitter presidential race and a surge in coronavirus infections. Europe is locking down again. In Beijing, by contrast, Xi Jinping is exuding confidence that he and China can emerge from the pandemic stronger and unbowed.

headline: The Tax Fight Haunting California
abstract: Thursday: Ah! It’s property tax reform. Also: Fire updates; and more on Justin Turner.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Manufacturers got a big bounce, but service businesses still face a big climb.
abstract: The pandemic didn’t just shrink the U.S. economy. It also reshaped it, at least temporarily — shutting down some industries almost entirely, while leading to a rise in demand in others.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic didn’t just shrink the U.S. economy. It also reshaped it, at least temporarily — shutting down some industries almost entirely, while leading to a rise in demand in others.

headline: Can I Tell My Friend Her Halloween Costume Is Problematic?
abstract: A reader feels that Scarlett O’Hara-style period dress may be seen as whitewashing the antebellum South.
lead_paragraph: A new friend in the Midwest was invited to an outdoor Halloween party where mask-wearing was requested. We went shopping for an art-inspired costume for her. But I saw that she was gravitating toward period costumes. After the party, she posted pictures online. I was stunned! She wore a full-blown Scarlett O’Hara-type gown — to a mansion, no less! If I’d known, I would have tried to talk her out if it. This year’s widespread Black Lives Matter protests, along with the traditional whitewashing of the antebellum South, make her choice seem insensitive. I’ll be seeing her soon, and I already feel awkward. I know she’ll share details of the party, and I feel obligated to enlighten her. Any advice?

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Ballet flats, colorful rugs — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Student Voting Surges Despite Efforts to Suppress It
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Voting and Voters', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Absentee Voting', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Youth', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic and new requirements in Republican-led states created voting obstacles for college students this year. Yet youth participation appears to be on the rise.
lead_paragraph: With many campus quads resembling ghost towns and childhood bedrooms serving as lecture halls, politically active college students have moved their get-out-the-vote efforts online, hosting debate watch parties on Zoom, recruiting poll workers over Instagram and encouraging students to post their voting plans on Snapchat.

headline: Cars led a wave in spending on goods.
abstract: As the U.S. economy rebounded in the third quarter, one sector played a big role: Motor vehicles and parts were selling rapidly, contributing to an overall bounce in durable good spending.
lead_paragraph: As the U.S. economy rebounded in the third quarter, one sector played a big role: Motor vehicles and parts were selling rapidly, contributing to an overall bounce in durable good spending.

headline: Today’s economic report shows a record-setting rebound. But the numbers are misleading.
abstract: Today’s economic report shows a record-setting rebound. But the numbers are misleading.
lead_paragraph: U.S. economic output grew at the fastest pace on record last quarter as businesses began to reopen and customers returned to stores. But the economy has climbed only partway out of its pandemic-induced hole, and progress is slowing.

headline: ‘Quick, Quick, Quick’: Trump Rushes Martha McSally at Rally
abstract: On Wednesday night at a rally in Arizona, President Trump rushed Senator Martha McSally on stage as she fights to hold on to her seat.

headline: What Trump’s disrespectful treatment of Martha McSally says about his own struggles.

lead_paragraph: President Trump’s dismissive and disrespectful treatment of his nominal political ally Senator Martha McSally in Arizona on Wednesday was cast by local media as a humiliating coda to her difficult campaign.

headline: Home building has helped drive the U.S. recovery. Exports have lagged.
abstract: The main factor behind the big third-quarter rebound in U.S. economic output was growth in spending by consumers. Business investment played a major role too, and for similar reasons: Activity was all but halted during the spring lockdowns, then bounced back once the economy began to reopen.

headline: A Not-So-Merry Mix: Shakespeare, Bluegrass and Randy Quaid
abstract: The Broadway marquee was up, but this crowd-pleasing musical never made it out of Seattle. Among the creative differences: How fat should Falstaff be?
lead_paragraph: Among the casualties of the current Broadway shutdown are shows in previews that will never officially open, as well as those whose futures are still in limbo. This series is looking at the curious history of five other shows aimed for Broadway that never got to opening night.

headline: ‘There Are Tons of Brown Faces Missing’: Publishers Step Up Diversity Efforts
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Minorities', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The push in book publishing for more authors and workers of color hasn’t abated, and companies are increasingly making lasting changes to the way they do business.
lead_paragraph: This summer, as people across the United States gathered to protest police brutality and racial injustice, Krishan Trotman, an executive editor at Hachette Books, approached the head of the company with a proposal.

headline: Gilead’s Covid-19 Drug Is Mediocre. It Will Be a Blockbuster Anyway.
abstract: Gilead Sciences said Wednesday that remdesivir, which has been authorized for emergency use since the spring, brought in $873 million in revenues so far this year.
lead_paragraph: The United States reached a milestone, of sorts, when last week the Food and Drug Administration approved the first treatment for Covid-19.

headline: Labour Party Suspends Jeremy Corbyn Over Anti-Semitism Response
abstract: A long-awaited official report strongly criticized Britain’s main opposition party, which Mr. Corbyn once led. His reply to the findings prompted his suspension.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s main opposition party, Labour, suspended its former leader Jeremy Corbyn on Thursday after he deflected blame for the party’s handling of anti-Semitism allegations, setting the stage for an extraordinary rupture with Labour’s recent past and another period of tortured infighting over its future.

headline: The American Economy Was Hit by a Bus. It’s Healing, but Slowly.
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: Why the G.D.P. numbers out today can mislead.
lead_paragraph: To understand what the latest numbers on gross domestic product are telling us, imagine you are an obsessive sort who takes various measures of your health every day, puts those readings into a spreadsheet, and then every three months averages those daily numbers to get a summary of whether you are getting better or worse.

headline: The Trump campaign celebrated a growth record that Democrats downplayed.

headline: When It Comes to Octopuses, Taste Is for Suckers
abstract: Octopuses can taste what their arms touch, and scientists have figured out how.
lead_paragraph: Should anything ever compel you to lick an octopus’s arm, keep this in mind: That arm has all the cellular machinery to taste your tongue right back.

headline: Here Are the Policy Advisers Who Have Joe Biden’s Ear
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Biden has sought advice across the Democratic Party’s ideological spectrum, but his core advisers on the coronavirus, economics, foreign policy and climate change are familiar figures.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr., plotting an ambitious presidency that would begin amid twin health and economic crises, is leaning on veteran advisers with high-level governmental experience rather than outsiders and ideological rivals to help guide him on subjects including the coronavirus pandemic and the country’s diminished standing in the world.

headline: As details emerge in Whitmer plot, F.B.I. arrests Michigan men said to be tied to a white supremacist group.
abstract: Federal and state authorities arrested two men in Michigan on Thursday who they said were members of a white supremacist group, taking the men into custody just three weeks after more than a dozen members of a separate, anti-government group were accused of plotting to kidnap the state’s governor.

headline: The ‘South Park’ Guys Break Down Their Viral Deepfake Video
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Web-Original Programming']
abstract: In an interview, Trey Parker, Matt Stone and their collaborator Peter Serafinowicz discuss the back story of “Sassy Justice,” their deepfake video that used images of President Trump and others.
lead_paragraph: Like so many other things on the internet, the viral video “Sassy Justice” seemed too good to be true when it started showing up on television and then on the internet earlier this week. Presented as a local news broadcast from a station in Cheyenne, Wyo., the video is hosted by a reporter named Fred Sassy, who appears to be a dead ringer for President Trump — if he wore a cheap suit and a white wig and spoke with a campy accent.

headline: Kayleigh McEnany, the White House press secretary, blurs the line between government and politics.
abstract: Kayleigh McEnany, the White House press secretary, has suddenly started appearing on Fox News from a set-up at President Trump’s re-election headquarters, further blurring the lines between government and political activity.

headline: At the Queens Museum, Home and the World

lead_paragraph: Leon Black, the billionaire private equity executive whose financial ties to Jeffrey Epstein have sparked questions from his powerful clients, said Thursday that it had been a “terrible mistake” to give Mr. Epstein a second chance after his sex-crimes conviction in 2009.

headline: Goodnight to Our Beautiful, Wet Blue Moon
abstract: It was the first full blue moon visible in every time zone since 1944 on Halloween. Let’s learn more about the moon!
lead_paragraph: The moon remains, perpetually and since antiquity, a source of cultural wonder. Last week, when NASA announced that it would reveal “an exciting new discovery” about the moon in a matter of days, the internet, thirsty for distraction, went wild speculating about it. (It happened to be exciting news for space scientists — water and ice on the moon are more accessible than previously thought — but not the supernatural or extraterrestrial news many yearned for.)

headline: What We Know About the Death of Walter Wallace Jr. in Philadelphia
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Looting (Crime)', 'Vandalism', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The fatal shooting of Mr. Wallace, a 27-year-old Black man, set off protests, looting and violent clashes with the police in Pennsylvania, a swing state, days before the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon of Oct. 26, two Philadelphia police officers fatally shot Walter Wallace Jr., a 27-year-old Black man who was armed with a knife. In the nights that followed, protesters clashed with officers in the streets, and city officials imposed a curfew to try to curb the unrest.

headline: You (YOU!) Can Stop Election Rumors
abstract: As Americans vote amid a pandemic, misleading election information seems to be everywhere.

keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: China’s Communist Party emerged from four days of meetings behind closed doors in Beijing declaring the country’s leader, Xi Jinping, a “helmsman” who would lead “the ship of socialism sailing into the wind and waves with determination.”

headline: Yes, We Liked the Berkshires Shows. Here’s $2 Million.
keywords: ['Theater', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: This summer, a woman went to outdoor shows at two beloved theaters in Massachusetts. She and her brother are now helping them to cover their costs and survive this winter.
lead_paragraph: The calls came in late August. A couple who had moved up to the Berkshires during the pandemic had seen the first two union-approved theatrical productions of the summer, and were impressed. Now they had a question: What would it cost to keep those theaters intact for another six months?

headline: Biden and Cunningham Hold Slim Leads in North Carolina, Poll Finds
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Elections, Senate', 'Voting and Voters', 'Absentee Voting']
abstract: Joe Biden and Cal Cunningham both led their Republican rivals by three points, a Times/Siena College survey found. Perhaps most notably, 64 percent of respondents said they had already voted.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. holds a small but durable lead over President Trump in North Carolina, where fully 64 percent of likely voters say they have already cast their ballots, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll released on Thursday.

headline: In M.L.S., the Pandemic Changes the Playoff Math
abstract: The coronavirus sidelined the Colorado Rapids for a month. Other teams missed games, too. How does a league fill a playoff field when not everyone got to play a full schedule?
lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer’s reworked regular season is, at last, racing to a conclusion. Many of the league’s teams have only two games left to play of this year’s truncated, 23-game schedule. Several others must squeeze in three matches in the next 11 days.

headline: How Virus Politics Divided a Conservative Town in Wisconsin’s North
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: A lightly populated area in the critical swing state of Wisconsin serves as a microcosm for the way coronavirus politics is worsening partisan schisms across America.
lead_paragraph: MINOCQUA, Wis. — When coronavirus cases began to spike in Wisconsin this fall, Rob Swearingen kept his restaurant open and let customers and employees decide whether they wanted to wear masks.

headline: Bob Biggs, Los Angeles Punk-Rock Entrepreneur, Dies at 74
abstract: Slash Records, which Mr. Biggs founded in 1979, became one of the most successful independent record labels of its era.
lead_paragraph: Bob Biggs, who sensed opportunity in the Mohawk-filled mosh pits of the Los Angeles punk movement in the late 1970s and founded Slash Records, which became one of the most successful independent record labels of its era, died on Oct. 17 at his ranch in Tehachapi, Calif. He was 74.

headline: Biden’s Call for ‘National Mask Mandate’ Gains Traction in Public Health Circles
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Masks', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'States (US)', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A presidential order would almost certainly face a legal challenge. But if elected, Joseph R. Biden Jr. would have other levers at his disposal to make mask wearing a cultural norm.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the nation heads into what public health experts are calling a “dark winter” of coronavirus illness and death, public health experts are coalescing around Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s call for a “national mask mandate,” even as they concede such an effort would require much more than the stroke of a presidential pen.

abstract: A growing cadre of public health experts is coalescing around Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s call for a “national mask mandate,” even as they concede such an effort would require much more than the stroke of a presidential pen.
lead_paragraph: A growing cadre of public health experts is coalescing around Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s call for a “national mask mandate,” even as they concede such an effort would require much more than the stroke of a presidential pen.

headline: Justice Kavanaugh corrects an error in opinion that alarmed Democrats.

lead_paragraph: Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh on Wednesday corrected an error in an opinion he issued as part of a Supreme Court ruling that barred Wisconsin from counting mail-in ballots that arrive after Election Day.

headline: Women Could Decide the Election. Here’s How They’re Voting.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Women and Girls', 'Voting and Voters']

headline: The Wine World’s Most Elite Circle Has a Sexual Harassment Problem
keywords: ['Wines', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Race and Ethnicity', '#MeToo Movement', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: The Court of Master Sommeliers confers high honors, but many women candidates say they’ve paid a steep price.
lead_paragraph: Master sommelier is the most prestigious title in American wine, and those who earn it instantly join the ranks of the highest-paid and most influential members of the profession.

headline: A Glass House in the Mexican Desert
abstract: Just outside San Miguel de Allende, this modernist retreat reflects natural beauty in more ways than one.
lead_paragraph: At dusk, the house appears as a phosphorescent box, its mirrored panels reflecting the light of the sky and the ocher hues of the mountainside that, as if a mirage, will soon vanish as night falls. Casa Etérea — perched above San Miguel de Allende on the rugged slopes of the extinct Palo Huérfano volcano, part of the greater Los Picachos mountain range of Central Mexico — is both an architectural showpiece and a site-specific art installation, one built to inspire a sense of awe. A feat of sustainable engineering that uses solar energy and collected rainwater, the 800-square-foot dwelling has a glass exterior (with a striped UV-reflective coating) that is bird-friendly — even as it creates the effect of a seemingly infinite landscape.

headline: Ancient Dog DNA Shows Early Spread Around the Globe
abstract: Research on fossil canine genomes is expanding and producing some surprises about the lives of dogs and humans in prehistoric times.
lead_paragraph: The most extensive study of ancient dog DNA to date has shown how rapidly dogs spread across the world after domestication, and pins their likely origin to a group of extinct wolves.

headline: Remarkable Records of Joni Mitchell’s Changes
abstract: A five-disc archival collection traces the beginnings of one of the most daring trajectories in popular music.
lead_paragraph: The story of why Joni Mitchell quit piano lessons is also the story of how Joni Mitchell wrote her first song. She was around 7, and the tune was called “Robin Walk” — “it was real bouncy,” she remembers in a spirited interview with Cameron Crowe for the liner notes of her new archival collection, “Joni Mitchell Archives — Vol. 1: The Early Years (1963-1967).”

keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Wind Power', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: Chris Pendergast, Who Fought A.L.S. Mile After Mile, Dies at 71
abstract: Living for 27 years with Lou Gehrig’s disease (and beating the odds), he started Ride for Life, an annual trek that has raised millions for A.L.S. research.
lead_paragraph: Chris Pendergast, a Long Island teacher who defied the odds by surviving 27 years with Lou Gehrig’s disease, leading marathon “rides for life” for hundreds of miles from his motorized wheelchair to publicize the plight of fellow patients and raise $10 million for research, died on Oct. 14 at his home in Miller Place, N.Y. He was 71.

headline: Hurricane Zeta disrupts early in-person voting in Georgia.
abstract: The morning after Hurricane Zeta’s forceful winds downed power lines, toppled trees and caused road closures across the state of Georgia, widespread outages left more than 600,000 Georgians without electricity and took some of the state’s advanced voting locations offline Thursday — the penultimate day for early, in-person voting.
lead_paragraph: The morning after Hurricane Zeta’s forceful winds downed power lines, toppled trees and caused road closures across the state of Georgia, widespread outages left more than 600,000 Georgians without electricity and took some of the state’s advanced voting locations offline Thursday — the penultimate day for early, in-person voting.

headline: For Retailers, a Halloween Shock: It’s Actually Happening
abstract: Sales of costumes and decorations have been strong, with some seeing the holiday as a last hurrah before winter and the pandemic send people back inside.
lead_paragraph: Scott Morris, a co-owner of Morris Costumes in Charlotte, N.C., has slept at the office for the past 50 days — but he isn’t complaining.

headline: After Terror Attacks, Muslims Wonder About Their Place in France
abstract: French officials’ attack on “Islamic separatism” and the “enemy within” has Muslims questioning whether they will ever fully be accepted.
lead_paragraph: IVRY-SUR-SEINE, France — At age 42, Mehdy Belabbas embodied the French republican promise of upward social mobility: the son of a Muslim construction worker of Algerian descent, he was the first in his family to attend graduate school and served for 12 years as the deputy mayor of the working-class city where he grew up.

headline: Biden leads in a new poll in Pennsylvania, one of the states that may decide the election.
abstract: Quinnipiac University released polls in four major swing states on Thursday, showing former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. leading in Pennsylvania, narrowly ahead in Ohio, and effectively tied with President Trump in Florida and Iowa.

headline: The Venezuelan-American Vote, From a First-Timer in Florida

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — This year I’ll be voting for the first time in a U.S. presidential election. Registering to vote online, the option to mail-in my ballot or vote early — it’s all new to me.

headline: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: To a horror fan, “Halloween vs. Covid-19” sounds almost as promising as “Godzilla vs. Kong.” But in the end it’s been no real contest — not in my neighborhood, anyway, where health officials are reminding people that parties are a bad idea this year and recommending that children forgo the usual trick-or-treating. That’s ironic, maybe, for a holiday meant to show that we’re not afraid of death. But there you have it. We’re afraid of death.

headline: A Top Aide to Saddam Hussein Is Reported Dead

lead_paragraph: One of the most senior leaders of Saddam Hussein’s government and the highest-ranking figure to have eluded capture after the American invasion in 2003 has died, according to Iraqi officials and the deceased dictator’s Baath Party.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Embarrassing Parents, Personal Style and Social Media Perceptions
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Xi sets the tone for the next five years.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of migrant workers who have largely been confined to dormitories since last spring will be allowed to visit designated recreation centers on their days off starting Saturday, if they test negative for the coronavirus.

headline: Economy’s Big Rebound Leaves a Shortfall as Progress Slows
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']

keywords: ['Movies', 'Witchcraft', 'Women and Girls', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']

headline: Tony La Russa Returns at 76, Ready to Combine Old Wisdom and New Data
abstract: Baseball strategy has changed rapidly since La Russa last managed, in 2011. After being hired by the White Sox on Thursday, he said he would use both his own baseball experience and advanced analytics.
lead_paragraph: Tony La Russa has a permanent home along the top row of the back wall in the Hall of Fame’s plaque gallery in Cooperstown, N.Y., between Bobby Cox and Frank Thomas. That is where visitors will find La Russa: in profile, lips creased, eyes focused, a strategist in bronze. The first sentence of the text below his image cites his 2,728 victories, the third most for a manager.

headline: Billy Joe Shaver, Outlaw Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 81
abstract: Waylon Jennings put him on the musical map. Elvis Presley and Johnny Cash recorded his material. Bob Dylan sang admiringly of listening to his music.
lead_paragraph: Billy Joe Shaver, the Texas singer-songwriter whose trenchant, vivid compositions helped launch country music’s outlaw movement in the 1970s, died on Wednesday in Waco, Texas. He was 81.

headline: No Selfies or Hugs, but Biden Is Sneaking In Meet and Greets
abstract: From a distance, with an elbow tap instead of a hug, the former vice president is getting a version of the in-person campaigning he loves.
lead_paragraph: Before a speech this month in Durham, N.C., Joseph R. Biden Jr. made his way around a circle of participants, chatting with each of them before posing for a group photograph. In Chester, Pa., a week later, he kibitzed with supporters, playfully punching one in the arm. And on a recent trip to Florida, his private schedule for the day included time for a photo line.

headline: Why Is Europe Keeping Its Schools Open, Despite New Lockdowns?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Politics and Government', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Europe’s latest wave of restrictions to stop the spread of coronavirus have largely avoided closing schools. We take a look at why and how they are being kept open.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When Chancellor Angela Merkel announced the latest round of restrictions on public life, she named bars, restaurants, theaters, concert halls, gyms and tattoo parlors as institutions that would be forced to close. But missing from the list released on Wednesday were schools and day care centers — among the first to be shuttered in the spring lockdown.

headline: Biden leans into climate change with two new ads.

headline: Lingering Mail Problems Worry Voters in Final Week of Election
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The Postal Service’s performance has not been as bad as initially feared, but handling of mail ballots has been inconsistent enough that some people are choosing to vote in person.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — She waited and waited for her mail-in ballot to arrive until — finally, maddeningly — she could wait no more.

headline: Film Club: ‘Three Families. Nine Weeks. ‘Things Are Getting Annoying.’’
abstract: What lessons about family have you learned during the pandemic?
lead_paragraph: “Three Families. Nine Weeks. ‘Things Are Getting Annoying.’” profiles three families, seven parents and nine kids who filmed themselves and share what it has been like to work, parent, school, eat, sleep and hang out all jammed under one roof for three months straight during quarantine. This eight-minute film touches on themes of family, love, conflict and perseverance and offers many practical and often humorous lessons on parenting in a pandemic like “Trust your kids to do their work,” “Don’t force mindfulness” and “Don’t forget to follow your own rules.”

headline: From Bolivia, Lessons for a Successful Election
abstract: In the last year, Bolivia’s democracy suffered as partisan clashes filled its streets and mistrust in government grew. And yet it pulled off a calm, uncontested election. What can it teach other democracies under siege?
lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia — As nationalism, misinformation and the pandemic have emerged as threats to democracy — and a presidential election has roiled the United States — the relatively small nation of Bolivia, in political upheaval for most its 195-year history, managed a free and fair vote.

headline: U.S. to Remove Wolves From Protected Species List
abstract: Populations have rebounded in recent decades, but some scientists on the panel that evaluated the proposal said it was deeply flawed.
lead_paragraph: Gray wolves, one of the first animals shielded by the Endangered Species Act after Americans all but exterminated them in the lower 48 states, will no longer receive federal protection, officials announced Thursday.

headline: Slump in Air Travel Hindered Weather Forecasting, Study Shows

lead_paragraph: I always know when my older daughter is about to cry. She’s 9 now, but her voice still gives her away, a slight squeak settling into her words. When she doesn’t speak, her cheeks show me, a blush spreading out from their centers. It was this way one night in late August as she pulled pajamas from her drawers.

headline: An Astronomer’s Guide to Stargazing with Your Space-Obsessed Kid
keywords: ['Moon', 'Mars (Planet)', 'Uranus (Planet)', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Saturn (Planet)', 'Jupiter (Planet)', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Planets', 'Venus (Planet)', 'Milky Way Galaxy', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Content Type: Service', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting']
abstract: How to find constellations, planets and stories in the sky.
lead_paragraph: As a little girl growing up in Portugal, Raquel Nuno made birthday wishes upon shooting stars. She was born near the peak of the Perseids meteor shower, one of the most prolific annual cosmic light shows. Every year her father whisked her and her family away to the beach to celebrate under the celestial fireworks. There, she gazed up at the dazzling display amid a backdrop of stars as countless as the grains of sand at her feet.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Unemployment During the Pandemic
abstract: Who wants a job, but doesn’t have one? How has the composition of the unemployed in the United States changed during the pandemic?
lead_paragraph: Our next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” live-moderated discussion will take place on Wednesday,  Nov. 18.

headline: A Man in a Black Ski Mask Cuts Short a 17-Year-Old’s Life
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Derek Trucios, 17, was the third teenager to die in Brooklyn this week, as a wave of gun violence takes a high toll among young New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Derek Trucios was still a high school student, just 17, but he already was talking about going to medical school. He had finished his online courses on Wednesday afternoon and was strolling with a 16-year-old friend down a residential Brooklyn street when a man in a black ski mask came up to them.

headline: Big Tech Continues Its Surge Ahead of the Rest of the Economy

abstract: “Rats crawling on him, he can’t move,” said the brother of the man, who was rescued after about 30 minutes and remains hospitalized in stable condition.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday just past noon, Leonard Shoulders strolled up to a bus stop in the Belmont neighborhood of the Bronx. A handful of people stood around, waiting for their rides or looking down at their phones — an unremarkable scene.

keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Drownings']
abstract: About 200 migrants were aboard a boat that caught fire and capsized on Saturday, hours after it had left Senegal for the Canary Islands, according to the International Organization for Migration.
lead_paragraph: At least 140 people drowned when a boat carrying migrants sank off the Senegalese coast over the weekend in the deadliest shipwreck this year, the International Organization for Migration, a United Nations agency, said on Thursday.

keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Writing and Writers', 'News and News Media', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: He was a Twitter pioneer in writing at length, 140 characters at a time, about losing his job at The New Yorker. He also wrote an admired book on New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Dan Baum had been a successful freelance writer and author for 17 years when he landed a staff writing job at The New Yorker. He called it “the ne plus ultra of journalism gigs.”

headline: Holidays Must Look Different This Year. Lives Are at Stake.
keywords: ['Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Families and Family Life', 'Quarantines', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates']
abstract: This year’s holiday season will be hard. But shared sacrifice will keep coronavirus outbreaks from spreading further.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, the coronavirus is still a mystery. Scientists can’t say for certain why it’s deadly or debilitating in some people but has virtually no effect in others. They don’t know exactly how long immunity lasts or whether (or when) a vaccine will stop its spread and bring this wretched chapter to a close.

headline: Lies, Damned Lies and Trump Rallies
keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Who you gonna believe, me or your own eyes?
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump lies a lot. In fact, he lies so often that several media organizations try to keep a running tally, and even try to draw political inferences from fluctuations in the number of lies he tells in a given month (although the trend has been relentlessly upward).

keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Absentee Voting', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Choua Yang, Hmong Refugee and Educator, Dies at 53
abstract: With her husband, she founded Prairie Seeds Academy in Minneapolis, a charter school centered on Hmong language, culture and heritage. She died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Dems Mess With Texas
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: Is this the year that Texas turns blue? Even if not, there’s no denying the political shift in the Lone Star State.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Jimmy Orr, a Favorite Target of the Colts’ Unitas, Dies at 85
abstract: He and Baltimore’s Hall of Fame quarterback were a top passing combination in the ’60s. But he may be best remembered for the pass that never came his way.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Orr, the Baltimore Colts’ receiver who teamed with quarterback Johnny Unitas in one of the N.F.L.’s leading passing combinations of the 1960s, died on Tuesday at his home in Brunswick, Ga., in the state’s coastal low country. He was 85.

headline: Trump and Biden Converge in Florida, an Elusive Prize Still Up for Grabs
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The presidential rivals both appeared in Tampa, confronting their vulnerabilities and courting a range of voters, a clear sign that both see their political fortunes tied to the state.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — That old political heartbreaker, the presidential battleground of Florida, lured the two White House contenders to the same city on Thursday, as President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. confronted some of their biggest political vulnerabilities in a state that is once again shaping up as the most elusive prize in next week’s election.

headline: Trump’s Hard-Line Immigration Policies Go Before Voters
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Border Barriers', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: The administration has raced to build the president’s promised border wall and block migrants from entering the United States, but the future of those policies will be determined by the election.
lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Texas — The leadership of the Department of Homeland Security gathered on Thursday under the shadow of 30-foot, black-painted, steel bollards to promote the near completion of 400 miles of President Trump’s border wall.

headline: Five Great Things Biden Has Already Done
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: We’re learning not to underestimate the guy.
lead_paragraph: Many of our best presidents have been underestimated. Truman was seen as the tool of a corrupt political machine. Eisenhower was supposedly a bumbling middlebrow. Grant was thought a taciturn simpleton. Even F.D.R. was once considered a lightweight feather duster.

headline: Clemson’s Trevor Lawrence Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
abstract: The star quarterback, who will miss this weekend’s game against Boston College, said he had “relatively mild” symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Lawrence, the star quarterback at top-ranked Clemson and a leading contender for the Heisman Trophy, has tested positive for coronavirus, the university said Thursday night.

headline: The Original Nachos Were Crunchy, Cheesy and Truly Mexican
abstract: Ballpark and Tex-Mex nachos are both ubiquitous in the United States. But the original version is deeply rooted in the borderlands and Mexican home cooking.
lead_paragraph: The biggest claim to fame for the border city of Piedras Negras, in Coahuila, Mexico, is that it was the birthplace of nachos, one of America’s most popular snacks. Yet that fact is not widely known beyond the region, something that has long frustrated the people of Piedras, as locals call their hometown. They’re so proud of their invention that they started the International Nacho Festival there in 1995.

headline: First Pass Friday
abstract: Trenton Charlson would like to think that he got me. But he didn’t.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Welcome back to a featurette that I like to call “First Pass Friday,” where solvers get to see how I did on the first tricky themeless puzzle of the week and, subsequently, feel much, much better about themselves.

headline: Will ‘Mank’ Be Netflix’s First Best-Picture Winner?
abstract: David Fincher’s new film about the making of “Citizen Kane” could be an Oscar favorite in a year dominated by streaming contenders.
lead_paragraph: “Citizen Kane” has cast a vast cinematic shadow for nearly eight decades, sitting atop countless lists of the greatest films ever made.

abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Oct. 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the use of conservative judicial appointments as an incentive for people to vote Republican misstated the number of vacancies in the federal appellate courts. Several hours before Justice Amy Coney Barrett was confirmed by the Senate, a judge from the First Circuit, Juan Torruella, died. The courts now have two vacancies, not one.

headline: N.H.L. Team Drops Top Draft Pick Accused of Racist Bullying
keywords: ['Abuse of the Disabled', 'Hockey, Ice', 'Draft and Recruitment (Sports)', 'Bullies', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The Arizona Coyotes knew that the player, Mitchell Miller, had been convicted of abusing a Black classmate. On Friday, Miller’s college team dropped him, too.
lead_paragraph: The Arizona Coyotes said on Thursday that they had renounced the rights to their top pick in this year’s N.H.L. draft after a published report described the player’s 2016 conviction in a juvenile-court case related to bullying of a Black classmate who has a developmental disability.

headline: The Ghost Was the Least of Our Problems
abstract: After spooky things started happening in our new house, a scary thing happened in our marriage.
lead_paragraph: My ghost is a mother. I am convinced of this by both the ghost’s behavior and the history of our house. You see, a mother died here, on the property. We were told the three-story Victorian was being sold “as is” after the longtime owners, a couple, had died tragically.

headline: Travis Roy, Who Inspired Millions After a Hockey Tragedy, Dies at 45
abstract: After an awkward fall 11 seconds into his first Boston University game left him a quadriplegic, he dedicated his life to advocacy for similarly disabled people.
lead_paragraph: Travis Roy, who suffered a paralyzing injury just 11 seconds into his first hockey game for Boston University in 1995 and, as a philanthropist and motivational speaker, was revered by the sports world as an example of determination and courage, died on Thursday in a hospital outside Burlington, Vt. He was 45.

headline: New Zealand’s Advance Preview of a Post-Virus World
abstract: What it feels like to leave New York and land in a parallel universe of calm politics and good health.
lead_paragraph: Roughly three weeks ago, I stepped off a plane and into a parallel universe. Here in New Zealand, coronavirus lurks far from the limelight, the recent election was orderly and uncontroversial, and the national mood — for the most part — approximates relief and even elation.

headline: In Avignon, Snatching Theater From the Jaws of New Lockdowns
abstract: Delayed from the summer, France’s biggest stage celebration was further curtailed as restrictions again hit the country. That made the moments of grace that were possible all the more powerful.
lead_paragraph: AVIGNON, France — Festivalgoers who cross the medieval ramparts of Avignon are used to being greeted with a riot of activity. Every July, thousands of posters cover the city’s walls to advertise stage productions as the official Avignon Festival and its Fringe compete for attention. Seemingly every street corner brings hopeful performers ready to pitch their work to passers-by, day and night.

headline: A Korean news agency publishes an op-ed from Biden.
abstract: A South Korean news agency published an op-ed from Joe Biden.
lead_paragraph: In the waning days of the presidential race, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden is straying way off the traditional political map to chase votes: He delivered a closing argument in an op-ed published Friday by a prominent South Korean news agency.

headline: Biden and Trump will criss-cross the Midwest as the campaign enters its last weekend.
abstract: President Trump will campaign in Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin on Friday, while Joseph R. Biden Jr. heads for Minnesota, Wisconsin and Iowa.
lead_paragraph: With Election Day less than 100 hours away, the Trump and Biden campaigns are fanning out across the crucial swing states that are likely to decide the race. The president will campaign in Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin today, while Joseph R. Biden Jr. travels to Minnesota, Wisconsin and Iowa.

headline: Prosecutors Call Former Embassy Employee an ‘Experienced Sexual Predator’
abstract: Brian Jeffrey Raymond, who worked at the U.S. Embassy in Mexico, was charged with videotaping a woman who was partially naked and unconscious. Prosecutors said there are at least 21 other victims.
lead_paragraph: A former employee at the U.S. Embassy in Mexico, described by prosecutors as an “experienced sexual predator,” was arrested in San Diego this month and charged with videotaping and photographing a woman while she was partially naked and unconscious.

headline: A vote-counting official in Florida who gave money to Trump’s campaign resigns.
abstract: The acting chairman of the county board that inspects and tabulates mail-in ballots in Jacksonville, Fla., resigned on Thursday amid criticism that he had made political donations to President Trump and displayed his campaign signs at his home.
lead_paragraph: The acting chairman of the county board that inspects and tabulates mail-in ballots in Jacksonville, Fla., resigned on Thursday amid criticism that he had made political donations to President Trump and displayed his campaign signs at his home.

headline: An unproven Covid-19 drug is turning out to be a proven moneymaker for its manufacturer.
abstract: The United States reached a milestone, of sorts, when last week the Food and Drug Administration approved the first treatment for Covid-19: Veklury, better known by its scientific name, remdesivir.
lead_paragraph: The United States reached a milestone, of sorts, when last week the Food and Drug Administration approved the first treatment for Covid-19: Veklury, better known by its scientific name, remdesivir.

headline: In voting cases, Chief Justice Roberts is alone but in control.

lead_paragraph: In a little over a week, the Supreme Court issued five sets of orders in election cases. In three of them, Democrats prevailed.

headline: Late Night Is Too Nervous to Believe in Biden-Leading Polls
abstract: “It feels like we’re all Charlie Brown going to kick the football, but we know at the last second Lucy’s gonna give us coronavirus,” Stephen Colbert joked on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Biden leads by 3 points in North Carolina, a Times/Siena College poll found.
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. holds a small but durable lead over President Trump in North Carolina, where 64 percent of likely voters say they have already cast their ballots, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll released on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. holds a small but durable lead over President Trump in North Carolina, where 64 percent of likely voters say they have already cast their ballots, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll released on Thursday.

abstract: How do you feel about naps?

headline: ‘Rogue City’ Review: An Action Movie Skimping on Action
abstract: Olivier Marchal’s film proves that gangsters and crooked cops can speak French and still spin clichés.
lead_paragraph: Crime fiction has long been fascinated by the fuzzy line between crooked cops and the criminals they are meant to chase. The new French film “Rogue City” tramples it, positing that corruption is pervasive and we live in a hopeless, brutal world from which there is no escape. It’s a bleak vision that makes Olivier Marchal’s movie radical in its nihilism.

headline: These Are the Perks Companies Use to Get Workers Back to Their Offices
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Corporations', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Free lunch. Discounted parking. Learning pods for children. Some New York City companies are offering incentives to workers who are required to return to the office.
lead_paragraph: At the headquarters of SL Green, a real estate company in Manhattan, employees walk the halls with masks on, line up with proper spacing for free lunch and sit at cubicles behind plastic barriers that rise up well over six feet.

headline: These Zombies Threaten the Whole Planet
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Drilling and Boring', 'Methane']
abstract: Canada’s oil patch has nearly 100,000 suspended wells, neither active nor capped, and they’re a worrying source of planet-warming methane.
lead_paragraph: REDWATER, Alberta — William Romaniuk stopped his tractor at the edge of his field and sniffed. A breeze came off the North Saskatchewan River, rippling across rows of ripe wheat, but a caustic scent flooded his nose. An oil well between his crops and the river was leaking, and enough gas was flowing out of a pipe below the rusty pump jack that the farmer could smell gas and see it swirling in the air.

headline: After Jon Ossoff calls him a ‘crook’ during a Georgia Senate debate, David Perdue cancels final one.
abstract: Senator Perdue of Georgia cancels his final debate with Jon Ossoff after Ossoff calls him a ‘crook.’
lead_paragraph: The Republican Georgia Senator David Perdue withdrew on Thursday from the final debate in his tight re-election race a day after his Democratic challenger, Jon Ossoff, called him a “crook” and accused him of trying to profit from the coronavirus.

headline: New Zealand Voters Approve Euthanasia but Reject Recreational Marijuana
abstract: Proponents of legalizing cannabis voiced anger at Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, who revealed only after the referendum that she supported it.
lead_paragraph: New Zealand will join a small number of countries that have legalized euthanasia after its citizens voted overwhelmingly in favor of it in a referendum this month.

headline: As virus cases surge to new records, outbreaks in swing states could shape the election.
abstract: With over 9 million U.S. coronavirus cases, outbreaks in swing states could shape the election.
lead_paragraph: Voters in several swing states are casting their ballots even as the coronavirus reaches new peaks in their communities, creating more uncertainty about how they will vote — and for whom.

headline: How Do You Feel About Censored Music?
abstract: Do you ever listen to songs with lyrics that are explicit, suggestive or violent? Do your parents have rules about what you can and can’t listen to?
lead_paragraph: What kind of music do you listen to? Do you ever listen to songs with lyrics that are explicit, suggestive or violent? Do you prefer the clean versions of these songs or the unedited ones? Why?

headline: A Nice Riff on Love
abstract: Priscilla Page and Glenn Siegel met while organizing a concert at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. They later founded a jazz series in Western Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: In early October, Priscilla Maria Page and Glenn Steven Siegel watched the jazz saxophonist Charlie Kohlhase lead a band outdoors, where the musicians’ notes cut through fall air. The location of the concert, by a creek outside the Institute for the Musical Arts in Goshen, Mass., was one that Ms. Page and Mr. Siegel had selected: The performance was the latest in a long line of jazz shows that the couple has organized in the region. So it’s natural that when, during the concert, Ms. Page and Mr. Siegel noticed a pair of gnarled apple tree stumps sitting a modest stage length’s apart from each other, they couldn’t help but do a little location scouting.

headline: What Losing My Father Taught Me About Parenting, Planets and Pain
abstract: Pain, both physical and emotional, is not something to be feared; it’s something to learn to manage, no matter your age, health or time left to live.
lead_paragraph: “There’s pain, and then there’s stepping on a Lego in the middle of the night,” my father often repeated with a laugh when his grandkids visited. They took over his living room, dining table, bedroom floors and bedside tables with messes of plastic blocks haphazardly assembled to resemble something magical and grand, excavated from the depths of their imaginations.

headline: From Melbourne to New York, Oceans Couldn’t Keep Them Apart
abstract: Stephanie Hains and Christian Nilsson met up for a Tinder date never expecting to see one another again. Instead, they began a long-distance relationship.
lead_paragraph: As rain pelted the London streets, Stephanie Hains and Christian Nilsson were scaling an iron gate at 2 a.m. The two, who met on Tinder and were enjoying a first date, had found themselves locked into Hyde Park.

headline: On-Again, Off-Again, but a Cabdriver Knew They’d Get Married
abstract: Sarah Koatz and Stuart Winchester once rode in a yellow cab with a driver who told them they would get married someday.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Beverly Koatz and Stuart Hopkins Winchester had no idea where their relationship was going in March 2013, but the “Cupid Cabbie” did. By the end of their yellow taxi ride one evening from Union Square to the Upper East Side in New York, he told them they would get married someday.

headline: This Election Map Will Be Everywhere. Don’t Let It Fool You.
abstract: It’s full of tricks and optical illusions.
lead_paragraph: It’s full of tricks and optical illusions.

abstract: Cases, hospitalizations and deaths across much of the country are the highest they have been during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Cases, hospitalizations and deaths across much of the country are the highest they have been during the pandemic.

headline: Do Hospitals Value Everyone? This Winter, They Have a Chance to Prove It
abstract: We need a better system of transferring patients to ensure the best care during the next phase of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — As hospitals in much of the country face a surge in patients with Covid-19 and the threat of influenza this fall and winter, we must be on guard against attempts to restrict patient admissions or limit intensive-care capacity. The incentives will certainly be there for hospitals to do so.

headline: Friends Since Eighth Grade, Married With a New Urgency
abstract: David Rhoades and Nicole Weiss have been a couple since high school. A diagnosis brought them even closer together.
lead_paragraph: David Rhoades skipped a lot of school in the mid-2000s as a student at Sturgis Brown High School in Sturgis, S.D. Not much held his attention, besides a girl a year younger who was good at painting and drawing.

headline: Trump Has Made the Whole World Darker
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: America has become just as cynically transactional in its foreign dealings as Russia and China.
lead_paragraph: There is no escaping it: America is on the ballot on Tuesday — the stability and quality of our governing institutions, our alliances, how we treat one another, our basic commitment to scientific principles and the minimum decency that we expect from our leaders. The whole ball of wax is on the ballot.

headline: The Woman President Who Wasn’t
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Trump may have beaten Hillary Clinton, but the story doesn’t end there.
lead_paragraph: One of my clearest memories of election night in 2016 is running into women who were going to watch the results with their daughters, so they’d get to share the experience of seeing Hillary Clinton elected president — the moment when the political glass ceiling in America would be shattered forever.

headline: Goodbye Principled Conservatism
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Under Trump, the politics of resentment now govern the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: If Amy Coney Barrett’s confirmation to the Supreme Court turns out to be the last major act of a one-term Trump presidency, it will be a fitting finale. Republicans, like the Federalist Party of yore, will consolidate power in the judiciary. Apart from that, they will have spent the past four years squandering their reputation, forsaking their principles, and trashing the kind of political culture they once claimed to hold dear.

headline: At First He Ghosted, Then They Became a Couple
abstract: Samyukta Mullangi and Mohit Agrawal connected on the dating app the League. He disappeared for two months, but when he re-emerged, they had a six-hour first date.
lead_paragraph: In July 2018, Dr. Samyukta Mullangi, now 31 and a first-year hematology-oncology fellow at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York, met Mohit Agrawal, also 31 and the deputy policy director to Gov. Ned Lamont, Democrat of Connecticut, on the dating app the League.

headline: Don’t Write Off the Persistent Man From California
abstract: She is a planner and he is not, and she lived in New York City while he lives in California’s East Bay. Nonetheless, they made it work.
lead_paragraph: A few matters might have stood in the way of a relationship between Mallika Pereira and Dr. Kennedy Cosgrove. She is a committed planner and he said his best friend in medical school referred to him as “Mr. TBD.” She lived in New York. He lives in Lafayette, Calif.

headline: Biden Can Fix Latinos’ Disappointment With Democrats
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: Have We Learned Nothing After Four Years of Trump?
abstract: The 2016 election should have forced change on all our factions. With Trump’s help, they’ve all reverted back to type.
lead_paragraph: In the original Greek the term “apocalypse” refers to an unveiling, the gray rain clouds of the everyday world torn away and something long hidden finally revealed. The political apocalypse of 2016, when Donald Trump improbably vanquished the establishment of both parties, fits this ancient definition perfectly: It was a moment when all kinds of uncomfortable truths about American life were suddenly exposed, when the hidden realities of our country and our coalitions were suddenly dragged up into the light, when the failures in both parties and every faction were laid bare.

headline: Don’t Fool Yourself. Trump Is Not an Aberration.
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Epidemics', 'Slavery (Historical)']
abstract: Many of the worst things the president has said and done were said and done by his predecessors.
lead_paragraph: For many millions of Americans, the presidency of Donald Trump has been a kind of transgression, an endless assault on dignity, decency and decorum. They experience everything — the casual insults, the vulgar tweets, the open racism, the lying, the tacit support for dangerous extremists and admiration of foreign strongmen — as an attack on the fabric of American society itself. And they see the worst of this administration, like separating children from their families at the border, as an unparalleled offense against the values of American democracy.

headline: Why India’s Muslims Reach for Liberalism

It is common knowledge that Mr. Modi thrives on the grievances and bigotries that pit privileged majorities against minorities living in fear.

While prowling grungy, postindustrial Bushwick on his old Dawes bicycle, he turned the corner onto a one-block street called Belvidere and found himself gawking at what looked like an intimate little castle made of fiery orange-red brick and terra cotta.

Sometimes, she said, “I get into a slump and can’t get out.” Several times, psychotherapy had helped her regain her equilibrium.

This week, we’re looking at an untitled in-progress painting by Henry Taylor, who is known for almost impressionistic portraits that are inspired by memory, history and scenes of everyday life. Taylor’s first exhibition with Hauser & Wirth will open at the gallery’s space in Somerset, England, in February.

Skakel, a neighbor and a cousin of the Kennedys, was ultimately charged and found guilty of murder, but his conviction was overturned by the state’s highest court.

lead_paragraph: It’s all Byron’s fault. Before James Dean and Gary Cooper and Heathcliff and Rochester — all the real and fictional men lounging at the center of the Venn diagram of “bad boys” and “sad boys” — Byron made such a career of drinking, lusting and gallivanting that he became a type. The Byronic hero: temperamental, hedonistic and romantic. “I am such a strange mélange of good and evil,” the poet once wrote of himself, “that it would be difficult to describe me.” Save it for your Tinder profile, bro.

Tiffany & Company, the luxury jeweler, said that “windows of select stores in key cities will be boarded in anticipation of potential election-related activity.” Saks Fifth Avenue said it was “implementing additional security measures at certain locations in the event of civil unrest due to the current election.”

abstract: Outraged by a court decision to ban nearly all abortions, tens of thousands of women took to the streets of Poland’s capital on Friday, culminating a week of big protests across the country.

headline: What Went Viral This Week

abstract: Halloween decorations, Harry Styles and a QAnon-adjacent missing children story broke up a wall of pre-election political news.
lead_paragraph: Here at Daily Distortions, we try to debunk false and misleading information that has gone viral. We also want to give you a sense of how popular that misinformation is, in the overall context of what is being discussed on social media. Each Friday, we feature a list of the 10 most-engaged stories of the week in the United States, as ranked by NewsWhip, a firm that compiles social media performance data. (NewsWhip tracks the number of reactions, shares and comments each story receives on Facebook, along with shares on Pinterest and by a group of influential users on Twitter.) This week’s data runs from 9:01 a.m. on Friday, Oct. 23, until 9 a.m. on Friday, Oct. 30.

headline: Hospitalizations rise in N.Y.C., but stays are shorter and fewer patients are dying.
abstract: Hospitalizations have been slowly but steadily rising in New York City, eliciting painful memories of the surge of infections in the spring that killed more than 20,000 people. But this time is different: Patients with serious cases are spending less time in the hospital on average and are less likely to be put on ventilators. And fewer patients are dying.

lead_paragraph: As a veteran television journalist, Sally-Ann Roberts knows how to tame an unsteady landscape and will it into submission. She survived 40 years reporting and anchoring the news for WWL-TV in New Orleans, covering 10 races for mayor and in 2005, Hurricane Katrina, a storm that submerged four-fifths of the city in water and left her rebuilding her home for nearly two unforgiving years. But as far as grandparenting during the coronavirus pandemic, she says she’s met her match.

headline: ‘The Mandalorian’ Season Premiere Recap: Back in the Saddle With Baby Yoda
abstract: The first episode of Season 2, released on Friday, suggests that the Disney+ space western probably won’t move far, far away from what worked last year.
lead_paragraph: Almost a year ago, the “Star Wars” spinoff series “The Mandalorian” debuted on Disney+ with a first episode that had been kept mostly under wraps — unseen by the critics and largely unspoiled by advertising. That secrecy preserved what turned out to be a wonderful surprise: the introduction a fun new character, called “the Child” on the show but immediately dubbed “Baby Yoda” by the fans. This tiny, adorable, superpowered creature became TV’s breakout star last fall, raising the question of what Jon Favreau, the creator of “The Mandalorian,” might possibly spring on the audience in the second season.
